> 4. Zero visibility "where am I?" fog at some times.

TWaxx said...

 > like that)...they have it at star alley in linden alley (near hayes &
 > franklin).  it's got several mixes, one by folks that you guys mention

Speaking of Star Alley, lately they seem to have really gotten it
together. They've got most things opened for listening now, they've
reorganized things a *lot* better, and they've been buying lots of
good music (well, I've been finding great stuff there lately).

The way they used to do things really bugged me, and I complained, and
they must have listened or something, because they've fixed most of it
(they still need 1200s instead of those antiques though). Anyway, I
like what they've done, so I thought I'd make a plug for them.

Sean

 > >As a dedicated smoker, I think smoke machines are great.  As well as the
 > >spectacular effects you get with a few lasers, it actually feels as if my
 > >lungs are being *cleaned* compared to the abuse they normally receive!

 > Ah, perhaps that's because the mineral oil they use in foggers, is
 > a normally used as a laxative in it's liquid state.

Most foggers use water-glycerin fog (which is why it tastes sweet).
Glycerin is somewhat viscous, and when you breathe in enough, it's
going to gum up your lungs a bit. No biggie for most people, and maybe
a biggie for those with breathing problems.

Sean

Something wierd has been happening with my sfraves filter ever since 
sfr switched homes.  A lot of mail doesn't seem to pass through my
filter but ends up in my regular mailbox.  This wasn't really a problem
because the volume wasn't great but when I logged on this time 90%
of the "Pronoia Projection" thread was in my inbox.  That was kinda
annoying.  In the past all mail from Tenderloin Waxx, and some from
Brian Behlendorf and Tony Garcia ended up in my regular box.  What
I noticed about the pronoia stuff was that all the mail was 
"Cc:" to sfraves.  Could this be the reason?  I haven't made any changes
to my filter (I wouldn't know how if I tried) and the only change
has been the moving of sfr.  Anyway, if anyone can help me clean
this up I'd be grateful.

BTW, the location announcement for the Burning Man breakfast will be 
posted on an actual cork bulletin board at the campsite not on a
computer bulletin board.  Just to clear up the confusion...  Can't
wait, 24 hours and counting. :)

Thanks.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  1 15:14:37 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id PAA13057; Thu, 1 Sep 1994 15:14:37 -0700
Received: from media.mit.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id PAA13051; Thu, 1 Sep 1994 15:14:27 -0700
Received: by media.mit.edu (5.57/DA1.0.4.amt)
	id AA23949; Thu, 1 Sep 94 18:14:15 -0400
Date: Thu, 1 Sep 94 18:14:15 -0400
From: Bob Ramstad <boccibob@media.mit.edu>
Message-Id: <9409012214.AA23949@media.mit.edu>
To: pandora@hulk.sfsu.edu
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: Candice's message of Thu, 1 Sep 1994 09:17:21 -40962758 (PDT) <199409011617.JAA25498@hulk.sfsu.edu>
Subject: mail question
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


get procmail.  (you may already be using it.)  it works great.

my .procmailrc includes, among other things:

:0:
* ^TOsfraves
sfraves

and magically everything is totally groovy.  this catches mail to
sfraves-planners as well, btw, and doesn't care if 'sfraves' is in the
to: or cc: field.

(note that if the second line read '* ^To: sfraves' anything which had
'sfraves' in the cc: field but not in the to: field would end up in
your mail mailbox.  the ^TO is a euphemism for checking a whole slew
of fields, including X-Sender: and other nuveau trendy fields like
that.  basically it ends up working the way you think it should.)

procmail is capable of insanely complicated and wildly useful
behavior, too.  (funny how those two things are often found together.)

yowsa,
Bob

I think there's much more going on than I have here, but there's also
plenty of stuff here - the burning man festival, groove kitchen, boogie
buffet, sunset, spundae, and the new moon party are all good bets.
rest one day then go to come/unity. :)  The others - ooga booga, tribute
chemistry and cumulus all could be cool too, so don't stay home...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Friday, September 2nd - Monday, September 5th - Burning Man Festival
        in Black Rock Desert in Nevada.
        SFR get-together courtesy of pandora@hulk.sfsu.edu:
        > Looks like we'll be serving up oatmeal Saturday morning at Burning 
        > Man.  Bring your favorite toppings (and a little to share with
        > everyone).  Fruit, brown sugar, or what have you.  I'm gonna bring
        > a little milk to cool the oatmeal down but I can't bring a lot 
        > because my coolers full.  If anyone else can bring some to contribute
        > that would be great.  Look for the location info on the Burning Man
        > community board.  Oh, if you can't bring anything, don't worry,
        > *please* come and eat with us anyway.

Friday, September 2nd - ooga booga finale
        robbie hardkiss - jeno - thomas - dan - simon
        9pm - 7am  location: 916.484.4006

Friday, September 2nd - Tribute: Justin and Gabrial -
        Dance in Celebration of their Lives
        DJs: Utopia, Grame-La Paix, Carlos, Dutch, Christophe
        Live Performance:  Darwin Chamber
        Lazers by Hollywood Dog  Sound by Chuck McKay
        "in a beautiful exclusive outdoor location" (near Redding)
        Free of charge (916) 224-0508

Saturday, September 3rd - Groove Kitchen
        Mark Farina  Markie  John Howard
        10pm-sunup  415.267.7615

Saturday, September 3rd - CDC Sound System presents the final of Chemistry
        415.615.8559

Saturday, September 3rd - The Cloud Factory presents Cumulus  
        dj's  Deaks  HDW   Tim Mcknew    Donut  and others
        live sounds found and created by Aural Anesthesia
        $3  outdoors   call 408.755.2461 for map point info

Sunday, September 4th - Spundae 
        DJ Dan  Simon  Jeno  Sool  Dutch  Carlos  Josh  Tony  Tara
        Markie Mark  Jay-J  David Alvarado  Mark Farina  Miguel
        Suiki  John Howard  Terence Toy 
        visuals by Pure & Synergy       
        9pm-8am.  cheeper b4 10:30pm.  21+.  55 Natoma, SF.
        supports Project Open Hand.  
        415.974.9389    415.764.2922

Sunday, September 4th - new moon party

Wednesday, September 7th - Come/Unity - 415.241.8815

Saturday, September 10th - Wicked
        Jeno  Garth  Markie  Thomas
        415.512.5713

Saturday, September 10th - DreamTime - "Close your eyes and dream..."
        Dutch  Carlos  Das  Corbin
        415.789.8468

        stay tooned. (may be postponed due to Komotion permit issues)

        Celebrate the farewell of Summer
        S.F. Intouractive, 415.395.8376   Hello Happy Line: 212.631.3618

        DJ's Susan and Polliwog, other DJ's TBA

I have installed a filter in majordomo to bounce to me any message the words
"z!ppy", "z!ppies" or "prono!a" appear in, though admittedly it doesn't catch
everything.  Again, that account has been suspended indefinitely.  So sad to
give a group a chance and see them squander it. BTW, it should be noted that
the group creating such ill will are Americans who were not involved with the
movement before the Wired article was published and certainly not at the time
the article was being researched, and who upon commencement in America of
their "tour" split off from their only source of legitimacy, Fraser Clark
(say what you will).  I gave them the benefit of the doubt and offered
assistance initially - I don't consider that a mistake, I'd do it again for
another group. 

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: laura@taz.hyperreal.com (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Thu, 1 Sep 1994 20:46:14 PST
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.1.1 5/02/90)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Zip in the Canyon?

Well, I've been reading alt.culture.zippies since it was newgrouped and
the Z!ppies rarely appear there.  Yet, here they are on sfraves spamming
away with . . . whatever it is.

Anyway, since they don't seem to read netnews, and since a lot of my 
sfraves aquaintences don't read net news either, I'm reposting two 
rather "telling" articles concerning the Grand Canyon . . . whatever it
was.

*************************************************************************

Newsgroups: alt.wired
From: wcm@netcom.com (White Cliffs Media)
Subject: World Unity Festival

Can any attendees comment on the WUF fiasco? The z!ppy group seems to be
off-line. The Phoenix news media made a big deal about how the area
would have to be quarantined because cleanup crews were afraid of
"catching AIDS from discarded hypodermic needles." Arizona will probably
never be ready for world unity, it's just a nice place to go camping.
Even the Hopis kicked out festival goers! As for myself, I went to
San Diego that weekend.

*************************************************************************

From: flyvision@aol.com (FlyVision)
Newsgroups: alt.culture.z!ppies
Subject: I went to Flagstaff "In Order To Dance"

I had 2 reasons to go there:
a.  For the last 3 years 98% of the music that I listenned to was TT&A
(TechnoTrance&Ambient),
b.  Three of my French friends who live for travelling and going to TT&A
parties were going there.

I left NYC on the 20th and had to be back on the 27th.

On the 21st we slept in this Navajo owned land 3 hours drive north of
Flagstaff.  The next morning we understood more about the "World Unity
Festival" (I still didn't get the difference between the "World Unity
Festival" and the "Rainbow Gathering"; anyway...).  It was a bunch of
hippies (do not read in a pejorative way) and others meeting to celebrate
"World Unity".  I would say that about 400 people were there on that
Tuesday.  We asked around for any info on Z!ppies or techno party and got
no positive response.  The organization was almost inexistent so we
decided to head north and see some natural beauties and look for the
Z!ppies by ourselves.

On the 25th at 8PM we got the following message on a Z!ppies' answering
machine of the West coast: "... we're on tonight ... with a small sound
system ... (plus explanations on how to get to the place)".

At 12AM we were a little more than an hour west of Flagstaff.  The place
seemed nicer than the first one.  The same kind of people were there
(Hippies, dead heads, bohemians, gitans, Krishnas...) but still no trace
of Z!ppies =(.  There was a 130bpm beat in the nearby forest though.  We
walked over and found a very precarious DJ installation with two
campground fires and a stromboscope (less cool than it sounds;)).  My
friends new the DJ from Goa (Gil ("Goa" Gil as he calls himself in SF));) 
He was DATing (spinning from DATs) some 6 month to 1 year old "Progressive
Trance" (which is Goa specialty; the finest if you ask me).  30 people
were dancing, 20 were sitting around the fires.  Some interesting people
not aggressive like the hippies (yes that's what I found about the hippies
of this World Unity Festival (Re:"Z!ppies: Please stay away!" above)) but
not Z!ppies either.

The next day (26th) some serious sound system arrived.  Some Z!ppies too
among them Fraser Clark who is suppose to the "Da Man";).  Some less than
zero rock played from 7PM to 9:30PM when Gil strated DATing again.  About
50 people were there and my friends and myself were the only four persons
(and believe me I looked all around) who were ready for a "four days rave"
as it was advertized in several zines all over the western world (Wired,
Actuel(in France), and many others mostly techno and underground zines). 
I forgot to mention that it had started raining around 6:30PM.  Gil DATed
until 4 or 5AM.  We were sleeping very close to the stage and I woke up
several times.  The music was very good (my rating:17/20) but only 10
people were still around.

I left the next morning for NYC and I haven't heard much about this
"200,000 people Megarave", as I had read before going, since.

I e-mail the guy who wrote Wired article.



From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep  2 01:31:48 1994

From: Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: I'm glad it's over
To: SuperDuperRavers <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, brian@hyperreal.com
cc: Me <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9409020132.A26412-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


and in a way, I feel I should have never participated in it.  One thing I 
have learned from  SuperDuperRavers <sfraves@hyperreal.com> is that I do 
not agree with everyone's opinion on it.  There are even people on the 
net that I feel almost throw a negative energy into our discussion 
groups, which I have a tendency to forget and just engross myself in 
their negativity.  For me, it's almost like eating french fries, and I 
just feel the need to keep responding to these people that are just not 
ready to sit back and flow with life as part of the universe (whatever 
boundaries, if any there are).  Next time, I will try even harder to 
resist the temptation to fight fire with fire ( or more newspaper ).  But 
Brian, I must thank you for taking the one step that was really needed.  
I will stand in my chair and clap for 10 seconds (well, not in my chair, 
in front of it), and I recommend anyone that wants to do the same.  Maybe 
with the synchronous energy, we can "keep the negative energy out" like 
garlic is supposed to ward off evil spirits.  Is that stuff 
superstition?  I don't know.  

compound your energy.

later--->

          YLEM - Artists Using Science and Technology                    
                                                                            
          is hosting a Forum:  "Surprise Surprise"                      
          Wednesday, September 7, 7:00 pm                                 
          at the Exploratorium McBean Theatre                            
          3601 Lyon St., San Francisco                                  

	  Lots of stuff going on at this forum!
          It's free, all are invited!  Come and meet some                 
          like-minded Artomata!  It's also a free night at           
          the Exploratorium!
                                                                            
          Presentations:                                                

	    This is an YLEM schmooze fest where members and guests 
	    will show off their creations: A look at the surprising 
	    creations of artists using science and technology, hosted 
	    by Mark "Spoonman" Petrakis
                                                                            
            Mike and Chrysanthe Moser - 
			combine poetry, computer images, rinkytink piano 
			and electric guitar.

            Jeremy Sutton -             
			describing computer portraiture

	    Michael Kan - 
			to show tapes of the Labor Day event, Burning
			Man with his invention, the True Vision video
			camera.

	    Dave Krzysik - 
			presents works of the Film/Poetry society

	    Eleanor Kent -
			presents knitted (!) fractals, tilings, moire 
			patterns and more

	    Theo Ferguson - 
			gives the latest on the SolArt Global Network,
			which is organizing SolArt Festival `95.

	    Putting in appearances on videotape are artists Lee Champagne,
			Sonya Rapoport, Stewart Dickinson, Ken Rinaldo,
			Dave Archer and Myrrh.

	    And more!  Marble paper with Myrrh, color titanium with 
		       Craig Cassin's electric gizmo.  Lobby displays 
		       of art and technology:  David Gaw of Coactive
		       Aesthetics shows his controller for interactive
		       works, Jim Thompson his LED wearbles and 
		       computer spirograph.  Jeremy Sutton does live
		       computer portraits, Dan Kottke displays his 
		       cyberlights, Linda Jacobson author of Garage
		       Virtual Reality autographs books and shows off
		       her data glove.  Sarah Frucht shows her screen
		       saver Sarah's Geometric Dreams and Greg Jalbert
		       demos his software Bliss Paint.
                                                                            

          YLEM INFO:  for sample newsletters, membership info,               
                      or any other YLEM business, write:

You know, I would much rather try to decrypt one of those pronia
messages than see a bunch of people Whining about "What's this doing in
my mailbox?" I liked the message.  I liked it a lot more than I like
the messages that reprint someone else's entire message--with headers--
and then say "you're right dude" or "right on, man!" or whatever.

It's all about expression.  If you don't like it, lift your finger (I 
know, apparently it's difficult) and press "d".

isn't this place supposed to be about change and harmony and relating
information and experience and all that?  Whining about the pronia messages
reminds me of the many reasons so many people left this list awhile ago..

mike

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9409021946.AA21497@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: unz!pped
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Mike comments:
> Man, that's amazing.  you guys kicked off the z!ppy dude because you
> were annoyed with his posts.

Actually, my understanding is that brian decided to end his *subsidization*
of them.  There is nothing stopping that person from rejoining sfraves
with their *own* account.  They were using a hyperreal account brian gave 
them for free.  Hyperreal costs $ to run, and brian gives free accounts out
with the understanding that the users will make a positive contribution to 
some aspect of the hyperreal environment.  Other than a handful of gifs in
the z*ppy WWW dir, my observations tell me that they have used the
hyperreal account as a mainly disruptive force here in the hyperreal
world.  Contract broken, contract ended.  

I do agree that the z*ppy filter is a bit heavy-handed if not downright
silly.  And truthfully, we've had people spew stuff that was far more 
negative without being thrown off the list for it.  I was actually 
starting to find them amusing in a perverted kind of way. 
 
VECTOR OUTBOUND - CHECK IT - The beat goes on...
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\Everything/\Is/\Possible/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

On Fri, 2 Sep 1994 01:31:44 -0700 (PDT, Tony V Garcia wrote:

>and in a way, I feel I should have never participated in it.  One thing I 
>have learned from  SuperDuperRavers <sfraves@hyperreal.com> is that I do 
>not agree with everyone's opinion on it.  There are even people on the 
>net that I feel almost throw a negative energy into our discussion 
>groups, which I have a tendency to forget and just engross myself in 
>their negativity.

I don't think there has been any negativity.

[ Just perhaps a need for ba.raves.obscure_poetic_replies :-) ]

What we do is to ascribe negative motivation to neutral or even positive 
messages.  When we do so, others are quite right to comment "Had a bad 
day, Ken?" in reply. 

The best way to reduce negativity is to simply assume the best possible 
motivation on the part of everyone else.

[ Which does not necessarily mean the action taken is any different - I 
agree with the action taken by Brian. ]

>  For me, it's almost like eating french fries, and I 
>just feel the need to keep responding to these people that are just not 
>ready to sit back and flow with life as part of the universe (whatever 
>boundaries, if any there are).  Next time, I will try even harder to 
>resist the temptation to fight fire with fire ( or more newspaper ).  But 
>Brian, I must thank you for taking the one step that was really needed.  
>I will stand in my chair and clap for 10 seconds (well, not in my chair, 
>in front of it), and I recommend anyone that wants to do the same.  Maybe 
>with the synchronous energy, we can "keep the negative energy out" like 
>garlic is supposed to ward off evil spirits.  Is that stuff 
>superstition?  I don't know.  
>
>compound your energy.
>
>later--->

YOUR FRIEND MIKE said:

> You know, I would much rather try to decrypt one of those pronia
> messages than see a bunch of people Whining about "What's this doing in
> my mailbox?" I liked the message.  I liked it a lot more than I like
> the messages that reprint someone else's entire message--with headers--
> and then say "you're right dude" or "right on, man!" or whatever.

I agree about one line posts in general, much less with more 
copied text than original.

BUT i think you hit the key right on the nose with
"I liked the message." 

i would agree with that had it been that
THE message. Any one of those would have done. And i might have said that.

But i see it as being analgous to going into a public area
and repeatedly yelling random comments. (No.. not the repeated
mumbling comments of people along telegraph :) So that the only
way to block them out is to cover your ears or walk away.

This is something that i think is important to keep in mind for
raving because our parties are someone elses Pronoia posts.
We have to be respectful of other people when doing stuff.

> It's all about expression.  If you don't like it, lift your finger (I 
> know, apparently it's difficult) and press "d".

A kind of extended version of the above is realizing that 
different people have different experiences.  While you may merely
have to press a "d" key (which i do as well) other may have to scroll
through their messages and cant jump to the next one. 
(as i found a coworker doing today, before i said 
'Man.. type pine or elm or SOMETHING!' :)
OR even worse the could have compu$erve or some such account
and have to pay for messages.

> isn't this place supposed to be about change and harmony and relating
> information and experience and all that?  Whining about the pronia messages
> reminds me of the many reasons so many people left this list awhile ago..

and whining about whining about whining messages are even worse...:) :)
but i guess i missed the exodus,when was that?

seriously.. i dont want to come off sounding preachy
like i have said the "just hit 'd'" line many times
and like i have posted shit that was less coherent than pinkus...
im just pointing out things that i often need to remind myself


 ,
dana

"it will be a great day when our schools get all the money they need
 and the air force has to hold a bake sale to buy a bomber"

Hulloa,

	This seems like a good time to speak up (too much mail is a common 
problem) ... I have tried procmail but it does not seem to like Solaris much. 
I know that you can use the commercial version of Eudora for filtering on the
mac ... but ... anyone know of something that will filter under solaris 
easily? ... so much work being shoved in between raveMail ... 

`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`
`,`,`randall@cadence.com`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,is`technical`support`,`,`
`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`

 
> get procmail.  (you may already be using it.)  it works great.
> 
> my .procmailrc includes, among other things:
> 
> :0:
> * ^TOsfraves
> sfraves
> 
> and magically everything is totally groovy.  this catches mail to
> sfraves-planners as well, btw, and doesn't care if 'sfraves' is in the
> to: or cc: field.
> 
> (note that if the second line read '* ^To: sfraves' anything which had
> 'sfraves' in the cc: field but not in the to: field would end up in
> your mail mailbox.  the ^TO is a euphemism for checking a whole slew
> of fields, including X-Sender: and other nuveau trendy fields like
> that.  basically it ends up working the way you think it should.)
> 
> procmail is capable of insanely complicated and wildly useful
> behavior, too.  (funny how those two things are often found together.)
> 
> yowsa,
> Bob
>

X-Sender: komotion@localhost
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 2 Sep 1994 15:38:01 -0500
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: komotion@netcom.com (Komotion International)
Subject: K'motion sickness
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, the fire marshal's come and gone twice now, and we've talked to two
lawyers, at least two journalists and a whole lotta other concerned folk
about our situation. (I can't believe I skipped Burning Man for this!)
Information seems to change more rapidly than I can type it, so in lieu of
an exhaustive report I'd just like to take this opportunity to invite
everyone down to our General Meeting on Tuesday, September 6 at 7 pm at
Komotion (2779 16th Street, San Francisco).


The following are among the topics we expect to discuss:


-Legal Status: What the fire department has to say about our activities and why.

-September Shows: The outlook for a September 24 Friends & Family party is
grim.  
 We've already cancelled four shows so far. The remaining live shows may have to
 be moved, cancelled or scaled down on a case-by-case basis.

-Smaller Shows: Our legal occupancy for regularly scheduled "parties" is 49.
 This means the bulk of our bookings will have to be of a more intimate variety,
 i.e. live recordings, acoustic nights, one-band "showcases," etc.

-The Big Shows: Looks like we will be able to get away with the occasional big
 bash, as long as we go with strictly underground promotion (i.e. no ads, few
 flyers, mostly word-of-mouth). If there's interest, we'd like to make a go of
 Friends & Family again around Halloween.

-Modifications: As it turns out, our landlord may be hiring a contractor for
 routine seismic upgrades soon. We may be able to cut a deal with the contractor
 to put in a third exit and/or a sprinkler system. More on this as it develops.

-Off-site benefits: We've already sunk a chunk of money into recent repairs and
 legal fees, not to mention lost show revenue (both current and projected). We
 will be staging a series of benefit concerts at other locations, including the
 Bottom of the Hill in S.F. and possibly 924 Gilman Street in Berkeley. If
 anyone has any leads on putting together any ravey-housey benefits at an
 alternate location, please get in touch.


Again, thanks to everyone who's offered suggestions, practical info etc. 
The value of the support we've received from the list community is
immeasurable.

Hope to see y'all on Tuesday.


--judge 





              Komotion International  2779 16th St at Folsom
          Magazine/Performance Space/Art Gallery/Recording Studio
           Tel 415-861-6423 Fax 415-431-6523 komotion@netcom.com
             Send stuff to; P.O. Box 410502,S.F.,CA 94141-0502
                              * B E C A U S E *

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

YOUR FRIEND MIKE writes:
 > It's all about expression.  If you don't like it, lift your finger (I 
 > know, apparently it's difficult) and press "d".
 > 
 > isn't this place supposed to be about change and harmony and relating
 > information and experience and all that?

Not every action of this sort is censorship. In this case it was
a repeated misuse of this forum. One has to draw the line somewhere
regarding apprpriate use. If not, why not just move all the Usenet
groups to sfraves? In my opinion, the Z!ppies crossed that line
repeatedly and ignored people's pleas to stop posting their unrelated
stuff.

Sean

There seem to be some egos and agendas flying around here rampantly
since when are simple thoughts and simple words to be so out of context 
so quickly on sfraves?  What's Going on here?
When you look at the responses, half liked them, half did not, so why did 
the half that did not like the voice gain sway?
What about those who liked the voice? They are seldom as vocal.
Also, what did PRONOIA CENTRAL do wrong? It Flamed back those who flamed 
it, and responded in kind to those who were interested.
What Faith was broken, I believe we all have a right to know.  An act 
that cuts off anyone's ability to communicate just because one doesn't 
like the UNCOMMUNICATIVE NATURE OF THE COMMUNICATION?
Sounds Like any alien from outer space would be kicked off of sfraves 
also, and by the way, didn't the zippies put on two of their own 
events in San Francisco?  One called the jupiter bash at a warehouse 
close to where SPAZ used to hold their night, didn't they host a 
SPAZ party, didn't they put on the first performance publishing 
event at the Crash Palace in San Francisco, where they had the 
computers up on stage and live internet on stage as the main 
event?
Of course the zippies are not from San Francisco, and by default their 
continued presence on sfraves would not be intimitely related to the 
sfrave scene, because they are no longer in the sfbay area.  Pronoia 
Central did not utter one foul word, It responded strongly to the foul 
words of our own community.  Since when does a few words from Pronoia Central
become noise and objectionable spewing especially considering what some 
of us ourselves are also thus guilty of.  Is it not the nature of rave to 
have perhaps enticing or vague information?   We do it continuously 
whenever we put on a rave as a sfcommunity, we put out verbal feelers also.
Given that I had put out those words as a member of this sfcommunity, 
since I'm not a zippy, would you have tolerated me?  I can't believe I am 
even asking a question like this.  Ettiquete? Netiquette? For the sake of 
a few self-proclaimed grumps, and verbal objectors, why Brian, did you 
remove all the capabilities of PRONOID individuals like ggoff and reidf 
from MANIFESTING THEIR LIFE POEM at Hyperreal.  Who was Pronoia central?
And How many of us would like to see it back?  Why did you, brian destroy 
what many including yourself were in the process of creating.  Seems as 
though you were being paranoid, conspiring behind their backs to harm 
them, and harm them publically.  You keep talking that the Zippies should 
have come forward in front of all of us before the event at VIVID 
PRONOIA, and that everythin should have been done publically.  What did 
you just do? you removed their ability to communicate and put down your 
and a few other's word that they broke faith with you.  You removed their 
ability to communicate with us and our ability to communicate with them.  
You're no different than Pincus, I'm no different than Pincus None of us 
are really any different than any of the Zippies. when I saw them they 
were hungry and determined to help.  They drove their van right though 
the police lines unnoticed to deliver food for Food Not Bombs.  They all 
gave up all their jobs and apartments left loved ones behind to go out on 
tour across the states for two months, not knowing what would happen, but 
spreading pronoia, real pronoia, actively thinkiing and figuring how to 
help others around them, why else did people keep putting them up, all 11 
of them up in their homes.  Sure they could be lousy house guests,  11 of 
anyone would be a lousy house guest scenario.  They have a right to a 
voice, and especially to the voice you gave them Brian.  Nothing short of 
premeditated physical murder on their parts would warrant removing their 
voice.  Besides what about the other Zippies, or non-zippies, forget the 
labels, they were and are some of the most creative and industrious 
individuals and simultaneously the simplest and quitest and spaciest  and 
smelliest and rudest and whatever else you want.  WWhat right did you 
have to take away their freedom of speech?  Some of Us would like to talk 
to the zippies that did not have a chance to talk to us on the net 
through Pronoia Central,  from what I have witnessed so far, each 1 of 
the 11 is as different and contradictory and interesting as I am, which 
says the same for any and all of us on any net commuinity.  Whaat about 
the link to POSITIVE VIBE GENERATORS? why did you remove that from 
Pronoia Central, and what are you intimating by filtering mail with the 
word Zippy or Pronoia, what  are you doing?  Sit back and Consider the 
nature of your censorship.  Give them back Their voice.  Be True to your 
own commitment to equal public availability and access.  No 
individual or group of individuals becomes worthless just because you 
Brian and a few others say so.  What Reidf Did by presenting the Yogi and 
The Saint was interesting.  Brian, what you did was peurile, lacked 
creativity, and belies your training, skill, and discipline as an 
information throughput facilitator.  You Brian of all should have 
remained staunchly neutral.  Guiding the events to proper public 
representation.  It is expected that you Brian will do so immediately.
Do not play with life or the living.  Do not create the dead. Manifest 
human, for that is what you are.




planet 6 
sound

On Fri, 2 Sep 1994, tazzleberry wrote:
> There seem to be some egos and agendas flying around here rampantly
> since when are simple thoughts and simple words to be so out of context 
> so quickly on sfraves?  What's Going on here?
> When you look at the responses, half liked them, half did not, so why did 
> the half that did not like the voice gain sway?
> What about those who liked the voice? They are seldom as vocal.
> Also, what did PRONOIA CENTRAL do wrong? It Flamed back those who flamed 
> it, and responded in kind to those who were interested.
> What Faith was broken, I believe we all have a right to know.  An act 
> that cuts off anyone's ability to communicate just because one doesn't 
> like the UNCOMMUNICATIVE NATURE OF THE COMMUNICATION?
> Sounds Like any alien from outer space would be kicked off of sfraves 

All valid criticisms, given what transpired on the list itself.  But 
there is more to my suspension of Pincus's account on hyperreal than that.
The account was created as a favor from me to Pincus who had complained about
not having the means by which to communicate.  I said it would be 
provided in the context of creating a meaningful Zippie archive on hyperreal
and in communicating to others on the net who expressed interest (the 
opposite of which is known as "spamming").  I also said I couldn't be 
available for Unix consulting - I pointed out "pine" and "trn" - and
that I strongly suggested that he and others working with him first
establish a presence on the most appropriate forum, alt.culture.zippies,
and then work with other members of hyperreal who had offered to help
create the WWW site.

After this, the Santa Cruz party took place, and the group calling
themselves the "Zippy Pronoia Tour to US" (including pincus) split off
from Fraser Clark. At this time I feel I would have been justified in
removing pincus's account, as I had lost a lot of confidence in this
group's ability to use hyperreal's resources.

A month later, no contact made with alt.culture.zippies, no effort
spent at creating a WWW site, and spamming of the sfraves mailing
list.  As owner of hyperreal.com I made an executive decision, a
decision I was hoping I'd never have to make, and which will affect
my eagerness at offering generosity in the future.

> also, and by the way, didn't the zippies put on two of their own 
> events in San Francisco?  One called the jupiter bash at a warehouse 
> close to where SPAZ used to hold their night, didn't they host a 
> SPAZ party, didn't they put on the first performance publishing 
> event at the Crash Palace in San Francisco, where they had the 
> computers up on stage and live internet on stage as the main 
> event?

Yes, but the discourse of late wasn't relevant to this.  To the extent
that they only attended their own parties, I consider them as much a
part of the SF rave scene as any other visiting performer or DJ.  I
have a feeling the faction of zippies led by Fraser Clark will
actually be much more integrated to the scene, so we'll see.

> Of course the zippies are not from San Francisco, and by default their 
> continued presence on sfraves would not be intimitely related to the 
> sfrave scene, because they are no longer in the sfbay area.  Pronoia 
> Central did not utter one foul word, It responded strongly to the foul 
> words of our own community. 

Saying "they started it" doesn't wash with me.

> Since when does a few words from Pronoia Central
> become noise and objectionable spewing especially considering what some 
> of us ourselves are also thus guilty of.  Is it not the nature of rave to 
> have perhaps enticing or vague information?   We do it continuously 
> whenever we put on a rave as a sfcommunity, we put out verbal feelers also.

Pincus has had a long history of sending purposefully obscure and
pseudomystical messages with no relevance to anything.  He sent 7
messages in quick succession to the list.  He has been warned by me
about this before.  We often do have people like this - yet usually
after awhile they get a clue.  Pincus didn't.  While he may think that
bandwidth and consideration for the other 386 members of sfraves
aren't important, I do.  If everyone, or even a small number, of other
members were to contribute in the same manner as Pincus had, I'd make
sfraves a moderated mailing list.  Which is essentially what I did
when I turned the filters on (which are now off - still a few messages
to forward, I will soon).

> Given that I had put out those words as a member of this sfcommunity, 
> since I'm not a zippy, would you have tolerated me?  I can't believe I am 
> even asking a question like this.  Ettiquete? Netiquette?

Netiquette is exactly what wasn't being observed in this case.  Of
course we would have tolerated you, as we tolerated Pincus for two
months.  But eventually even the worst cases learn netiquette.

> For the sake of 
> a few self-proclaimed grumps, and verbal objectors, why Brian, did you 
> remove all the capabilities of PRONOID individuals like ggoff and reidf 
> from MANIFESTING THEIR LIFE POEM at Hyperreal.  

Greg Goff and Reid Fossey still have hyperreal accounts.  There is still
a lot that can be done in the same vein as what the Zippies wanted to do.

> Who was Pronoia central?

An account shared by Pincus and Reid, now Reid has the account to himself.

> And How many of us would like to see it back?  Why did you, brian destroy 
> what many including yourself were in the process of creating.  

In a sense, I did it to save them from becoming even more of a mockery
of themselves,though that would admittedly be hard to do.  Pincus and
the faction known as "Zippy Pronoia Tour to US" are NOT the only 
Zippies, and not the only online Zippy group, either.  	I have become
disillusioned with that faction's activities of late, and decided to
stop my subsidation of their efforts.  

> Seems as 
> though you were being paranoid, conspiring behind their backs to harm 
> them, and harm them publically.  

Diverging interests.  They've managed to harm a few other people, one
elderly man in particular, in public.

> You keep talking that the Zippies should 
> have come forward in front of all of us before the event at VIVID 
> PRONOIA, and that everythin should have been done publically.  What did 
> you just do? you removed their ability to communicate and put down your 
> and a few other's word that they broke faith with you.  You removed their 
> ability to communicate with us and our ability to communicate with them.  

They lost my subsidation of their efforts.  They are welcome to get a
netcom account, communicate through you, etc.  If they start spamming
SFRaves again I'll take the same measure I'd take against any group
spamming the public lists I run.  I would *not* consider communicative
posts spamming.  I would consider pseudomystical irrelevant
blatherings spamming.  Note that: I would consider pseudomystical
*relevant* messages acceptible.  If your problem is that it's an
arbitrary decision on my part, you're damned right, it is.  I'm sure
netcom would allow pincus to start and run his own mailing list if he
so desired, though as I've said too many times alt.culture.zippies is
a totally appropriate place for it.

I have not stopped my subsidation of other more active Zippy-related
groups.

> You're no different than Pincus, I'm no different than Pincus None of us 
> are really any different than any of the Zippies. when I saw them they 
> were hungry and determined to help.  They drove their van right though 
> the police lines unnoticed to deliver food for Food Not Bombs. 

Though the above seems like a nonsequitor, I'll admit to their passion
for their endeavor.

> They all 
> gave up all their jobs and apartments left loved ones behind to go out on 
> tour across the states for two months, not knowing what would happen, but 
> spreading pronoia, real pronoia, actively thinkiing and figuring how to 
> help others around them, why else did people keep putting them up, all 11 
> of them up in their homes.  Sure they could be lousy house guests,  11 of 
> anyone would be a lousy house guest scenario.  They have a right to a 
> voice, and especially to the voice you gave them Brian.  Nothing short of 
> premeditated physical murder on their parts would warrant removing their 
> voice.  

Well, when you invest time and effort to set up a site and can grant
accounts to people who do everything except threaten you with murder,
get back to me.  I guess this is just where we have a difference of opinion.
I went *very* far to avoid having to take back my generosity.  And it
was *not* an easy decision.  

> Besides what about the other Zippies, or non-zippies, forget the 
> labels, they were and are some of the most creative and industrious 
> individuals and simultaneously the simplest and quitest and spaciest  and 
> smelliest and rudest and whatever else you want.  WWhat right did you 
> have to take away their freedom of speech?  

Netcom's only $17.50 a month - 408-554-UNIX.  There are dozens, if not
100's, of Internet public account systems in the bay area.  Also, the
group in the "Zippy Pronoia Tour to US" own the name zippy.org (which
I helped them register) and when they get their own machine or have a
site willing to be a domain alias I'll be happy to do name service for
them.

> Some of Us would like to talk 
> to the zippies that did not have a chance to talk to us on the net 
> through Pronoia Central,  from what I have witnessed so far, each 1 of 
> the 11 is as different and contradictory and interesting as I am, which 
> says the same for any and all of us on any net commuinity.  

Pincus always claimed he was only representing himself.  I have not seen
any of the other 11 on the net so I cannot speak for them either.

> Whaat about 
> the link to POSITIVE VIBE GENERATORS? why did you remove that from 
> Pronoia Central, 

Reid still has his account (in addition to his netcom one, hint hint)
and is being quite active in that regard.

> and what are you intimating by filtering mail with the 
> word Zippy or Pronoia, what  are you doing? 

It was an attempt to get a handle on the spamming and responses to it in
the short term.

> Sit back and Consider the 
> nature of your censorship.  Give them back Their voice.  Be True to your 
> own commitment to equal public availability and access.  

I have suggested totally viable alternatives.  What I instituted was
*not* censorship.  

> No 
> individual or group of individuals becomes worthless just because you 
> Brian and a few others say so.  What Reidf Did by presenting the Yogi and 
> The Saint was interesting.  Brian, what you did was peurile, lacked 
> creativity, and belies your training, skill, and discipline as an 
> information throughput facilitator.  You Brian of all should have 
> remained staunchly neutral.  Guiding the events to proper public 
> representation.  

The "throughput facilitator" to do his/her job effectively must lay
down ground rules for the communication that goes over it - I can send
email from my machine to yours at Berkeley because both our machines
talk TCP/IP for example.  I laid down some very loose ground rules,
the same rules that are a part of the sfraves list, the Internet, and
the terms of my trust in his ability to use his account wisely.  We
had a social seg fault, and core was dumped.

> It is expected that you Brian will do so immediately.
> Do not play with life or the living.  Do not create the dead. Manifest 
> human, for that is what you are.

Is this a death threat?  Good thing you don't have a hyperreal account. :)

Listen, I appreciate the passion involved here.  That is the hardest
part about my decision.  But passion without guidance turns into
friction.  I did what I had to so that friction wouldn't burn holes in
the list or to hyperreal.  

	Brian

Arrived here on Thursday from Seattle.  Walked by the 
Palladium, which was playing Erasure, and got told by a group 
of people hanging out in front that "nobody plays techno in San 
Francisco, why do you want to listen to that shit, techno is 
out here, you have to go to san jose".  I hope this is not 
true, because I am living near the financial district and I 
have no car.

Anyway, I need to know

1) Where are the underground record stores?  I like stuff that 
comes out on Tresor, FAX, and R&S.

2)  Where are the clubs that play the stuff I like?  I like 
higher BPMs than house music, but I could settle for house if 
that is truly all there is in the city here...

3)  Where can I find cheap net access?  I used to have my own 
PPP account but down here everyone wants to charge by the hour. 
 Where can I get a cheap shell acct or unlimited PPP?  I am 
less than thrilled with hooked.

Anyway, guess this is changing the topic away from the zippies, 
but I don't know one single person in San Francisco, so...

mccoy@hooked.net

oh yeah, anyone from Choate or UPENN or Seattle down here?


From sfraves-owner  Sun Sep  4 16:05:02 1994

From: laura@taz.hyperreal.com (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Sun, 4 Sep 1994 16:04:54 PST
In-Reply-To: Andrew McCoy <mccoy@hooked.net>
       "Just moved to SF, need advice" (Sep  4,  3:27pm)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.1.1 5/02/90)
To: Andrew McCoy <mccoy@hooked.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Just moved to SF, need advice
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Welcome to San Francisco.  I moved here in January from New York City and 
have experienced many frustrations.  

>"nobody plays techno in San 
>Francisco, why do you want to listen to that shit, techno is 
>out here, you have to go to san jose".  

Nobody BIG who the major party organizers/promoters book for the bigger 
clubs and parties plays techno.  Jeno, Garth, Markie Mark, Spun, and 
others in the top echelon of local just aren't into techno it seems.  

There seems to be some conception that the harder faster stuff is for the 
kiddies.  For a while SF had very strict caberet laws that effectively 
divided the party scene into under and over 21.  When techno was played, 
it was mostly at the all ages parties; meanwhile, many in the over-21 crow 
tend to avoid the all ages or so-called "kiddie" events.   People used to 
remark to me "techno is for speed freaks."  So that's a sampling of some 
of the attitude. :-( .  HOWEVER, I've seen that this is changing slowly.  
If anything SFRaves is a hotbed of technophiles (if such a thing can be 
said to exist in SF).  If you hang out here you'll find the techno.

You can find techno at some of the smaller clubs and parties, and at some 
renegade parties, too.  Look for names like Goa Gill, Ethan, HDW, 
Planet-6, Deaks, and DRC.  I spin on occasion, too.  Parties to watch out 
for include SPAZ, Test, Your Sister's House, Friends and Family, and Liquid 
Air.  (F&F and LA are on haitus right now while we sort out some space/site 
problems).

>1) Where are the underground record stores?  I like stuff that 
>comes out on Tresor, FAX, and R&S.

Well, there used to be Gaia Mantra, but I heard that they have recently 
closed up shop.  You could take the BART out to Berkeley and go to 
Rasputnin's on Telegraph.  Deaks and I have both resorted to mail order.  
If you look around, you can find a few tracks here and there, I've had 
good luck at Star Alley (look it up in the phone book since I don't know 
the address).

>2)  Where are the clubs that play the stuff I like?  I like 
>higher BPMs than house music, but I could settle for house if 
>that is truly all there is in the city here...

As far as I know the only place is SPAZ, which is held at 60th 6th Street 
on Friday nights.  There might be others, the best bet is to watch out for 
the sfraves calendar which is published to this list every Thursday.

>3)  Where can I find cheap net access? 

You can try crl.com or netcom.com .  I've not used either, but I know lots 
of people who have one or the other.  I also know a number of people that 
were on netcom, got sick of it, and switched to crl.

> I am less than thrilled with hooked.

Oh, but hooked is supposed to be the Best in the Bay Area according to Alex 
Bennett (morning DJ on Live 105).  I'm being sarcastic here.

>oh yeah, anyone from Choate or UPENN or Seattle down here?

I went to UPenn for a while back in the mid 80's.

Laura

>Arrived here on Thursday from Seattle.  Walked by the
>Palladium, which was playing Erasure, and got told by a group
>of people hanging out in front that "nobody plays techno in San
>Francisco, why do you want to listen to that shit, techno is
>out here, you have to go to san jose".  I hope this is not
>true, because I am living near the financial district and I
>have no car.

First of all, anyone who goes to the Palladium is *not* from the city.
It's a club that caters to pre-teenage suburban nerds who love to listen to
madonna and have no concept of a good party :) :)

>1) Where are the underground record stores?  I like stuff that
>comes out on Tresor, FAX, and R&S.

Any of the record stores on upper and lower Haight Street (take a walk and
window shop, it's great!), BPM on Polk Street, Gaia Mantra on 16th Street
and a few in Berkeley among others.

>2)  Where are the clubs that play the stuff I like?  I like
>higher BPMs than house music, but I could settle for house if
>that is truly all there is in the city here...

Stay here on sfraves and you will learn about all the cool spots real fast.
Derek Chung publishes a weekly SFRaves calendar on this list.  It's posted
every Thursday.  If you want it I will forward the most recent to you. Just
eMail me.  It's about 3 pages long.

>3)  Where can I find cheap net access?  I used to have my own
>PPP account but down here everyone wants to charge by the hour.
> Where can I get a cheap shell acct or unlimited PPP?  I am
>less than thrilled with hooked.

I use crl but they are not cheap...



>oh yeah, anyone from Choate or UPENN or Seattle down here?

It will not take long for you to get comfortable.  If you were part of the
underground up in Seattle you should be familiar with XLR8R magazine.  They
just established themselves in SF as of last month.  Their next issue will
be an SF issue.

Welcome!

Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>From Randall Wright <randall@cadence.com>:
>	This seems like a good time to speak up (too much mail is a common 
>problem) ... I have tried procmail but it does not seem to like Solaris much. 
>I know that you can use the commercial version of Eudora for filtering on the
>mac ... but ... anyone know of something that will filter under solaris 
>easily? ... so much work being shoved in between raveMail ... 

I use the MH mail handler myself. It's free, and there's a number of
decent browser interfaces that you can use, includling xmh, exmh (if
you're willing to put up with Tcl/Tk abomination), and GNU emacs mh-e.
MH works on Solaris 2.3, Irix, HPUX, SunOS, and many more. Try 'archie'
to find where you can get it via ftp (it's free).

Put a pipe to MH's 'slocal' in your ~/.forward file, e.g.:

"| /usr/local/lib/mh6.7/slocal"

Then put a file like the following in your ~/.maildelivery

################################################################################
#
# File:         .maildelivery
# RCS:          $Header: $
# Description:  
# Author:       Niels Mayer
# Created:      Mon Jan 30 14:03:19 1989
# Modified:     Mon Aug 29 10:58:36 1994 (Niels Mayer) mayer@netcom6
# Language:     N/A
# Package:      N/A
# Status:       Experimental (Do Not Distribute)
#
################################################################################

#
# note that unless /usr/local/lib/mh6.7/slocal has setgid mail permissions, 
# (like inc does), then when no actions succeed for a particular piece of
# mail, the mail will just disappear intead of going to the maildrop!
#
#  - .maildelivery must be writable only by its owner to be active
#
# .maildelivery Syntax: <field>  pattern action result cmd-string
#
# To automatically put unfiltered mail into your MH inbox uncomment the "default" line, 
# otherwise unfiltered mail will be left in your maildrop in the ususal way
# default - ^ A "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +inbox"

#
# winterp-request
#
To winterp-request ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-request"
Cc winterp-request ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-request"
Apparently-To winterp-request ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-request"
Resent-To winterp-request ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-request"

#
# winterp-source
#
To winterp-source ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-source"
Cc winterp-source ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-source"
Apparently-To winterp-source ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-source"
Resent-To winterp-source ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-source"

#
# winterp
#
To winterp ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-list"
Cc winterp ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-list"
Apparently-To winterp ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-list"
Resent-To winterp ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +winterp-list"

#
# XmGraph
# To: XmGraph@hpltp.hpl.hp.com
# "Thuan Pham" <pham@hpltp.hpl.hp.com>
#
To XmGraph@hpltp.hpl.hp.com ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +XmGraph"
Cc XmGraph@hpltp.hpl.hp.com ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +XmGraph"
Apparently-To XmGraph@hpltp.hpl.hp.com ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +XmGraph"
Resent-To XmGraph@hpltp.hpl.hp.com ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +XmGraph"

records, Belgium)
Markie had double copies and played the "Peaking" Duck Mix and the 
Mandarin Dream Mix back to back. The logo side (Peaking Duck Mix) is the
70's style slightly acidy one witht the male vocals.  I vaguely seem to remember
these words from my teens but can't be sure, Niels do you have sweet exorcist?
Does he say "Right On Kung Fu man"? :)

Subject: Groove Kitchen-Sunset

I want take a moment to thank Preston for putting on great Groove Kitchen at
the Troc.  It was a take me back to earlier days when the groove was phat,
and the people were happy. It felt so good in there.  Jon Howard, Markie, and
Marina Farina concocted blistering sets, which scaled acid house, progressive
house, and acid jazz. It was one of those great parties that kept getting
better all night. And thanks to all the sfravers who showed up to make it
great. That spirit just kept on flowing into the next days communal loveFest;
Sunset. What? 300 to 400 ravers, dancing around in love with the music and
nature. I'm sure other people saw that great older couple (45 or so) who
happened to walk by, got swept up in the music, and danced with everyone for
over and hour!! I loved those people....They just felt it with us.
They were ear to ear smiles. Special hugs and kisses to Tony for just kickin
it till the sun when down. It was the best good-bye to summer.    See ya
 down the  road...........robertj..........monterey

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: holiday
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Mission Rock got very high marks from some friends 
of mine.   I missed it.


Groove Kitchen at the Trocadero (dock worker?)
This space is nice for dancing - a big basic room.
The music was loud and clear.  I thought the visual effects
were good.  They had a real sense of humor.  

The ambient area upstairs had trouble isolating itself from
the downstairs.  I didn't really care.  Some of my friends
were more interested in a mellow ambient place to hang out.
This party was not for them.

This was a clubby city party like I tend to favor.
Lots of the fabulous and beautiful.  Everyone was a hipster.
The music and the people reminded me of the recent
Wicked.  This was better. 

The best I could get out of my friends from London was that
"it's exactly like clubs at home".  So there ya go.


Sunset was the absolute shit!  Gorgeous day.  Heavy turnout
with lots of experience and variety to mix it up.  I heard the
last two djs - dirty funky sick jams that sat on your head
and oozed.   This party amazes me.  

Met a few nice people from Oakland (Gabriel, Robert?) and
from Santa Cruz (Telelia?, and friend?).
Also met Mel from San Diego at a party later.
I could have that all wrong... I do my best!

Dave

A LOT OF PEOPLE HAVE BEEN CALLING AND SINDING E-MAIL ABOUT WANTING MORE INFO
ON THE SEPT. 17 RAVE IN LA.

HERE IS THE PRESS RELEASE AGAIN:

PHILIP BLAINE PRESENTS

Take a trip into the next
*** MILLENNIUM ***
The biggest event of your lifetime will be the New Year's Eve party taking
you into the next Millennium - NewYear's 1999.

Writer/Producer JAMES CAMERON (Aliens, Terminator, T-2, True Lies) is
currently producing a new movie called STRANGE DAYS starring Ralph Fiennes,
Angela Bassett, and Juliette Lewis.  The movie takes place during December 30
and 31, 1999.  One of the important scenes takes place at the huge New Year's
Eve Party outdoors in the streets of downtown Los Angeles. THUS, . . .

Be a part of the movie and experience the massive event with:
*** DEEE-LITE (only LA performance)
*** APHEX TWIN (only west coast performance)

Djs Jason Bentley, Doc Martin, Markie Mark (SF), Michael Cook, John Bishop,
Mark E. Quark, Frank C., and Orlando.  Tribal Percussion by: Shaheen

LOCATION:
At this Event/Film Shoot, we are CLOSING FOUR CITY BLOCKS in the heart of
downtown LA.  Because of the high demand, the location will be revealed on
the tickets.  So, Buy Yours Now, Don't Miss Out!

9PM TILL DAWN, SATURDAY SEPTEMBER 17, 1994

The entire area will be surrounded by Blockbuster Movie Effects, art
installations and other set design; to make it appear as LA would look on New
Year's Eve 1999:
* Featuring 360 degree Full Scale designed set with tons of futuristic
installations and effects.
* The streets and cityscape will look like the year 2000.
* Huge Jumbotron Video Screens.
* Tons of Confetti dropped at the mock midnight New Years celebration.
* Immense Laser effects, Intellibeams, Varilites, Dataflashes, etc.

INTERACTIVE CONCOURSE
* Technology Displays: CD-ROM, MultiMedia, and Internet stations
* Virtual Reality Simulators
* Smart Bars and other Arts & Crafts concessions
* Rides: Velcro Wall, Human Gyroscope, and Acro-Bungee!
* Chill out area in ambient garden

Come experience the new youth movement that is changing event production
around the world into a festival of light, sound, diversity and freedom.
 Witness the people of the world pilgrimage here to the new mecca, the
sunniest frontier of positivity, expanding consciousness and creativity.

$10  $10  $10  $10  $10  $10  $10  $10  $10  $10  $10  
To make this the highest energy event ever, the ticket price is only $10 !!!
ALL AGES.

event.

651-0630 and Record Reaction (310) 434-5753.

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep  6 15:26:08 1994

Received: from [128.32.175.232] (well-221-2.CNR.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.175.232]) by nature.Berkeley.EDU (8.6.5/8.6.5) with SMTP id PAA22615 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 6 Sep 1994 15:25:53 -0700

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: sunset buzzzzzzzzz
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i Mijos ! What a Sunday! Leaving the busted Chemique, what could we do but
huddle and dance to car stereos at 24th and illinois while we promised to
make Sunset the most incredible ever. 
Unconfortably spun, we rode the day out and then took our mats and blankets
over the bridge, and each group that arrived at the marina was met by
knowing smiles.
The sun shone, the wind blew,  dogs and kids ran around in the human
playground, and everyone shared bubbles, smiles, hugs, fruit, water,
blankets, luv.

The music grew into a grinding beat and heads bobbed and we smiled at each
other "Sheeeeet" and grass clippings got kicked up in the air. The music
synchronized perfectly to the sun's good-night, ribbit, kung-fu.....

. Even the police could tell there was nothing wrong goin' on. Lotsa 
sunset newcomers, from outatown ("are all sf parties this good?"-I wish)
and "old schoolers" that never hit the east bay before ("are all sunsets
this good?"-uh-huh). 

what a family to belong to; I'm the luckiest person on earth, because I am
surrounded by such wonderful people and love. 

Galen et al.,  excellent party.

Lotsa luv, 
Milton and the E-Bee...........

In-Reply-To: Andrew McCoy <mccoy@hooked.net>
       "Just moved to SF, need advice" (Sep  4,  3:27pm)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.1.1 5/02/90)
To: Andrew McCoy <mccoy@hooked.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Just moved to SF, need advice
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Welcome to San Francisco.  I moved here in January from New York City and 
have experienced many frustrations.  

>"nobody plays techno in San 
>Francisco, why do you want to listen to that shit, techno is 
>out here, you have to go to san jose".  

Nobody BIG who the major party organizers/promoters book for the bigger 
clubs and parties plays techno.  Jeno, Garth, Markie Mark, Spun, and 
others in the top echelon of local just aren't into techno it seems.  

There seems to be some conception that the harder faster stuff is for the 
kiddies.  For a while SF had very strict caberet laws that effectively 
divided the party scene into under and over 21.  When techno was played, 
it was mostly at the all ages parties; meanwhile, many in the over-21 crow 
tend to avoid the all ages or so-called "kiddie" events.   People used to 
remark to me "techno is for speed freaks."  So that's a sampling of some 
of the attitude. :-( .  HOWEVER, I've seen that this is changing slowly.  
If anything SFRaves is a hotbed of technophiles (if such a thing can be 
said to exist in SF).  If you hang out here you'll find the techno.

You can find techno at some of the smaller clubs and parties, and at some 
renegade parties, too.  Look for names like Goa Gill, Ethan, HDW, 
Planet-6, Deaks, and DRC.  I spin on occasion, too.  Parties to watch out 
for include SPAZ, Test, Your Sister's House, Friends and Family, and Liquid 
Air.  (F&F and LA are on haitus right now while we sort out some space/site 
problems).

>1) Where are the underground record stores?  I like stuff that 
>comes out on Tresor, FAX, and R&S.

Well, there used to be Gaia Mantra, but I heard that they have recently 
closed up shop.  You could take the BART out to Berkeley and go to 
Rasputnin's on Telegraph.  Deaks and I have both resorted to mail order.  
If you look around, you can find a few tracks here and there, I've had 
good luck at Star Alley (look it up in the phone book since I don't know 
the address).

>2)  Where are the clubs that play the stuff I like?  I like 
>higher BPMs than house music, but I could settle for house if 
>that is truly all there is in the city here...

As far as I know the only place is SPAZ, which is held at 60th 6th Street 
on Friday nights.  There might be others, the best bet is to watch out for 
the sfraves calendar which is published to this list every Thursday.

>3)  Where can I find cheap net access? 

You can try crl.com or netcom.com .  I've not used either, but I know lots 
of people who have one or the other.  I also know a number of people that 
were on netcom, got sick of it, and switched to crl.

> I am less than thrilled with hooked.

Oh, but hooked is supposed to be the Best in the Bay Area according to Alex 
Bennett (morning DJ on Live 105).  I'm being sarcastic here.

>oh yeah, anyone from Choate or UPENN or Seattle down here?

I went to UPenn for a while back in the mid 80's.

Laura

Very pleasantly surprised by the selection at Rasputins though...loads of
tweeky techno and trance and acid of all flavors. The techno, house, etc.
buyer there, brian, commented to me: "I just get one of *everything,* if it
sells, I get more" +) So the more of us that buy techno there, the better
the selection will be I imagine :)

Also, thre is an email/mail order resource known as:

!nnovative Record Source

that emails a weekly list of new and classic titles including a 4-5 line
review of each; killer trainspotter. The buyer (Todd) seems to have quite a
taste for the acid/techno/trance end of the spectrum. I've had quite good
luck with them so far. IRS can be reached at: 

poepping@miller.cs.uwm.edu

take it easy
ethan

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep  6 17:53:00 1994

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id RAA15422; Tue, 6 Sep 1994 17:53:00 -0700

Date: 6 Sep 1994 17:55:45 -0800
From: "Kevin Keiper" <Kevin_Keiper.COORD#u#CTR@quickmail.ucsf.edu>
Subject: the burning that was the ma
To: "sf raves" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
CC: "don rainwater" <gcpw@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

                                            the burning that was the man...
greetings sfravers:

i just got back from burning man and for those of you who could not attend,
wow...
you really missed a unique experience.
i travelled with spaz, and we were the only dance contingent representatives
from san francisco.
some brief details sure to be elaborated on later by others:
  
...big sound system borrowed mostly from shark bait (our midrange/tweeter
section blew out so all we had were the bass bins at first).
the conditions in the desert were such that  you could really  *feel* the bass
shake the desert floor from 50 yards...incredible.
topher spun really masterfull progressive house/ambient-ish dubby orb-like
stuff with a taste of trance thrown in for a long time on several occasions,
notably as the day was drawing to a close sunday evening before the burning. i
really enjoyed it. the mood his selections encouraged complimented perfectly
both the warm, quiet late afternoon peace developing as the sun approached the
horizon as it set, and the butterflies-in-your-stomach anticipation of the
nocturnal festivities to come.

 peter from freezer added his two cents in the early am (sunday) after a small
party sat. nite with the *morning* music set. he and don from boogie soft also
collaborated sunday night for some live ambient during the party held after the
man burned.(thanks for the short wave ted, it was really cool...)
phillip spun some black practically liquid vinyl(whew... the heat out there!!!)
on the heavier acid/trance tip sunday day which was quite good as well. candice
of sfraves provided a really nice sfraves breakfast saturday morning with
oatmeal but i actually expected more people. when i was eating, me and my
friends were the only ones there :(
mtv came out and interviewed several spaz people and a couple others... i do
not know when or even if this footage will air, but because i have no tv, some
one could post what they saw if they see it. 
i could write tons more, but im sure others will fill in the cracks...
the hot springs were really cool too.
comments?
kevin

        Just wanted to say that we had a great party in Monterey with
Deaks, James, Donut, HDW and Tim McKnew spinning phenomenal sets.  We had a
great live play over with Tim's set.  Bryce kicked us off to an energetic
start,  Ernie (Deaks) just killed the crowd, look out for this man he could
be very dangerous in the future :)  the energy levels could become
uncontrollable when this man turns the tables...Look for Donut and James in
Santa Cruz definitely up and coming.  Monterey has some great positive
energy coming alive so if you are near check it out!  Special ythanks to
brycer and swoosh(cats.ucsc.edu) for all their excellent help and everyone
else who helped make Labor Day weekend a wonderful time.  I hope everyone
had a great time all over this weekend.  Look for a post from the Cloud
Factory in a couple of days about two upcoming events.

Love, Scott

P.S. If anyone is interested in seeing our expenses please e-mail I'll be
happy to mail 'em to you.  It was a three dollar party that made a few
bucks.  We've thrown three parties for three dollars each and are breaking
even with a tiny bit extra.  YOU CAN DO IT!!  Anyonr can throw a party, it
takes a positive attitude, some organization and a little time and can be
done with only a LITTLE money!!!

The Cloud Factory

...has been moved from Komotion to a private location near 20th/Mission.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 6 Sep 1994 11:41:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Maui-Your Sister's House" <ysh@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: fog machines.

As a former lighting tech for an Atlanta club that used lots of fog 
sometimes, I just gotta stick my $0.02 in --

There are two kinds of fog "juice": water-base, and oil-base. Oil-base is 
that really disgusting stuff that makes you cough. Water-base, used 
sensibly, should not cause the problems I see on this list.

Water-base is just water and glycerin, really -- the machine vaporizes 
water with a *very* hot element, and it is blown into the desired area. 
The glycerin just helps it last longer, but not mby much. I don't see how 
glycerin, esp. in such small amounts, could be causing these problems.

I believe the main problem here is the people using it. If it's 
water-base, but bothering folks, then:

1) The room is not properly ventilated. If the space doesn't have an 
air-handler of some sort, don't fog it.

2) The person operating the fog machine is trigger-happy, and is fogging 
*way* too heavily. (It takes only a little bit of fog to get the desired 
light-enhancement).

3) Said operator is blowing the fog out too close to the ground. It 
should be blown out well above the crowd (I like to send it down from 
the ceiling, actually) so that it dissipates before much of it gets to 
the dancefloor.

As for the odor, I agree, the scented ones are an abomination! However, 
the stuff I have used smells like -- well, like water.

Sorry I couldn't post this in a more timely fashion...

Maui

On Fri, 22 Jul 1994, Alissa Feinberg wrote:

> > i was thinking some sorta group collage effort....or some computer 
> > graphics that can be manipulated by different people...i guess i would 
> > have to think about its direction and exacution a little bit more...
> > 
> > anyone interested? any ideas? susie(:
> 
> I too have a strong background in the visual arts. I've actually done 
> a lot of collaborative work with people, both for serious art 
> projects and just for fun. I've had several collaborative painting 
> parties which have all resulted in great artworks.

I would REALLY like to have an art party and make pieces (banners, an 
altar, etc.) for Your Sister's House, as we are returning to the scene. I 
also want very much to do some things, banners, maybe a new logo, for 
sfraves.

Alissa, you called our voicemail (YSH) a long time ago -- I recognized 
your name from our mailing list! I don't think I've met you though.

I have some fabric for banners, and I know where to get good-size bottles 
of nice flourescent paint at a good price --- let's see what else we can 
come up with!

> A few problems I've encountered with collaborative works: people tend 
> to get VERY protective AND VERY sensitive when it comes to creating 
> things, especially if they are not used to doing this professionally. 
> They usually have problems with it if someone comes along and adds 
> to, obliterates, or otherwise monkeys with whatever they've done. 

I'm not too worried about that -- I've seen alot of painting recently, 
and it seemed to me that people were being very cool about it. No one was 
being destructive of other folx work, and no one was getting paranoid 
about their own.

> After art 
> parties at my house the people involved are much closer. We go 
> through a lot of stuff staying up all night painting and figuring out 
> ways to work together while maintaining a sense of individual 
> aesthetic.

That sounds wonderful! Let's *do* it!

> Yes, I'm ALWAYS interested in art parties! A chill room art scene 
> would probably be somewhat different than these things that I've 
> hosted before. I could see painting getting a little messy or out of 
> hand...maybe. Collage, yes! I can see piles and piles of old 
> magazines, scissors and lots of white glue on huge pieces of butcher 
> paper. Add crayons and markers to that. I'm sure people would bring 
> things to add (jewelry and plant matter, etc.). Hang a roll of 6 ft. 
> wide paper on the wall and just roll it off onto the floor as 
> needed.. 

I really hope that I can help to make this happen -- I think it would be 
so great to do -- a really nice change-of-pace from loud dance music and 
sweaty bodies (not that I have anything against either of those :)  )

Let me know what you all think.

It just occurred to me -- what if you already *did* the party, and I just 
wasn't here? Oh, dear...

Oh well, write and tell me!

Maui :)

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is now basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself/& I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules.

 It's every Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I shifted the lunch meeting time a 
bit -  I hope to see more of you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 11:50AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

Received: from epikt.agames.com by agames.agames.com (8.6.9/3.14+gl) id WAA07251; Tue, 6 Sep 1994 22:01:14 -0700
Received: by epikt.agames.com (8.6.9/3.14+gl) id WAA05720; Tue, 6 Sep 1994 22:01:05 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: the man burned, and you weren't there, ...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


and it's a damn shame.  Stopped by the oatmeal breakfast (hi!) but didn't
see any of the usual SFO suspects.  Sorry I didn't partake but I was on
a fruit-juice fast all weekend.

Space, in sufficient quantities, is a drug, and the night stars were of
an intensity unmatched since Pete Ashdown's Knolls event (new moon, high
desert plateau).  The sungod fried our insanity to a crackly-crunchy crisp,
and the cold desert night kept us huddled around the fires.

Suddenly the theory of the four elements made a lot of sense.

As the fire burned my flesh to ash and the wind stripped the charred 
remains from my bones, all non-essentials were stripped away; worries
about work, The Law, hipness, phoning relatives, car insurance, and all
the other hundreds of niggling detail-work required of us to stay out
of the legal shredder.  Water, food, fire, and other people, and then
what?

Lots of art, almost all of which gets immolated by Sunday night.  It's
amazing what people do when the restrictions are lifted.  What keeps our
everyday life from being this interesting?  The tyranny of the majority,
as expressed in zoning laws, upkeep rules, the desire to make everything
drive-thru (or at least drive-near), ... ok, I'm rambling, but it was
beautiful.  I hope my "Free Action" coupons helped some people out.

Sure, it's pseudo-mystical shit, but we don't run on logic.  Rationality
is a tool with which the Beast fulfills its desires.  I was perfectly happy
drumming myself into a trance and daring the fire to burn me as I danced
around it semi-possessed (only caught fleeting moments of pure ego-loss).
The only downer was all the bottled-up sexual energy, which runs headlong
into the conflicting equation of SEX=DEATH stated by new diseases and old
morality, and whose conflict manifests itself in big cars, outlet malls,
and other messianic religions.  

Oh well -- I'll shut up before Brian puts a grigsby filter on sfraves >%^)
Hope to see more of you next year.

// g

12" listed w/description (160 and 166 PBM) and some tapes, available by
mail-order or at Silent Records in S.F.

	Title: "God Says No!" Records: ...a new direction in techno...
	URL:   http://iia.org/~cuddihd/gsn.html

This page also has pointer to some cool music-related sites with music samples
and more. 

One of the sites is, guess what, the SFR Archive but unfortunately it is still
pointing to techno.stanford.edu. Brian, maybe you want to send them the new 
address.
BTW, Spry Inc. has just released a fully functional demo of their AIR Mosaic for
Windows.  One of the nice features of this yet-another-version of Mosaic is the
presence of multiple Hot-Lists groupable by subject and the fact that they
come preconfigured with a bunch of cool and/or useful addresses. Again, the 
first URL in the Music Hotlist is the SFR Archive, but again, they have the
old address :(
