Hey, this is for all y'all who wanted to get a demo of the stuff that I've
done.  It's going in the mail Wednesday.  

(Sorry this is being posted up to all of SFRaves but I don't know how to make a
mass mailing list when sending something out.)

If you gave me your mailing address, you should be receiving it within the next
two weeks.

Side OnE is a seamless trance mix with the following chronological points of
interest:

 0:00    (tape starts)
 0:04    Shooting Star Wish I Had A 303
 1:53    A.D.D. Girl Can't Get Arrested
 4:04    The Letter L (with Bert & Ernie)
 7:01    Shot At Sunrise (an interlude)
 8:54    The Letter L (Mr. Potatohead Goes Back mix)
 9:24    Godzilla vs. Steve Shelley
 11:47   An Evening With The Marquis
 15:3?   (tape runs out abruptly)

On Side Dos (the ambient side) is an extended put-it-on-and-go-to-sleep remix
of Stay Awake (from Mary Poppins) with a vocal sample from the version by
Suzanne Vega.  After that ends, you get a sudden cut into one of my very first
efforts at sequencing music, a pointless little attempt at dub that somehow
ended up on THIS tape purely by accident.  It's a nice melody, it's just that
I'm into more atonal stuff now.

I apologize for the sudden cuts at the end of each side, I kept forgetting to
take the length of the tape into account.  Also, keep in mind that you're
listening to a 2nd generation hi-speed dub.

Again, if you don't get anything from me within two weeks, lemme know and I'll
send another copy out.

Oh yeah, before I forget, here's a comprehensive equipment list:

        Roland R-70 drum machine
        SoundBlaster 16
        Turtle Beach Maui soundcard
        Realistic stereo mixer
        Korg rackmount line mixer
        Digitech delay rackmount
        Dod filter
        Boss sustainer pedal
        Fisher portable stereo
        486 personal computer

Don't forget to drop yer comments!

 milk
 weed

---------------------------------------------------- paul.geronca@support.com

Greetings, SFRavers!

Well, after much soul searching, and thought to the practicalities of
the matter, I must regretfully announce that I will not be able to 
organize the September 24th Friends and Family, and have discussed 
this with Komotion.  We have arranged for another date at the space...
stay tuned for details.  As many of you know, I am currently working
with an attorney on the Oyster Bay case, which is consuming much of my
spare time.  The remainder of my time is going to meet commitments I
have already made, as well as toward repairing/stabilizing my internet
site (which suffered catastrophic failures).  Neither Ethan nor I have
the time and energy to devote to this undertaking, each for our own
personal reasons.  I hope you understand our reasons, and will continue
to support the many fine events held throughout the Bay Area during this
(hopefully) brief hiatus.  And, BTW, please support Komotion...you can
send them email at komotion@netcom.com.  Thanks for your support!
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@crl.com-----

O.K. first of all. all i have to say to you is that if you think that the 
only people who go to the palladium is navy guys and girls from the east 
bay named candi with an i you are dead wrong and as far as the music that 
is played there you haven't been there in a long time. i used to be the D.J.
there and i can't remember when the last time that madonna was played 
there and i stopped working there last halloween so it must have been a 
long time ago. as far as music that is played there the palladium gets 
sent music by the music reps about two months be for you can buy it of if 
it's an import they usually get it right when it comes out or a little 
before. hell we even got stuff that you can't buy like the "new" mixes of 
surrender yourself by the daou we had those on a white lable when the 
original came out one of six copies in existance at the time and remember 
love you more by sunscreem they had that in '91 when they made 1000 white 
lables of the original song. be sides that they had 808 state come down 
and mix it up a couple of years back and when techno hit the bay area we 
were right on top of it switching the format from modern to a more housey 
technoie type of night even now sundays have been all acid jazz hip hop 
reggae and house. i do have to admit that the place still look like it's 
caught it a time warp from the seventies and because it's in north beach 
they get alot of tourists and navy guys but they do have a great sound 
system up to the minuite lights well except for the neon but most of all 
they have a very non threating atmosphere anyone can go to the palladium 
and have a good time talk to anyone and not have to deal with their 
attitude can you say the same from any of the others like 1015,the sound 
factory,the end up,dv8,dna,townsend, i don't think so.
anyway this has been my little rant i'm just protective and a little 
touchy about people who haven't been to the palladium in years bad 
mouthing it.Peace.Talizman.

sunset was the bomb of the bomb! nothing but bodies in motion lit by 
flickering tiki torches and the sky and the ground and great music.  I 
had to be pryed away...
so many beautiful people...

painting at new moon was great.  we should have something like that 
whenever possible.  the Free Love flag has been converted...

and for the first time, cops came and I didn't hate them.  I was playing 
a song with the line "why don't you love me, like I love you?" when they 
said turn it down.  I kinda felt flattered that they noticed the music. 
heh heh...

much love,
whitsitt

From sfraves-owner  Wed Sep  7 11:07:26 1994

From: Todd_Spaulding@globalvillag.com

X-Priority: Normal
Subject: Cumulus, Sunset, New Moon

Message-Id: <94Sep7.110658pdt.149187@pmail.globalvillag.com>

Precedence: bulk

Date	9/7/94
Subject	Cumulus, Sunset, New Moon
>From	Todd Spaulding
To	sfraves@hyperreal.com

Internet mail                 Cumulus, Sunset, New Moon

My friends and I all had a WONDERFUL time at Cumulus.  I think each of us agreed
that it was a party that we actually had a really good time at for once in a
long while.  (Too many lame parties at 24th and Illinois, not counting the first
two or three at that spot -- before it was a 2-A-Week location.)  

Harmony, a couple weeks ago, was a truly beautiful and uplifting vibe for us,
but we put on that party, so it doesn't count!   ;-)

All the DJ's at Cumulus did a great job as I expected, and the music kept me
floating about an inch off the ground all night.  We stayed until after sunrise
to see everyone off, and it turned out there was no one but Bryce and the other
DJ's to help lug the sound system back up out of the monstrous and amazing sand
pit the party sat it.  I convinced my friends that WE would appreciate and need
the help from others if it were OUR party, and that we were practically
obligated to give them a hand.

So, up the giant sand incline we went with the sound system, two to a monitor.
                     That hill was our death.  

I couldn't see straight for 30 minutes after I got to the top.  Somehow we made
it back to our car, but I was satisfied that we had just saved the Cumulus crew
probably about an hour of backbreaking labour.  <Yay!>

Very, Very, VERY unfortunately, we missed Sunset and the New Moon parties, and
mucho bummed we were.  I tried to stay up after Cumulus until Sunset, but
consiousness much past 1PM just wasn't happening.  I decided to sleep until
Sunday evening, and then make my journey up to Berkeley for a New Moon party,
but I couldn't wake up Greg.  I even shook his waterbed for a few minutes, but
the waves only put him into a deeper coma.  Being totally dead myself, I gave
in.  A few hours later we found ourselves totaly awake at 4:00 AM in the
morning, and somehow hungry.  Ahh, the Raver lifestyle.  Too bad I was so tired
this week.  There will always be another week!

See you all soon!
Love and Hugs,
Todd

--------------------------------------

Kevin Keiper writes:
> i just got back from burning man and for those of you who could not attend,
> wow...
> you really missed a unique experience.

I concur.  The tone of my experience at the burning man was set when I drove
my car onto the desert and was passed at 60 miles an hour by a car shaped
like a shark (fins, teeth, a tail that moved) being chased by a fishing boat
with a nakid, crazed captain atop the recon tower.

> i travelled with spaz, and we were the only dance contingent representatives
> from san francisco.

Thank god you guys were there.  I heard stories of the rave two years ago
that was located 2 miles away from the man and was so loud that you could
hear it for miles around the desert.  This time wasn't quite so loud, but
I'm not complaining.

> some brief details sure to be elaborated on later by others:
>   
> ...big sound system borrowed mostly from shark bait (our midrange/tweeter
> section blew out so all we had were the bass bins at first).

A small tragidy, that mid range going out.  What happened to it?

> the conditions in the desert were such that  you could really  *feel* the bass
> shake the desert floor from 50 yards...incredible.

Black rock desert is an amazing place.  It's made out of gypsum dust with the
consistancy of talcum powder packed hard into the ground.  It covers hundreds
of square miles with no rocks, plants, or hills to break its flatness.  And
yes, it conducted sound really well.  It also had a very nice feel to it as
good as any dance floor I've been on.

The music was amazing.  Before I left for the burning man, I was a little
sad about missing the new moon rave, but this was every bit as good as
the goat rock or pt. reyes new moons I've been to.  Really, if you wanted
to pick the place for the ultimate rave of all time, the black rock desert
can't be beat.  There's no ranger to shut you down out there.

> mtv came out and interviewed several spaz people and a couple others... i do
> not know when or even if this footage will air, but because i have no tv, some
> one could post what they saw if they see it.

I spent a good two hours on sunday taking pictures of the MTV crew doing their
thing out there.  I believe I annoyed the hell out of them, but hey, at the
burning man there are no spectators, and even the media is a performance.
 
> i could write tons more, but im sure others will fill in the cracks...
> the hot springs were really cool too.

The greens and browns of the hot springs and vegetation were a welcome
change from the yellowish white of the desert.  Maybe you saw me out
there, I was the guy with the purple umbrella.

Ciao,

Purple Tiger

Subject: The Burning Man [schoudhu@ccmail.abbotthpd.com] (fwd)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: schoudhu@ccmail.abbotthpd.com
Subject: The Burning Man
Date: 07 Sep 94 02:50:17 GMT

     Hello all,
     
     I'll add my $0.02 to what the Burning Man experience was like... First 
     off all, to sum it up, it was the most artistic and unique experience 
     I, and most of my crew have been to. The people were of such wide age 
     and background variety, yet everyone was just *so* friendly! It was 
     great!
     
     The days were spent walking around getting to know people, and the 
     nights were strictly for partying. The Black Rock Desert truly is so 
     serenely desolate..you can close your eyes with the car travelling at 
     80mph..for what seems like hours at a time.. and not hit a thing! 
     
     Well, the days activities included many 'artsy' things.. the impromptu 
     cafe's and bars and dancing parties that sprung up in the main camp 
     were great. One group was handing out 'zines' and another was handing 
     out poetry, etc... Our group brought a portable rock-climbing gym that 
     many people seemed to enjoy!
     
     On Saturday night there was a big 'burning' of a huge towerlike 
     thing.. The closest thing to describe it wouldve been a huge snout 
     sticking up from the earth.. The party that ensued around that and the 
     'opera' show that followed was just too cool! 
     
     The raves on both nights were just great, with SPAZ doing a great 
     job..yeah, one can *really* feel the pumping bass in the desert. The 
     Sunday night tunes had a lot of greeeeaat trancey stuff.. which went 
     well with the unreal view of the stars ( I swear I never knew one 
     could see so many stars in a night! ). 
     
     And of course the Burning of the Man on Sunday night was hella cool as 
     well. There it was, a mass of people who helped raise the man, light 
     him, and then he burned!! The man came crashing down and then 
     *everyone* started dancing around him! There were so many drummers who 
     drummed continuously for 3+ hours, until the last of the flame had 
     turned to ashes! Amazing! That experience alone was mind-boggling. The 
     vibe was intense! Any of you who went definitely know what I'm talking 
     about.
     
     All, in all, it was a great event.. I know what I'm doing next Labor 
     Day weekend! It was at times almost a scene out of a Mad Max movie... 
     with the artisctic and creative energy of all these people coming 
     together for a single purpose... If I were you I wouldnt miss it next 
     time! As you can tell, I'm still kinda speechless about it all!
     
     What an experience!
     
     Regards, and rave on folks!
     
     Si Choudhury

Mijos, can anyone tell me what happened at chemistry?
Ok, ok, I don't want to hear the old "you shouldn'ta paid 20 in the first
place" stuff, I've promised myself that i don't know how many times, but
when you see everyone you love together in one place, and the lineup iiiiz
gooooooooood, you go...

so why did 20 not guarantee a long night in there? Some girl said "we
closed because baaaaad gangsters with baseball bats were gonna come in and
hurt you, we saved your ass" well, isn't that special? raise your hands
everyone who saw that....

Coulda returned our 20, since we still had the envelope and numbered card.
hmm,and when we relocated at 24th and ill, everyone uncomfortably spun,
building up unnecessary tolerance to their disco wafers, we got no news or
announcements from anyone. It just turned into a late night cruise strip of
low riders and gangstas, with little groups huddled for warmth near car
stereos. Could do that in the east bay with doobie and a six pack...

one dude sat there going, "chemistry loves us, man, the'yre our family,"
bub, mom and pop left us home alone....the real family was crashing hard,
40$ poorer and probably none the wiser...

for a consistently good summer-long vibe at a 5$ party, the family feel did
exist, busted parties did relocate, and Carlos cares, but why put a 20$
finale? Seems like baiting, and i ate... But to just leave us there, not
say anything, hell, what happened? I haven't checked their message, but
Chemistry can rise above Anthem (whata rip) and keep its name for most of
us, if they do a free one, with the same fucking line-up we paid for. Then,
maybe our money will make more people happy (those who didn't pay) and not
just a few (those who didn't play). 
Remember a wrehouse Organics, busted this spring? They relocated to the
closest thing (they bought out the Hayes) so no-one had to drive *&#@-up,
and while in line, they apologized and promised(delivered) a free park
party. Just gotta luv sincerity. Got nuthin' against makin a buck, just do
it right, and if you claim family, my chemists, stay with us till the end.

Buzzzzz,
Milton and the E-Bee

From sfraves-owner  Wed Sep  7 20:11:41 1994

Date: Tue, 06 Sep 1994 19:21:00 -0500
Organization: Purple Tiger Sophistems

Lines: 58
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Kevin Keiper writes:
> i just got back from burning man and for those of you who could not attend,
> wow...
> you really missed a unique experience.

I concur.  The tone of my experience at the burning man was set when I drove
my car onto the desert and was passed at 60 miles an hour by a car shaped
like a shark (fins, teeth, a tail that moved) being chased by a fishing boat
with a nakid, crazed captain atop the recon tower.

> i travelled with spaz, and we were the only dance contingent representatives
> from san francisco.

Thank god you guys were there.  I heard stories of the rave two years ago
that was located 2 miles away from the man and was so loud that you could
hear it for miles around the desert.  This time wasn't quite so loud, but
I'm not complaining.

> some brief details sure to be elaborated on later by others:
>   
> ...big sound system borrowed mostly from shark bait (our midrange/tweeter
> section blew out so all we had were the bass bins at first).

A small tragidy, that mid range going out.  What happened to it?

> the conditions in the desert were such that  you could really  *feel* the bass
> shake the desert floor from 50 yards...incredible.

Black rock desert is an amazing place.  It's made out of gypsum dust with the
consistancy of talcum powder packed hard into the ground.  It covers hundreds
of square miles with no rocks, plants, or hills to break its flatness.  And
yes, it conducted sound really well.  It also had a very nice feel to it as
good as any dance floor I've been on.

The music was amazing.  Before I left for the burning man, I was a little
sad about missing the new moon rave, but this was every bit as good as
the goat rock or pt. reyes new moons I've been to.  Really, if you wanted
to pick the place for the ultimate rave of all time, the black rock desert
can't be beat.  There's no ranger to shut you down out there.

> mtv came out and interviewed several spaz people and a couple others... i do
> not know when or even if this footage will air, but because i have no tv, some
> one could post what they saw if they see it.

I spent a good two hours on sunday taking pictures of the MTV crew doing their
thing out there.  I believe I annoyed the hell out of them, but hey, at the
burning man there are no spectators, and even the media is a performance.
 
> i could write tons more, but im sure others will fill in the cracks...
> the hot springs were really cool too.

The greens and browns of the hot springs and vegetation were a welcome
change from the yellowish white of the desert.  Maybe you saw me out
there, I was the guy with the purple umbrella.

Ciao,

Purple Tiger

Subject: Burning Man
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 8 Sep 1994 09:09:27 -40962758 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23alpha]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2574      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Where to start...  Amazing seems to be the only word that has left
my mouth since I got back.  I really have to ditto Grigsby's post.
The absolute freedom and loss of boundaries was mind blowing.  I 
learned so much out there.  Water, sun protection, warmth, food
and pure, egoless human relations.  No 7-11 for those last minute
"necessites".  Did you forget something?  Hope that someone else 
didn't and is willing to share.  Beautiful.  I found Burning Man
to be quite different than other similar festivals/gatherings.
Maybe it was the *extreme* friendliness of everyone.  Maybe it
was that everything was so extreme.  Nothing was simply done, yet
everything simply happened.

Yeah, there were a few party poopers, but they were also part of the
beauty.  But then there was the man in the (two hour) coffee line
that told me about his mine claim out in the mountains and how he
just stumbled on the party thinking that it was Gerlach (Go Bruno!).
He gave me stones to make jewelry with.

My words can't do justice to the experience.  Maybe my photos will.
Probably not.

I have calouses and peeling skin on my hands from the Crush Fest. 
I lost all sense of myself.  Try it sometime.  It's really not all
that bad.

The oatmeal was great.  We posted a sign on the bulletin board and
non-sfr folks showed up too.  I made some wonderful friends.  (If 
anyone out there knows Sue, Mark, and John remind them to call me
355-3770)  From Saturdays Black Rock Gazette:
	
	Oatmeal is the natural healer.  It heals the mind, it
	heals the body.  Come share in the faith with an oatmeal
	feed.  (South side of the Land of Milk and Cookies bus
	in back of the Tiki Camp.)

How this got in the paper, I don't know.  Things just kind of happened 
out there.  People trickled in between 8 and noon which was just fine
for us.  As soon as we fed one group another would come in.  

People made pretend cameras out of wood and pipe.  I loved it, 
self mockery is important.

Burning Man will be different next year.  People were already mourning
the loss.  (MTV was there?  Didn't notice.)  I'm glad it will be 
different, what's the point in doing the same thing all over again?
I hope that each year is different from the year before.  An aside 
to this...  If you fear Burning Man commercialism, do something free.
If you didn't like the people selling coffee, make coffee to give to
everyone.  Something like this only evolves into what *you* allow
it to.

Fuck it up.
-- 
Candice			pandora@hulk.sfsu.edu


    I'm nothing now, but I'm something compared to what I used to be.

perceived self-absorbed, self-promoting expressions and actions of the 
zips have created a negative impression to many people.  For whatever
reason, that is the reality.  

>Vector Outbound Information Throughput
>SubSpace Frequency
>Vector Interlink Information Totem Codex

Communication is a 2-way street.  Shouting in a language of your own 
choosing doesn't mean that you will be heard in the way you might want 
to - even if you only mean to express style instead of substance.

Many of us on this list go to parties all the time.  We are not that hard 
to meet.  There have been many ongoing open-to-the-public SFRave-related 
get togethers as well.  Special invitations have never been necessary for 
individuals who truly want to come together.

I've got nothing against religion or people's right to practice such, but 
giving that sort of free rein to *anyone* while excluding others is bullshit.

Unfortunately the mass hysteria caused by the last two weeks of kids 
shooting kids is going to cause many to give this idea serious thought.  
Hopefully it'll die before it comes to fruitition or get knocked down by 
the courts shortly after inception (bringing religion into the matter 
makes that damn easy)

Word has it that Wicked has finally bought the sound system we've all been
paying for ;), so Saturday may be the first chance to hear it.  

There are some new/old listings in the weeklies - Mission Rock is 
happening again on Fridays, The Top on Mondays, and of course Boogie
Buffet, if you hadn't already noticed.

The crowd went wild at Come/Unity last night, while last Sunday's Boogie 
Buffet was mellower, but I found some old friends there.  I haven't seen
most of you guys for a long time, maybe I'll see you at Wicked
or Sunset...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Friday, September 9th - Go Figure
        Slinkey  John Mac  Simon  Taj
        ambient room w/O.S.T & YT
        $5, 11pm-7am

They've already done this in San Jose, folks.
And, as if the curfew weren't bad enough, 
they started setting up police blockades downtown 
that serve to automatically feed drivers (people who 
are driving in downtown SJ) onto the freeway 
whether they like it or not. Of course, they only do this 
on Friday and Saturday nights- so, I guess I can live 
with that- yeah, right. Many of my friends who live downtown 
can't get home on weekend nights because of the blockades-
makes for some very creative driving. Oh, yeah, they also 
close some of the exits going into the downtown area. 
Last Saturday I was trying to get to Greg's Ballroom for 
DJ Tara's b-day fest. I ended up driving around the SJ 
Arena Complex for about half an hour just trying to 
find/make my way around the blockade on Julian.
Nevermind my friend who has been supporting herself 
for the past year& 1/2 and who also just graduated from high 
school, age 17, this past spring- she pays taxes, but she's not
allowed to go out in public? huh?

It sucks.

Take care-

Jocelyn

Mijos, this cannot bee!
Each day, scared people are willing to trade off their freedoms and
interfere in those of others for a little security? while many will fight
this, I think it should be noted that in the early seventies, before
certain pschotropic botanicals were made illegal, certain like-minded and
far-sighted people formed the Church of the Tree of Life, and claimed these
substances as part of their sacrament. Members can use these legally and
with little or no harrassment, I am told.

Damn right, time to form a new religion. Not only have some of the most
deeply spiritual people I have ever met been thru raves (but not limited
to), but maybe this would protect us from certain busts, but maybe I just
dream out loud too much. 

Could you imagine, tho, the cops being turned away, unable to legally
interfere in "our" sacrament? heh, heh...

Amen!
Milton and the E-Bee....



From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  8 16:03:55 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id QAA21711; Thu, 8 Sep 1994 16:03:55 -0700
Received: from netcom4.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA21706; Thu, 8 Sep 1994 16:03:49 -0700
Received: by netcom4.netcom.com (8.6.8.1/Netcom)
	id QAA25348; Thu, 8 Sep 1994 16:04:14 -0700
Date: Thu, 8 Sep 1994 16:04:14 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199409082304.QAA25348@netcom4.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Grand Canyon Mega rave - a report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The Grand Canyon Mega Rave
     (A report)
  (c) By Cap'n Crunch
  
  Well,  I'm finally back in civilization after being away for about 2 weeks,
and have not even thought about checking my Email.    

  My place has sorta been taken over by a bunch of Rock and Rollers,   who are
here practicing their performance for an upcoming Rock concert.    It's sorta
neat having live entertainment while working on the computer.

 A few wweks ago,  at 8 pm,  we left for Arizona,  to drive through the night
headed for the Kaibob national forest for the Unity festival/ Grand Canyon
rave/ Rainbow gathering.

 We pull into Kingman,  Az.  around 6:30 am with a slight problem with the car,
have breakfast,   and took car to a local garage,  where they diagnosed the
problem.    After about 3 hours of waiting,   I get the bad news..   $150  to
replace the distributor cap and wires.

 We were on our way,   and eventually got into the area about 10 am the 
following morning.    Our next problem was trying to interpret the directions
given on the info line.  I had called the number that previous evening,  and
transcribed the directions,   but was unable to interpret some of the words
given in the directions.   For instance,  off of route 40,  we were to look for
a sign saying "Park",   but later we interpret it as "Park" turnoff.   

  While looking for the site,  we ran into others,  and collectivly we converge
on the Rainbow gathering site,  and learn that the Unity festival was to be
located 7 miles away.    We decided to go to the Rainbow gathing first,  to
set up camp,  then head out for the Unity festival after setting up camp.

 later on,  we learn that the Unity Festival was either cancelled,  or moved
closer to the Rainbow gathering.   The Rainbows then invited the Unity folks
to their morning "Circle" to hash out and discuss some type of unity between
the Rainbows and the Untity folks.    The Rainbows are totally against amplified
sound,  but the ravers and Unity folks definately wanted amplified sound.

By Thursday night....

It was finally concensed that the ravers could do their thing,  as long as 
their music wasn't heard by the rainbow folks.    The SPAZ crew then set up
their sound system (A rather smallish one),  out about 3 meadows away from 
the Rainbow's but SOME of the rainbows were close enough to get and hear SOME
of the sound.   So,  there WERE some complaints about the music late at night
that resulted in the stoppage of the music.     Eventually,  it was agreed that
the sound be turned down,  but not so low as to not get the energy,   and 
things lasted til about 4 am or so.

The Unity folks weren't quite that fortunate,   but were able to get themselves
invited to join the rainbows for a short session to be held on Sunday,   and
also got permission to use amplified sound as long as it was far enough away
from the peace loving Rainbows.

By Friday,   the Unity folks were still trying to get permission to get their
sound systems into the park,   but the rangers kept intercepting them and
not allowing them to pass.

Frazer,  of the Zippies was a bit more clever,   and used a distraction 
technique,  and was able to cause a distraction,   while the sound system was
being moved right in front of their noses.    As far as the other Zippies,
such as Pinkus,  Angus and the others....   They have completly seperated
from Frazer,  who I am convinced,  has good intentions,  great energy,
and dispite the lack of resources,   always seems to pull through,  and
come off with an event,  dispite overwhelming odds towards failure.   In
this case,   a huge powerful sound system materialized,   and was put to good
use.

By friday,  the Zippies had set up the klller sound system,  and was able to
get things going,  dispite a long 2 hour rain storm.    After about 11 pm,
the rave started up,   and it was KILLER.    WOW!!,  this super sound system
was GREAT!.    Goa Gil then followed with some of his super Hard Acid trance
that had me bouncing around between the trees BIG TIME.   WOW!!  What super
energy,  as hundreds of folks were dancing out there in the middle of a forest
under a partial full moon.    A few Navaho dudz,  who have never been to a rave,
were totally impressed with the dancing energy,  and joined in as if they
were raving all their life.    A lot of the local Arizona dudes mostly stood
by and just gawked at the total joy and bliss that was happening in the
dance area.     Media people were sneaking around the dance area,   trying
to capture it on video.    Once the cameras left,   more and more people
came out dancing.

The Friday gig lasted until about 5 am when Goa got tired or was forced to
shut down,  due to a previous arrangement,  or whatever.   The media was  out
in full force,   mostly from foreign outlets,   but it was rumored that CNN
was to be bringing sattelite uplink equipment for the Sunday's "Drumming around
the world",  a HUGE drum circle to take place after QUIET SESSION from 6 am
till 9 am on Sunday.    I thought the camaras were rather intrusive,   with
their bright lights,   focusing on the dancers.    I spent most of my time
dancing away from the camaras.   Someone then mentioned that the Cap'n was
attending,  and CBC Canadian Broadcasting Co got an interview out of me,
and I told them that the rave scene is getting choked off by all this
nit-pickin authorities,   set agains people having a good time dancing.

The joy and energy there was nothing short of amazing,  and these media folks
transmitted these imabes round the world.   I just hope that the narration was
NOT about doing drugs,  and fucused on the energy and dancing.

 BY end of the Friday rave,  I was ready to trek out and look for a food 
kitchen for my morning caffene fix.

  I meet up with this great bunch of dudes from Texas and get invited to a pancake
breakfast and coffee.    After that,  I joined the morning circle to hear more
complaints from the rainbow's about the noise from the rave.    Things quickly
settled,   after it was made clear that the ravers would respect the 6 am
QUIET PERIOD,  as was ranbow tradition at these gatherings.

Late on Saturday,  before the rave,  we get rumors that the national guard
had set up roadblocks with sniffer dogs,  busting anyone with drugs, 
unregistered cars,  or other infractions.    Few people dared to make the trek
into town those days.    On late Monday morning,  we get word that the national
guard and the rangers had exceeded their budget and pulled MOST,  but not all
of the roadblocks.

Saturday,  was the largest rave...   More than 500 people were in attendance,
the media was there in force.    Again,   very little American media,   but I
met some grerat media dudz from australia doing a documentary.

I ran into Sara,  a journalist,  working for High times,  and spent a lot of 
time with her that evening.   Eventually, I realized that I should get over
to the rave,   and do it up again....  One can get distracted when one meets
interesting people.

The Saturday rave was really great....  Lots showed up and yet again,  Goa
Gil layed out some of the most incredable Hard Acid trance that reberberated
between the trees like I was in haaven.    By this time,   I had been awake
the 3rd night with little or no sleep,  but still managed to scarf enough
energy to dance my ass off until the very end.   At the end,  the sound
system went dead and we heard "ZZaaappp",  some sparks flying,   and someone
mentioned seeing some rainbow dude in a white robe and a beard running off, 
after he cut the generator wire,   so a few people start taking off after him.  
After catching up with him, he said that 6 am was the ending time as agreed,   
and Goa was to have played his last song in just a few minutes time.   There 
were some heated arguments between Goa,  the producers,  and this robed 
rainbow dude.

During Quiet hour,   I took the opportunity to "Meditate and trance" to try
and re-gain my energy for the World Drumming event to take place in a few
hours.

I then run into the Navahoe dude,  who tells me that they are still getting
fucked over for their land.    I listen to what he has to say,  then I
think about it,  then ask to see one of his elders on how he can pester the
Peabody Coal company that's strip mining their land.    I get the name of this
Navahoe Elder,  and make a point to try and find him about some ideas on how
they can get back at Peabody.

The Drums around the world were absolutly incredable.   The Navahoe,  and
all the other local tribes joined in... and with the teepees in the background,
the Navahoes,  Hopi's and other local tribes drummed and danced,  as well as 
Russian drummers,  Africa,  and India,   it wa a truly amazingly energetic and 
wonderful event.    CNN had set up an uplink,    and I am most curious as to 
what was seen in the news.     Has anyone gotten any tapes of CNN's brodcasts?

Late Sunday evening,  I FINALLY get some sleep since Wednesday evening (Last
time I slept).

People were then starting to leave,   and after lots of looking around,  I fail
to locate the Navaho elder dude,   but I did  talk to another Navaho,   who
told me of a demonstration they were having on this Thursday.    I make a 
note to try and check this out.

I wander around,  trying to find riders who are willing to PAY for their share
of gas,    and we now head north  towards the Grand Canyon.    And would
you believe it....   I run into Frazier of the Zippies,    We meet at the Taco
bell,   next to the IMAX theator near the Canyon.    I had just come from there,
after camping at the canyon rim,   pondering the possibility of actually hiking
down into the canyon.    I keep careful watch on the weather,  cause this is
Monsoon season,   and almost like clockwork,   everyone gets a thoural drenching
late in the afternoon.    I decided against hiking in (Was really glad I
did,  later),   and head East towards the Navaho reservation.    I make
wrong turn and meet Frazer.    After lunch,   we head back to the canyon
rim for some photo shots,   set up a boom box,   and rave for a few hours,
having our own party,  as herds of Japanese tourists parade by,   and take
it all in.....

So,  Frazer got his chance to rave at the rim.....  As we were finally
finishing the video,   a huge storm was brewing that provided us with the most
spectacular light show I've ever seen nature produce.    The storm was coming
from the West,  so I wizely head out to the car,   bid Fraser farewell,   and
headed east along the south rim of the canyon,  then North towards the 
navaho reservation,  to meet and talk with this Elder.

We get to this smallish bodunk town "Tuba City" in the middle of the reservation,
and were stunned by the poverty,  and yet see all this money around the place,
it's learly obvious that the Navaho get little of this money.

I sat all afternnon,  talking to the local kids,  and other folks about the
situation,  and learn it's really fucked BIG TIME.    For instance,  ALL
phone calls out of the reservation get socked with huge sur charges,   as
well as operator rates..   Navahoe phone co restricts the tone pads on ALL
payphones,  and filters it,  preventing ALL access from long distance
companies.   Sheesh!!  I wonder who gets all this extra money.   I know
who DON'T get any of it.   For instance,   most phones are rigged to only
allow incoming collect calls,  so huge surcharges can easily be levied
against all Navahoe folks who wisch to communicate OUT of the reservation.
This discourages them from "reaching out" for help.    They are in dire need
for a single Xerox machine,   as they get charged huge amounts for using
the one they currently have access to.

They have their OWN telephone company,  undoubtedly controlled by those forces
against them.    When having trouble calling INTO the reservation when I got
back,    I was usucessful at getting through.    I phone my friend who works
for major long distance switching equipment to investigate this for me.   So,
Ill try and find out....

  a) Why all incoming calls are blocked (Except collect calls)
  b) Why I cannot even reach the phone company's business office to 
     find out why I cannot reach one of their customers.

I get up to this trading post,   and see a hot dog stand,  and ask this white
dude if this is Navahoe run,  and he says NO,  so I walk away.    I did talk
to this Navahoe dude at the trading post and learn that most items are NOT
made by Navaho,   but they DO get the money from the sales.   I picked up
this great pullover wool sweater with great artwork on it.

We finally make our way up to where we were to meet this elder,   and I actually
have to drive on Peabody Coal property to reach his home,  and scope out this 
coal mining complex while driving through.    

It was horrible.   These huge giant machines,  digging huge gouges out of the
cliff,  with this long conveyer belt.    You get up to within 500 feet of
this "thing" and you can barely hear people next to you.    There were some
modest homes nearby,  occupied by Navaho,  and now I understand why they
are demonstrating.    The noise alone was quite a bit much to take.

After two unsucessful attempts to locate this dude,   I head back down
to the store and meet a few folks.    They informed me that I would be
arrested if I go up there to contact this Elder,  so I wizely depart,
making sure I get names and numbers to a few other Navahoe folks before
I leave.    I later discovered that it was impossible to get calls
INTO these numbers,  thusly confirming the fact that even incoming calls
are not allowed to certain Navaho individuals.

We head north,  then West,  and cut into Utah as we head West.    We take
a rather sutherly route West,  heading towards Las Vegas.    In early evening,
we head north on I-95,  near the nuke testing range,  wearing hankerchiefs
over our noses,   dousing ourselves with water to cool off.  WOW!!  it
was HOT.  Our destination....  BURNING MAN...  BLACK ROCK DESERT and a town 
called Gerlach.

products, but of course.

happy, sweaty people, all ages, NO JUDGEMENT, no violence, loadsa smiles,
hugs,  and everyone dances their own thing. Don't let the beer fool you,
its NOT an alcahol party. Its a vibe party, grrrrrlllll.............
Check it out on your way to whatever on saturday afternoon, you might get
into it, and  see that we don't do anything new at raves, we just do it
with different music! The love has always been around. 

Milton and the E-Bee....

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Cc: idm@hyperreal.com
Subject: Snivilisation first impression
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello,

My first impression from listening to the new Orbital CD once:

"Buy    this     album    NOW!"   :-)

And I'm no big Orbital worshipper/trainspotter - some of their stuff 
makes me yawn when I listen to it at home instead of the dance floor (even 
from the universally acclaimed second album).

But the new one is very inventive - no rust at chez Hartnoll.  While there 
is still a definable Orbital sound, Snivilisation is quite different from 
their previous work.

If it sounds like I'm avoiding specifics, it's because it's not similar to 
much else (part of what's good about it!).  Some of the tracks are perhaps 
like, say, Moby remixed by the Orb (or is it The Orb remixed by Moby?). :-)

New sound colors, different rhythms.  A few vocals...  Odd cover art!

provisionally 9/10.

-

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep  9 09:13:37 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id JAA02800; Fri, 9 Sep 1994 09:13:37 -0700
Received: from get.hooked.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA02791; Fri, 9 Sep 1994 09:13:32 -0700
Received: (fritz@localhost) by get.hooked.net (8.6.9/8.6.5) id JAA15152; Fri, 9 Sep 1994 09:13:31 -0700
Date: Fri, 9 Sep 1994 09:13:31 -0700
From: Cynthia Lopez <fritz@hooked.net>
Message-Id: <199409091613.JAA15152@get.hooked.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: BBS Costing Too Much? 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is a courtesy message for anyone who is using AOL or any 
other BBS which is costing them a fortune and would like to 
stay on SFR without paying dearly.   (I'm not intentionally 
promoting my BBS, just trying to help fellow SFR'ers afford to 
stay on the list-I found out the hard way.)

We (Greg & Cindy) s*bscribed to SFR while on AOL and due to the 
amount of posts that come thru SFR we were paying over $60 a 
month for this BBS.  What BS!  So while listening to Alex 
Bennett we heard about Hooked.  Cost went from too much to only 
$25/month unlimited or $15/month limited service.  Runs under 
Windows.  The cool thing about Hooked is you can call up, get 
your messages, then *disconnect* to read your mail.  Your mail 
posts directly to your PC, doesn't stay on the BBS, and you can 
read it whenever you want once you've connected/disconnected.   
(With AOL you have to stay online to read your messages - what 
a scam!)

To get hooked e-mail:   staff@hooked.net

Oh yeah, if you do get "hooked" please mention that 
fritz@hooked.net sent you.

Peace & positivity,

g-n-c
House Archives

Ann sent this to me about three days before the new moon party:

> I had another dream about the party:  this time, we were having it at
> your house & it looked really cool & neat.  Then Ovid started doing his
> rap...and...he had this weird squeaky voice & you couldn't understand a
> word he said!  And THEN, the sound system went out.  And we had forgotten
> to get a backup system.  So everybody just stood around for a while & then
> some guy from Kommotion said:  "No problem!  You guys can come over to 
> Kommotion after hours (4:30?) and start up there!" 
> 
> So, then we went to Kommotion, and I realized...oh no!...I forgot to call
> voicmail and change the message!  
> 
> When I woke up I realized:  woooo, better pay that voicemail bill!  
> 
> :-) this is getting a little ridiculous... :-)

That night, i had a dream too: somehow everyone got the wrong date and 
showed up for the party Saturday night instead of Sunday.  Then noone
would leave!  i kept trying to tell people to come back the next day, but 
nobody believed me.

Anyway, dreaming these problems ensured they wouldn't happen.  M & Ovid's 
quantum visualization was great, we didn't move to Kommotion, and 
everyone (and for a while there it did feel like _everyone_) showed up on 
the right night to manifest a great party.

					more on new moon reality later,
					gregg

On Fri, 9 Sep 1994, Cynthia Lopez wrote:

> This is a courtesy message for anyone who is using AOL or any 
> other BBS which is costing them a fortune and would like to 
> stay on SFR without paying dearly.   (I'm not intentionally 
> promoting my BBS, just trying to help fellow SFR'ers afford to 
> stay on the list-I found out the hard way.)
> 
> We (Greg & Cindy) s*bscribed to SFR while on AOL and due to the 
> amount of posts that come thru SFR we were paying over $60 a 
> month for this BBS.  What BS!  So while listening to Alex 
> Bennett we heard about Hooked.  Cost went from too much to only 
> $25/month unlimited or $15/month limited service.  Runs under 
> Windows.  The cool thing about Hooked is you can call up, get 
> your messages, then *disconnect* to read your mail.  Your mail 
> posts directly to your PC, doesn't stay on the BBS, and you can 
> read it whenever you want once you've connected/disconnected.   
> (With AOL you have to stay online to read your messages - what 
> a scam!)
> 
> To get hooked e-mail:   staff@hooked.net
> 
> Oh yeah, if you do get "hooked" please mention that 
> fritz@hooked.net sent you.
> 
> Peace & positivity,
> 
> g-n-c
> House Archives
> 
> 

To add my $.02:           For cheap 'n' nasty 
internet access, I use CRL.  $17.00 per month, unlimited access, no more 
fees for anything (except storage, $2/month per meg above 5meg.  I have 
never come close to having 5meg left on the system).  The support is 
excellent, and I have failed to get through on the first dial on average 
about one a month.

For even cheaper access just to internet mail, you cannot beat SFNET.  
You don't even need a computer.... they have coin operated terminals in 
cafes around SF.  No registration charge, stick in your quarter, and 
enter a handle and password.  You will remain a registered user.  A 
quarter buys 5 mins time.... it is mostly used for the chat tables - but 
has internet mail uploads and downloads about every hour.  Most nifty for 
checking the ravelist when away from home.  The other advantage is, of 
course, that your *true* name and address are known by nobody.  Ideal for 
the more paranoid individual who wishes to discuss the less legal aspects 
of the scene! :)

For more info on SFNET, it can be dialled from home on (415) 824 8747, 
and there are local numbers that cover the bay area.  CRL can be 
contacted at subscriptions@crl.com

Keep the Faith,

Fergal.

(Re: the question mark moon last night)

In case anyone's interested, the two bright objects near the moon
right now are Jupiter and Venus.  Venus is the one that made the
"question mark" dot with the crescent moon.  Vector off yer butt to the
window right now and (here in SF @ 8 PM, anyway) you'll get a good view of
all three.  Venus has cruised way off to the right of the moon and
Jupiter is above and to the right closer in to the moon.

-H-

(BTW: while on the topic of astronomy, anyone who is making a flyer
for a party in the near future should check out the Hubble images of
the Eta Carinae nova remnant... it's on the space telescope web site,
http://marvel.stsci.edu.  They look like they were taken right from
Industrial Light and Magic :-)


-- 
:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::
Howard Berkey                                             howard@netcom.com   
not an astronomer, but I play one on SFRaves :-)

> 
>

saying "yeah, man, i come to sunset every sunday!"  really made me feel 
good...deepfog

Hanging The Monitor - A few questions for the DJs out there -

 I was wondering what the preferred placement of monitor speakers are
for DJs ?

 If there was only one speaker ( left and right channels blended together ),
where would you want it placed? behind you? next to you? in front of you,
above the mixer? in front , behind the mixer? Or - someplace else?

 What about a stereo pair of monitor speakers?


    Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner  Sun Sep 11 00:48:49 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id AAA08069; Sun, 11 Sep 1994 00:48:49 -0700
Received: from well.sf.ca.us by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id AAA08064; Sun, 11 Sep 1994 00:48:45 -0700
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.sf.ca.us (8.6.9/8.6.9) id AAA09961 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sun, 11 Sep 1994 00:49:18 -0700
Date: Sun, 11 Sep 1994 00:49:18 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199409110749.AAA09961@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: *Last* weekend's report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I flew back to Portland on Tuesday morning with 3 hours of sleep, and
it's been 18 hour days since then, so this is a little stale, but I
though I should throw in some comments about last weekend.

Probably it was the best overall weekend I've had musically in half
a year.  I came into SF on Friday but couldn't go out due to work
commitments.  Saturday, I worked late and then went over to Ameba around
1 am for the Chemistry map point.  Things were hopping, lots of good
energy which is really great to see on Haight St. after dark.  Didn't
leave until late since I was trying (somewhat unsuccessfully) to untangle
a hardware conflict in the Ameba computer, so when I arrived at the 2nd St.
warehouse right at 3, most people were gone and I heard from the few who
remained about the scuffles and the bust.  So I was out $20 and the price
of a can of food.  As it turned out - surprise, surprise - this was
indicative of the old story, that the higher the price for the party,
the lower the probability of it working out.  It broke my several-month
streak of no busts, too . . . 

So I went over to the Troc (long time, no see), and I must say that Groove
Kitchen was a very pleasant affair.  It doesn't take long to see from the
energy of a party what the attitude of the promoters is, and Preston
delivers a positive time over and over again.  I experienced much less of
the scrimmaging on the floor that I've gotten used to in the last year,
and while the crowd wasn't overly friendly I'd give them credit for
attentiveness to the music and each other.  I missed out on John Howard
and Markie, but Mark Farina was in full swing on three tables.  I'm not
a big fan of Mark's selections generally - don't get me wrong, he's
a technically superb DJ - but I enjoyed the mix a bit more than usual
this time.  

Afterwards, Mark and Tracy Ameba and I went over to 24th and Chillinois
to check out the remains of the Chemistry lab explosion :-)  But all we
found were a bunch of people hanging around, with a couple of car sound
systems playing aggrotechno.  A couple of people told us they'd been
waiting around for up to four hours for something to get together, I guess
it never did.  So we went up to the top of Potrero Hill to watch the new
moon and the sun rise.

Sunday I went over to M and P-ter's for a little Visual Basic lesson, 
helped them load M's CD mixer gear in the car and then BARTed and ACTranned
over to the Berkeley Marina (their car being jammed with audio stuff).
Nice sunny and somewhat breezy weather.  I hadn't been to Sunset before
and the few Marina events I've been to have all been on the Bay side, so
it was a little surprising to see where the setup was behind the first
rise, but it really is a great spot during the day when it's breezy.
Had an excellent time talking with folks I haven't seen much of, and Tony
and the other DJs put in solid sets.  It was really cool to stand up on
the ridge at sunset with everyone and watch the sun slip behind Mt. Tam
while the beats chugged on and we all cheered and rushed down the hill!

We left early and missed another of Markie's renowned sets to help Gregg
set up for the New Moon party at his house in El Cerrito.  The basement
was set up as the ambient room, and the upstairs was the performance and
dance space.  I spun a few tracks while we were setting up in the basement,
but as it turned out I spent most of the evening upstairs.  

It really was a great party, although I know Gregg was sweating bullets
for a while as it got quite crowded after midnight, but I think even
despite the visit from the local gendarmes things worked out very well.
I thought Scottie and Tracy both did excellently on the turntables, and
I can see now why Tracy got such great reviews from her Sunset gig.
You GO, girl!

But the highlight of the evening for me really happened early on, as 
M and Ovid finally were able to do their ambient/spoken word performance
in a space that really did it justice.  The acoustics of Gregg's big room
were amazingly right for this effort.  M warmed up for half an hour or
so -- it's really fun to watch someone practically get en-tranced as they
mix, you can do that with ambient!  She built up a *wicked* overlaying
of environmental sounds (crickets!, her trademark of course :) and textures,
and then Ovid began his quantum-physics-philosophy rap (with a special
section on the Kabbalah this time).  And Sean set up an audio-modulated
laser that was just the right amount of visual attraction/distraction for
the musical/spoken word performance.  It was amazing to see people step
into the room while this was going on and simply not understand it for
a moment or two, then sort of fall into the swirl.  I really think that
this ought to be done again, perhaps in a planetarium or other auditorium
space set up for this kind of performance, or even better outside.  
It does require a minimum of distracting noises to work, but it's worth it!

I was very pleased to meet some of the East Bay crew for the first time,
including Gregg and Scottie and the other MESS folks and so on.  I felt
like this was an overdue connection and may help expand the sfraves net
a little wider and stronger as a result . . .

Monday evening I went over to the Club Deco on Larkin in the City and had
a really good time (after stopping first at Blues on Lombard to see my
friend Mitch playing with Johnny Nitro and the Doorslammers :).  Dub Tribe
had just begun playing when I arrived, and they did an energetic set to
a small crowd in the room behind the bar, followed by a nice close-up set
from Ernie Munson.  I also saw Randy and Buck (who's moving to the UK
"for good", or so he says).  Turns out I missed a good event here in
Portland Saturday night, both Buck and Dub Tribe had a real good time
up here, which I was glad to hear since Dub Tribe had been poorly
treated by some of the locals when they were here last year.

Anyway, all in all it was a great weekend, and I'm glad the scene is
holding up well!

phred

We were the map point for a party again this weekend, and thats always sa 
bit touchy because map points are always for young crowds who are used to 
getting burned by promoters and stopped by police. I do it for two 
reasons: for people to see that we are a bit more than a retail 
establishment by actively participating in our scene, and also to show 
new people that we ARE a retail establishment. Some times we do it for 
free , some times we accept money, last week Dutch gave us $50. Plus I 
get to spin while people get directions....for better or worse.

I saw an article laura wrote for Iron Feather journal about DJing, it was 
cool!

Wickeds new sound system works. King street was more king street than ever,
hot and sweaty, good crowd, no escape, Garth is really ON since he 
returned from a 3 week trip! NOW WHEN'S the FREE PARTY? 

The tables are open.....salutations, allen@ameba

From: resonate@netcom.com (resonate)
Message-Id: <199409112018.NAA22987@netcom2.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: repost: amazing party
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

	Last night I witnessed and participated in one of the greatest
	parties I have ever been to. Caliban and I mailed you all about it	
	and lots of SFRavers and internet dwellers were there.

	The place was Terrences house. Its a large space with seemingly
	endless rooms, a massive dance area with hardwood floor which
	opens into the outside massive backyard. At the end of the backyard
	is a large room with one wall missing so its open to the air.

	The place was decorated to the hilt- the entry room was the "black
	room" with black beanbags and black plastic walls and tv monitors,
	it continued into a dark hallway which opened into the large 	
	dance area. There were two sitting rooms off of the dance area
	and the dance area opened into a backyard which was aglow with
	the huge FreeFall black light banners and a fountain. There was a
	FREE bar and awesome FREE food from Ole. Past the food and drinks
	was the ambient area where Caliban spun the greatest ambient set
	in history- his signature sound incorporates classic electronic 
	music, spoken word, a scanner, custom made Weird Blinking Lights
	tapes (he records at the WBL studios and our live sets- he also
	is 1/3 of WBL), and infinite myriads of music and sounds. Some
	of his spoken word were Isaac Asimov, Eldridge Cleaver, Marashi
	Yogi etc... Weird Blinking Lights appeared in instrumental form
	in the middle of his set with a set of live instruments and then
	he spun out of it deeper into Calibanland. The ambient room was
	spacious with couches, lights and a great sound system- all open to
	the warm night air.

	On the dance floor were many djs- but the ones I knew were DRC and
	Cairo. All of the DJS were PUMPIN all night with the finest trance,
	acid, and techno. Not a single HOUSE beat was heard all night long
	(we could pay $20.00 for Wicked if we want house and YES I will
	freely flame that and get flamed for it). The sound was LOUD and
	high energy trance all night long I left about 5:00am or so
	and the entire place was still packed.

	People I hadn't seen in *years* were there and geeks from all over
	were there. It went all night long and I'm sure is still going even
	as I'm writing this. Everyone had a smile on their face.

	It was truly one of the greatest parties I have ever seen and
	big applause to Terrence, Cairo, Ole, Buttercup and the rest of their
	crew for the amazing party. Weird Blinking Lights had a blast
	generating sound. Terrence and his crew are really into music and
	took a lot of time and care to make sure that all the sound was
	plentiful and great sounding.

	Our scene is very much alive.

Hi.  Well there's still a pile of Interstellar CD left and honestly, I am
really quite surprised that the response by netters has been so, well, lame.
 I've always thought of us as the more hardcore ravers set, but out of
thousands of us, less than ten people have ordered the cd (a THOUSAND) were
pressed.

The CD again, was pressed to benefit all those who shoveled out major cash to
do the Interstellar Outback party, and even though it had major problems,
there are still many bills to be paid.

For just $11 bucks, which includes postage, you can hear some of the people
that where there DJing or playing live (as well as some that couldn't make
it:)
Many strong names are on it as well as new names that you'll be hearing more
of (this being a first release for some).  Also, these songs are only
available on this CD!

If you can find it worth $11 with shipping to check them out, all the great
bands and DJs appearing on it that didn't get to play for you would really
appreciate it.  They are shipping now and I promise they will provide you
with listening pleasure for a long time.

Also, anyone who has ordered the CD, post a review or reply to me personally
and tell me what you think!  Your input is appreciated as it will help on the
next one (which your support now will be remembered).


                                                        INTERSTELLAR OUTBACK
                                                           THE CD COMPILATION

A limited edition of 1,000 Compact Discs have been pressed TO be sold with
all profits going to pay those nasty bills that are accumulating to produce
the Interstellar Outback party.
The CDs (73 minutes) will be sold for a limited time on the net for $10 plus
$1 shipping and
for $8 at the party (so it would actually save you money to go and have a
great time!!!).
Hows that for advertising skill:)

The CD includes a 4 color insert of the flyer and a WIDE variety of music
from those artist
(both DJs and Bands) that will be attending the party.  All tracks were
recorded digitally and they're Phat!  There is a great representation of the
RAVE scene here with everything from:
HardCore, Jungle, Trance, House, Acid, and Ambient.  Do yourself a favor and
those who have
worked to hard to produce all aspects of Interstellar Outback the party and
donated their time,
money and music for the CD.  Check it out.

Thanks,
EllisD

From: Willis Wong <walrus@quack.kfu.com>
Subject: Wicked
To: sfraves list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9409112331.A3528-0100000@quack.kfu.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I didn't get to Wicked until 3:30 am or so but I got to see the altar of 
water bottles piled up outside which people couldn't bring in.

I could tell from when the dude was frisking me outside that it was
packed solid and goin' off because my glasses were already steamed and I
could see nothing and I wasn't even in the door yet. Once inside I
couldn't get over the steam factor... just standing there made me sweat.  
Walking around bumping into people drenched with sweat is very bizarre, 
if there's any skin contact from arms or whatever there's this slipping 
effect.  Nuts.

The house was a very deep, consistent, danceable beat, but I didn't hear as 
much cheering as usual for Wicked parties.  The guy with the fruit hat made 
for a great energy boost for me while I tried my hardest to stay up on 
the "dancing turf" as denoted by the painted lines.  It's just such a 
tight squeeze!  So far I'd say I like wicked's at Townsend more because 
of the room and slightly better air circulation... And it's got that 
close encounters disco light right in the middle too.

-w

 



From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 12 09:40:44 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id JAA29664; Mon, 12 Sep 1994 09:40:44 -0700
Received: from nexsys.nexsys.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA29658; Mon, 12 Sep 1994 09:40:40 -0700
Received: from localhost by nexsys.nexsys.net (8.6.5/SM-8.6.4)
	id JAA25769; Mon, 12 Sep 1994 09:38:19 -0700
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 1994 09:38:19 -0700
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199409121638.JAA25769@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: WICKED's Purple People Pusher
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Well last Saturday Wicked finally unveiled the long awaited sound system
that we have all been paying and waiting for.  Indeed the sound quality 
is quite formidable.  I was there during setup in the early afternoon and
was concerned because I could here every pop and crackle on the records
being played, (this is what happens when you get good response over 11k HZ.)
Still It seems to me that the system that they have (6 huge bass cabinets,
6 tops) is best suited for outdoor use, this comming full moon should prove
to be quite amazing.  Still when the club got full around 2, it was clearly 
the best sound that I have heard come out of a PA in all my days.

Although the room did not do it justice.  They set up their bass bins
in fornt of and two each side of the DJ (the DJ was is their usual King Street
location) with two mid cabinets on top of each Bass stack, and then a mid
at each end of the room in the back.  I think if they had 2 more bass bins,
and two more mid cabs and deployed them 4 for 4 at the points of the room,
it would have been absolutely unreal, but alas the sound in the 1 st half of
the club (closest to the DJ was still absolutely amazing, while in the back,
with King Street packed the way it normally gets, all the bass energy was 
absorbed by the bodies on the dance floor.

I got to hear all of the sets of all of the DJ and while they were good
and consistant for a Wicked, they didn't "blow me away" still I've never seen
Jeno so animated in all my days, he was clearly getting off on the effect
that this sound system was having on the crowd and almost looked like Carlos
in the way he was going at the tables :).  Garth was the hero of the evening
and played a very good "crowd pleaser" set. Complete with new stuff 
"just off the boat from London".  All in all, the FMR on the 19th should be
interesting.



					G

Message-Id: <9409121859.AA16347@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: weekend rpt
To: sfraves@taz.hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 12 Sep 94 11:59:05 PDT
Cc: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I got to Wicked at around 3 and managed to catch the last chunk of Jeno
and the first half of Garth before succumbing to the heat, humidity and
boomy acoustics that make King St. one of my least favorite venues.
If you like incessant no-escape pounding in a crowded zero-comfort sweatbox,
then this was certainly the place to be.  The sound system was big and loud;
I'm looking forward to the upcoming FMR for a sonically religious exper-
iance.  The people there  all seemed to be having fun, but after a couple 
of hours of paying homage I had had enough and and decided to check out
Terance's party on 14th st.  

I tend to get claustrophobic at house parties, but figured that this
wouldn't be any worse than King St.  I was delighted to find an incredibly
comfortable space: beanbagged chill space and a large dance room that 
opened into an even larger outdoor patio.  It was like the End-up minus
bar and beautifuly decorated as well; huge colorfully painted sheets,
video monitors, etc.  Also plenty of free food & drink.  The sound
was crisp & clean with music more of the techno/trance variety.  The vibe
was great with a nice mix of colorful folks.  I wished I had started my
evening here.  By 6:30 it was thinning out and the DJ's mixing had become
quite horrid, perhaps due to technical problems.

Sunset was absolutely wonderful.  The crowd was even bigger than last
week, 3-4 hundred strong.  I thought the vibe was better too.  This is one
happy party.  Solar, Galen, Spun & La Paix had fine sets.  I delivered
12 pages of sunset posts to Galen - I'm sure they'll make him smile.  The
blinking lights, strobe and black light display added a nice touch to the
evening.  There seemed to be a little bit more garbage strewn about this
time, so next week, we're gonna try to remember to bring some garbage bags.

There were a lot of sfravers in attendance - I was a little too tired to
be real sociable but we got to meet David Alves (hi david :) - it's
always fun to meet virtual people in the flesh.

My understanding is that there will be 4 more, to Oct 9th.  Also on the
friday the 23rd, the Autumn Equinox, look out for "Sunrise", an evening
party currently planned to be free, outdoor and near the city.  
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\Everything/\Is/\Possible/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 12 14:03:38 1994

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199409122103.OAA17823@netcom9.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: weekend report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

    WeakEnd Rave report
    ===================
    By Cap'n Crunch
    

Ahhh!  My first weekend back in Bay Area after the last two weeks trekking
around the Western USA.     I see that WICKED was at the King St Garage.
Bummer!!   Won't be going to WIDKED *this* time.   The last time I was
at King St venue,   I had to have my lungs pumped to remove all the horrible
stale smoke residue from my lungs.    I'm STILL trying to pay the $750 medial
bill.

Instead,  this relly cool dude Terrance decided on a whelm to throw a very
good party.    It was FREE,  with free food,  VERY GOOD MUSIC and dancing
with a very loud and clean sounding sound system,   as long as one of the
speaker banks was functioning.    I walk in,  and was greeted with a small
room and chill area,  couches and pillows everywhere.

I walk down this long hallway,  towards the music and was in this fairly
small,  and very cool (in temperature) dance area,  with clean,  powerful
sounds,  coming from two speaker banks on each corner of the room.

It didn't take me long to start dancing.   So I wasted no time,   and
just dug into the great energy of the vibe.   There were nothing but smilea
and luv,  all around the place.

It took me a while to realize it,  but the back wall was missing,   which
goes to an outside chill and schmooze area.    There were tables,  chairs
(not many),   and at the far end,  a free bar,  serving all kinds of drinks.

Out back (really towards the front),  a side area hosted another sound
system,  playing ambient.   There were sofas,  pillows,  and other soft
things to lay down on.

Near the dance area,  there was what I would call the sex room,   with
a TV monitor,   showing all the things you can do woth your "private parts".
The floor was covered with matresses,   and one can only guess at what
they were used for.

A smaller room had a comfortable futon,  and another mat,  where people
were laying down,  resting from dacing.

It's hard to tell how many people were there,   but I would guess at somewhere
between 150-200 people.    A larger proportion of the folks were gay when
compared with other small private parties,  but all were very interesting
to talk to.

The music (provided by local talant),  was new and refreshing,  and although
"beat matching" wasn't perfect ALL the time,    it still kept me on the dance
floor most of the time.

Around 6 am,  Pollywog spun some rather eklectic stuff,  but opened with a
horrendous hard acid trance that caued me to leave this planet.   She took
me back to earth (somehwhat faster than I expected,    but it was "different".

Towards the end,  the music became less dancable,  but I DID meet Frazer and
Frank and the Megatripolus crowd.    Just a reminder,   Megatripolus starts
on 1st Oct.

-------

After the party,   I head over to Boogie Buffet,  and was not that impressed
with the lack of patrons.    The pillows were most welcome,  and I tranced
out and did metitation to some nice mellow ambient music preceeding the Acid
Jazz things they play.    At one point,  the DJ played some house,  but was
repremanded for doing so.

No more $2 pancakes like they Used to serve,   a lot less than the old "Buffet",
but the $4 cover charge at least made up for it.    Next,  I dropped into the
EndUp to say hi to some friends.

Aaahhh!! Nothing like a Sunday Morning on South of Market....   Boogie Buffet
closed earlier, and figured it was about time to head out to the Berkeley
Matina and Sunset.    I sure wasn't dissapointed...  

-------------
SunSet party
-------------

When I arrive,  I find about 50 people milling around,  with the sound system
playing ambient and slow dance stuff.    I take the opportunity to meet and
schmooze with a few friends,   and gradually,  the beat pickes up and
immediatly I start dancing,  digging into the music and the visuals of
a perfect sunney Sunday afternoon in the park.   People were sunbathing,
flying kites,  playing frisbee,   and romping with their pets.

The music got down into some good funkey deep house,  with lots of sound
nuances embellishing some synth,  and other mind fucking "ear candy",
tickling my ears as I hoppped from speaker to speaker,  discoverng some
interesting "Phasing effects" from all the moving around.    Eventually,
things got so crowded that moving around was not possible.   I would
guess the crowed swelled to about 500 during the peak of this event.

I simply got lost into the music,  allowing it to have total control
over my body.    My knees completly healed how,  thanx to my exercises,
allowed me to be engrossed into doing some crazy motions without complaint.   
After about 3 hours of continious dancing,   some slight break in the 
music,  let me go...  So I struck out to discover who else was around.    

All the usual SFRavers were there,   and almost immediatly,  people come
up and say they haven't seen me for a while.   Wish I could be in two
places at once!!

This was the BEST Sunset party I've been to,   I sure hope it can contniue
to exist for a while longer.

The music finally stopped (Well after sunset - Around 10 pm),   and I
say to myself... "It's GREAT to be back"...   and head home...

Later...
The Cap'n

From: Paul Richard <pp000267@interramp.com>

Subject: Re: E Forest review.

I have to echo a lot of John's sentiments.  I had a great time (and no, Rob, it
 was NOT
my first party since I moved here, but it's been so long, it felt like it).
 Didn't get to meet
as many people as I would have hoped, but given the crowd, that's to be
 expected.

MAJOR HASSLE:  I arrive in a car with a friend; the close parking lot is filled.
  We are
told to go to the other area of the park about 10 miles away, and take a shuttle
 bus
back to the rave.   We arrive, we party, we get tired, we decide to go home at
 about 5:30.
  We arrive at the parking lot and discover that there is no return shuttle to
 wherever the
hell our car is parked.  The prospect of walking ten or so miles with majorly
 numb feet
(OK, so I forgot to put socks on with my Tevas - sue me) was a major bummer, but
 we
managed to talk a departing driver and friends into giving us a lift.  So I
 guess all's well
that ends well.

Paul

P.S.  Despite earlier posts to some, the President was not at Camp David last
 night.
However, he did know about the rave, as I gave him a flyer on Saturday morning,
 and
told him to stop by and visit a few thousand friends.

Yes, Wicked was a little hotter than normal and that sound system had me
dancin hard and nearly non-stop.  I've had so many good times at a packed
King St.  I was so sweat-soaked that I accidentally experienced the Hendrix
headband effect.  That feedback jam was amazing and provided a welcome break,
actually the DJs weren't as Wicked as they can be and there seemed to be more
beatless breakdowns -- either that or I just appreciated them more.  Good
thing it was housey and not non-stop hardcore or I would've passed out.  Was

i Mijos ! This has been one sloppy party! Ok, Ok, I enjoyed myself,
excellent music, we are all in awe of your system, great job, people. But
why the King? The Captain can't be the only person who hates the place.Hmm,
lemme see what's bein' said...
Geoff white wrote:
>Although the room did not do it [the new system] justice....  

Why buy an excellent system and stick it in there? 

Lee fogel's 2c:
>I got to Wicked at around 3 and managed to catch the last chunk of Jeno
and the first half of Garth before succumbing to the heat, humidity and
boomy acoustics that make King St. one of my least favorite venues.
If you like incessant no-escape pounding in a crowded zero-comfort sweatbox,
then this was certainly the place to be.

And Willis wong goes on:
>I couldn't get over the steam factor... just standing there made me sweat.  
>Walking around bumping into people drenched with sweat is very bizarre, 
>if there's any skin contact from arms or whatever there's this slipping 
>effect.  Nuts.

If all that sweat was dance induced, great, but you can get the same effect
on a packed bus with closed windows!

>The house was a very deep, consistent, danceable beat, but I didn't hear as 
>much cheering as usual for Wicked parties.  

That's because the people  were packed and hot, the floor was too wet and
muddy to sit down on, and there was "rave detritus" that stuck to your feet
on the dance "floor."I never saw one person jump up and down and scream
like at other parties, we were beat by the heat, and our vibe fed back to
the Djs, and they responded in kind. Very sloppy dancing by all of us,
compared to other Wickeds.


>So far I'd say I like wicked's at Townsend more because 
>of the room and slightly better air circulation... And it's got that 
>close encounters disco light right in the middle too.

Good point!

Did you (WICKED) all hear that? It ain't just me. Either get the King's
owners to get a ceiling exaust or put some sorta giant, portable, fan in
the corridor door to let us survive the night. Or just get a better place
next time. It's not easy to throw a party,duh,  especially Wicked, but
jeez, plan ahead and get us some space, too many people we love didn't show
or said  "the King, aw, man, not there!" early that night. 
By the way, how about some chill equipment? Rest is essential. We want
bags! We want bags!We want bags! We want bags!We want bags! We want bags!
Hey, still a great party, and I'm ready to be blown by the moon. 
Lotsa love,
 Milton and the E-Bee........

Precedence: bulk

I'm not down on Wicked parties cuz of heat.  I'm not asking them for 
this or that, because I'm just glad that there is something like Wicked to 
choose from.  Just like Cap'n Crunch said he chose not to go because he 
knows King St. and anyone else could do the same, right?  

I knew it was going to be a sweatbox from going last month, but I was 
just amazed at how much more it was this time - wHOA!  It would be cool 
to have more vents or something but if it doesn't happen then so be it.

Yes, that is actually one of the reasons why I like going to Wicked is for
a little bit of sweat.  If a little bit turns into a lot then it just
takes more skill not to slip.  Sure its nasty but it does seem to fit the
whole theme of it all and a lot of people don't seem to mind.  When I get
home and peel off my multiple-smoke-filled-dripping-wet clothes I always
think "man, that sure was wicked!" and fall asleep until whenever... 

-neutrally yours,
willis

Think about it more like a sweat lodge.
