---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 13 Sep 1994 15:49:16 -0400
From: Hossam A. El-Saie <hae2@po.cwru.edu>
To: Multiple recipients of list DCRAVES <DCRAVES@american.edu>
Subject: Re: IO Overdosegrrrl

a very good friend of mine (china) had an experience at interstellar
outback in kentucky that i know she wants as many people as possible to
know about. please read this and take what you can from it.

peace,
hossam




>
>Greetings to the MW/NE rave family:
>
>It has been three weeks since i died at Interstella Outback in Lexington,
>KY.  Yes, this is China and I was the subject of much of the controversy
>surrounding IO, drug use & the like.  I wanted to remain quiet for a few
>weeks to let everyone vent and quell down, but now I have to put my piece
>in to fill in the blanks from the perspective that only I can give it, the
>point of the person who died.
>
>First off:      PUBLIC CONFESSION.  I went to IO, danced all nite, then
>did heroin before sleeping at 6am and sent myself into respitory
>depression and died.  It was an unintelligent and irresponsible thing
>for me to do and i can't make up for it, but want to express my deep and
>sincere apologies to everyone for the scare, inconvenience and disservice
>I did to the image of rave (not untarnished on it's own.)  I
>single-handedly destroyed a party, ruined a vibe, and created havoc and
>many many bad trips.
>
>Second:  I am not an "young" or "stupid" girl.  What I *did* was stupid.
>But quite possibly an indicator in the uncertainty and risks involved in
>what is becoming a more common and accepted thing.  For those of you that
>have never met me, I've been raving for close to four years (ugh...age), I
>am 23 and a senior who is graduating from art school in December with a
>3.97 gpa.  I'm a photographer who has work published in several art
>journals as well as Spin and Rolling Stone.
>
>        My use of chemicals came from a desire to explore the politics of
>reality.  I was lucky and had resources available to me that allowed me
>the base to garner much knowledge of pharmacology and physio/psychological
>use of these chemicals.  Immediate, extended, longterm and the like.  I
>knew the ramifications.  I knew the risks and the proper ways to use.
>        As for heroin & narcotics in general.  It's a long and complex
>issue as to this particular addiction.  I make no excuses for my use or
>addiction.  But I also refuse to be dismissed as a *stupid girl* or an
>*unresponsible junky*  To see or know me, you would *never* know I was/am
>a junky.  I have a job that people (for some reason) envy, I go and do
>well in school, I have responsibilities and expectations I must meet.
>But look at my arms and know that IO wasn't the first thyme I shot drugs.
>
>TASCIALAXIS (i *know* i am spelling that wrong, but i can't locate it
>right off the bat in my notes) but its a term used to explain the rapidly
>rising tolerence experienced with drug use.  I use it to explain also the
>tolerency that we get in our own and others drug use.  We all go from
>having no knowledge/experience with drugs and get to lots of different
>stances.  It's a slow process.  Hindsight is the *only* clear view of it
>no matter how well you think you understand what is occuring.  If you
>thought you would never do drugs and are...think of why?  If you said *i
>only want to do (insert chemical here) for (whatever reason.)  Has that
>changed?  Have you ever done a substance to stay awake?  Because everyone
>looked like they were having fun?  No matter how easy it seems, no matter
>how much you know about what you are doing.  No matter *how much* nothing
>could ever happen to you...keep yourself in check.  Keep your friends in
>check.  It's not nagging.  It's being a friend.  Compassion, not judgement.
>        The fact is that the more you do, the more you think you are in
>control.  Bad trips happen to people that shouldn't do drugs, can't handle
>it.  Overdoses happen to people who are excessive, mix drugs, don't know
>about their drug and take too much.  It's
>important to know that I was none of these.  I didn't fall neatly into a
>catagory that you could say..."oh, she fucked up because (a.b.c.d...) and
>she should have know..."
>        For the record I've done a 18 month research
>project on narcotics addiction, and get synthethic heroin (hydro-morphone)
>straight from a pharmacy (bypassing any risk of impure street heroin)
>The effect is the same, the purtiy is standard.  And we had done this
>before.  We had done like 5X the amount we did that nite.
>
>Something somewhere just decided that we all needed a little kick
>in the ass and I got to be the lucky one with the sore butt! ;)  I got too
>cocky, thought I knew enough that i wasn't in a dangerous situation, that
>i had everything under control.  But (moral of story) YOU CAN NEVER
>PREDICT WHAT WILL HAPPEN.
>
>Something kicked me off my high-hobbyhorse and
>stated
>
>         "i don't care HOW LONG, you've done,
>         or what RESEARCH you've conducted,
>         or HOW MUCH you have done before.
>
>                I can take you anythyme,
>                                anywhere
>                                 and without any reason or warning...
>You get once practice try...
>Let's hope you learn something."
>
>The lesson wasn't just to me.  It was to everyone who say me blue and not
>breathing.  It was to everyone who
>questions their own or friends drug use, or were contemplating using a
>first thyme.  I just got to be the example.
>
>        BE CAREFUL!!! Drug use can go from personal exploration and growth
>to escapism and addiction with little warning or appearence.  BE AWARE!!!
>The drugs you buy amy not be what you think they are.  Garner knowledge of
>what the drugs you are interested in look like.  Affect you like.  Know
>what you will be like in 20 years if you choose to incorperate this in
>your life.  Know what the effect are so that if you feel weird, you can
>know if it is *drug-induced paranoia* or something is *really* wrong.
>
>        My seven years of exploration and use didn't prepare me at all for
>death.  I thought that I would know if I felt *woozy.* If something was
>wrong.  But I took the drug and ten minutes passed out (friends thought i
>had just decided to go to bed), ten minutes later i started convulsing,
>ten minutes later I turned blue and stopped breathing, ten minutes later I
>lost my pulse.  I flatlined.  I died.
>
>                                I DIED...
>
>you all getting this?
>
>I stayed flatlined just under 8 minutes they said, the ambulence arrived
>and injected my with a drug called Narcalt when they found that it was
>narcotic related.  It brought my pulse back.  The medics told my friends
>as the ambulence took me away that "your friend might now come back."
>Gave me less than 20% recovery.  When my pulse came back they told them
>that if i woke up, I might be *very* different that I was.  Brain damage.
>
>I did wake up.  I have no brain damage. I even convinced to release me tht
>day. (I *hate* hospitals)  The doctors, nurses, medics, hell even the
>state trooper showed me incredible compassion and the power of humaness
>that day.   The whole moment of infinity was revelaed to me when I asked
>"How did I get here?" to the doctor and was answered; "Your friends, the
>ones in the lobby.  They called an ambulence.  They saved your life."
>
>                                        My friends...
>
>                                                        waiting in the lobby
>                They saved my life...
>                Those *are* friends...
>                        Peekay, Hossam, Kira, Sammi & Darren...
>                                                        i love you all
>
>I got on Vrave that night...i got compassion from all of you.  Even JJ.
>First concern was for my safety.  Then for the accuracy of the rumours.
>Then questions to my motives...                         PLUR...peace
>                                                               love
>                                                               unity
>                                                               respect
>
>        So...i am not just a junky.  Or a stupid girl who does heroin for
>fun at raves.  I am everyperson.  Each of us.  I am the weekend you did
>too much.  I am the trip where you understood everything.  I am the thyme
>you laughed with another person for the first thyme in years.  I am the
>thyme you were afraid.  The thyme you wanted to stay straight when
>everyone else wasn't.  I'm the DJ who compelled you to move.  I'm the
>first thyme you experienced pure MDMA.  I'm the breakfast SUnday morning
>at Denny's with the NETRavers.  I'm that intellibeam you developed a
>relationship with over the course of the evening.  I am all of these thing
>because I am a raver, a net raver and we are all a FAMILY.
>        So like a family, you somethymes want to beat up your siblings.
>For thier actions, irresponsibilities. Stupidity.  You don't understand,
>you judge.  Or maybe the severity makes you want to close your mind.
>Punish.  But also like a sibling in this family who realized i did
>something wrong I confess my action, and it's wrongness and ask you
>collectivly for your forgiveness and compassion.
>        Remember this when/if you or your friend gets out of control or
>starts to ack irresponsibly.  Don't lash out, but rather try to understand
>then reasons or motives and help them.
>
>
>Oh...one more thing.
>        Anyone who wants to continue this discussion.  About anything.
>Motives, curiosity about what went on.  Curiosity of the narcotics. Hell,
>even to what the afterlife is like! ;) Or just feel the personal vendetta
>to flame the hell out of me, i'm a big grrrl and can handle *constructive*
>criticism.  Feel free to write me.  Lollipop; thank you for your open
>compassion in your post.  Roo, for your maturity and adult concern and
>tact.  JJ for everything!  And Peekay, Hossam, Kira, Sammi and Darren.  I
>love you guys! And i promise never to be a tard again.
>        I promise never to ruin a vibe like that again.  Raves are a
>beautiful phenomena by nature and undergo tons of negative hysteria by
>those who don't understand it.  We on the inside need to boot the PLUR
>above anything else to combat that.  I hope to see you all soon and am
>glad to be given another chance to check out the validity of life.
>Everyone...heed.
>
>Chinagrrrl
>
>

--
vrave:sphinx                                      TranceFused Productions
*its all about the vibe*                     Infoline/Voicemail: 804.768.2000

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 13 Sep 1994 11:35:53 -0700

Subject: Parttime Job available


Partime Job available @ InterNex - Customer Suppport

We have a small parttime job availabe for someone with a small amount
of computer experience.  Basically you would be working for me in customer
support.  This would entail mostly answering phones, filling out "trouble
tickets" when customers call in with problems, and some moderately interesting
jobs like configuring customer router and bridge hardware before it is shipped,
(if you can read and touch type, you can do this).  You would work about
4 hours a day and the pay is around $10/hr.  Our offices are in Menlo 
Park so this would be a great job if you go to Stanford or San Jose State.

We are pretty flexible at InterNex, no dress codes or bullshit like that.

If you like it here and we like you, the job could definitely expand into
something bigger.


Send all inquiries to geoffw@internex.net

Obrave: as of right now I and everyone who works for me are ravers.

Actually, tickets for this event is NOT available in SF. I tried
unsuccessfully to get tickets yesterday at two different places. The
seller had no difficulties in finding the event within the database; the
problem was that the printers would not actually print out the tickets
correctly.  This is a system-wide problem that BASS has acknowledged. 
Unfortunately, they don't want to do anything about it right now.

Lee

OBrave plug: I'll be spinning down in LA this Friday at Kevin Haskin's (of
Love & Rockets) birthday party/rave. This will be a small event of about
200 people and will be invite only. However, that doesn't prevent me from
having a list and letting as many people as I want in (within reason
anyways). If you're going to be in LA this Friday and want to go, drop me
a line and I'll try to put you on the list. See you there! 

p.s. Some guy named Taylor will be spinning there also. =)

------------------------------------------------------------------
Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
the SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 11:55ish to 1:10 or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is now basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself/& I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules.

 It's every Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I shifted the lunch meeting time a 
bit -  I hope to see more of you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 11:50AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

The Venue prohibits water bottles so that they can make money by selling
bottled water.  Water is also available in the bathrooms for free, and I had no
trouble getting a cup of ice for free.  I don't mind this too much since
the deal that is usually made is that the promoter gets the door and the
club gets the bar, I also think that's part of the reason that the temperature 
is as hot as it is (although it *is* a tradition for indoor Wickeds to be
as hot as hell :)

and I love 'em.  Of course, heat, sweat and house music don't make a wicked -

been to a wicked party - you *remember* them and its a cool contrast to the
FMRs and other outdoor events.  Milton was relaying some other attendees
feelings who asked him to do so and since he was wearing a dress,  I don't
know what he was complaing about - unless that bra was chafing him ;-)

>     I feel nothing but pity for those who have to do heroin in order to
>    "explore the politics of reality."

I got a sense that the "Overdosegrrrl" felt somehow superior for having
"died" and come back to life.  I was especially irked by her unctious
praise of her disciples for having saved her life (Uh, like who wouldn't
dial 911!).

Wow!  Like, here's a woman who's really been to the edge!  I see a crowd of
lesser mortals asking "what was it like?".   "Were you drawn to a pillar of
light?"  "Did you see god?"

Are we supposed to be impreesed that she has an enviable job and yet is
able to do heroin?  Is this some kind of post-modern fashion statement:  I
am successful but I have an edge.  Try piercing your tongue and working for
Apple Computer, that would be much safer.


William H. Birdsong
Medical Student, UCB-UCSF Joint Medical Program

birdsong@uclink2.berkeley.edu

	On Sep 14, 12:00pm, William H. Birdsong wrote:
> Subject: Re[2]: IO Overdosegrrrl (fwd)
>
> >     I feel nothing but pity for those who have to do heroin in order to
> >    "explore the politics of reality."
>
> I got a sense that the "Overdosegrrrl" felt somehow superior for having
> "died" and come back to life.  I was especially irked by her unctious
> praise of her disciples for having saved her life (Uh, like who wouldn't
> dial 911!).
>
> Wow!  Like, here's a woman who's really been to the edge!  I see a crowd of
> lesser mortals asking "what was it like?".   "Were you drawn to a pillar of
> light?"  "Did you see god?"
>
> Are we supposed to be impreesed that she has an enviable job and yet is
> able to do heroin?  Is this some kind of post-modern fashion statement:  I
> am successful but I have an edge.  Try piercing your tongue and working for
> Apple Computer, that would be much safer.
>

I fail to see how so many people could find so little out of this womans post.
What I got out of it was no matter how carefull, and how intelligent you are,
when using drugs, you can 1) overdose/kill yourself, and 2) become addicted.
In addition I think this post also served to thank those who loved her enough
to respond quickly and stay by her side throughout the whole ordeal.  It also
seemed to serve as a way to resolve her own feelings on the matter.

At any rate this individual deserves our compassion and our most positive
of energies.  It is clear the rave scene is different in all parts of the
country
which is also probably reflected in the drug of choice at raves.  I think it
should also serve as a warning to all of us out here to not allow ourselves
to follow in those footsteps and continue to work hard to promote positive
vibes at our events, which only comes from bringing a great attitude with
you to an event and sharing it with those around you.

Enough ranting from me,

Ron.

> William H. Birdsong
> Medical Student, UCB-UCSF Joint Medical Program
>
> 510-658-8570
> birdsong@uclink2.berkeley.edu
>
>-- End of excerpt from William H. Birdsong

Think Velvet Underground, David Bowie, Jane's Addiction and heroin.

Not to mention X and raving (before you flame, think about
perceptions of others - those who read the Chron, etc. Fashion
has to do with perceptions of a gesamt).


-j

"Blah Blah Blah"

Jamie Lawrence                                  <jamiel@sybase.com>

> Can someone please explain the reasoning behind this? I assume that 
> "access to water" means free access - so why prohibit water bottles ?

Aside from the previous explanations, a promoter told me that another
reason they don't want water bottles because of GHB or any substance other
than water.  In some of the raves I went to during the summer in LA, they
only allowed me to bring in water that was bottled.  (I had a bottle that
was opened during the car ride down to the rave, which I had to leave
outside.) But it defenately (?) is a rip off when a bar sells bottled
water $2.00 when you can buy the same little bottles in packs of 6 for
$1.69!

At 15:43 9/14/94 -0500, Komotion International wrote:
>Hey, y'all. Time for my first truly rave-related post, with no mention of
>lawyers, contractors or the Fire Department...
>
>Does anyone know of any raves or house parties in the Santa
>Barbara/Goleta/San Luis Obispo area?  My former sysadmin is in Lompoc,
>California and I'm trying to get him into this. Any info on ongoing
>parties, semi-regular promoters or whatever would be appreciated.
>
>
>judge
>

I'm involved with a group called the Justice League Sound System in SB who
put on most of the events there, although now that I live in SF I don't
make it down as frequently. We do a free beach party called Horizon the
first Sat. of the month, occasional one-offs (we might be doing an outdoor
event in 3-4 weeks) and a weekly called Justice. For info on all of the
above call 805.899.7336. It's a small, but very friendly and energetic
scene there. Ironically about half of the people who were in it 1-2 years
ago have now moved to SF, but that seems to be a trend all over.

There was another group, the League of Spiritual Discovery, that put on a
cuple of weeklies and one-offs, but they haven't done anything for a few
months and I think their voicemail has been disconnected.

There are a lot of people in the scene in SLO as well, but no regular
events that I'm aware of.

Actually, Monty, who spins at Justice every week and is my pick for Next
Big Dj (TM) is spinning at Sunset this week.

Joe

-----(ambient@netcom.com)--------------------(of what's happening now)---------

[ Bileous remarks about a person he's never met deleted. ]

You really make me sad.  China (overdosegrrrl) is an actual
physical real-life friend of mine, and here you go judging
someone you've never met who is trying to communicate something that
happened to her and her circle of MidWest Raves friends.

Personally, I don't think Susie should have ever reposted China's
post here, simply because the SFRaves list membership doesn't have 
the context to understand China or her relationship with other 
net-ravers at all.

China is truly one of the more interesting and beautiful (*and I'm
not meaninging solely in the physical sense*) people I have ever met.
I don't think for a second that she ever should have stuck that needle
in her arm . . . but I'd NEVER accuse her of holding herself up to
be "superior" after her experience.

Where is your PLUR?

Laura

It's not "really" the same people as the Megatripolis in London.
See, Frazer Clark and others founded Megatripolis in London.  After
a while there was a falling-out and Clark and the rest of the club went
their separate ways.  There was some kind of legal settlement where
the club in London could keep the name, and where Clark could use the
name in other ventures.

So it sort of is the same people . . . I find that whole crowd to be
so confusing, what with the Megatriplians, the UK-Zippies, the US-Zippies,
and so on. :-)

Laura

On Wed, 14 Sep 1994, William H. Birdsong wrote:

> I got a sense that the "Overdosegrrrl" felt somehow superior for having
> "died" and come back to life.  I was especially irked by her unctious
> praise of her disciples for having saved her life (Uh, like who wouldn't
> dial 911!).

	I think this critism of China's thankfulness to her friends is a 
bit misplaced. If I have the situation right, she was not the only one 
who had shot up. Although I do not know how injecting herion differs from 
getting it in a pill doped with it, I can tell you herion is not a drug 
which motivates you to do things. This combined with the setting and the 
possiblity that her friends had taken some substance that night makes an 
act worthy of praise. Hell, in a lot of situations things days, people 
will walk right by a situation where someone needs medical attention 
without a second thought. Or of those that do stop (now this is just my 
experience, so it may not apply to all of reality) are much more 
interested with looking than with helping (or listening to those who have 
training in the realm of medical emergencies). Granted China was a 
friend, and most friends will call for help once they realize something 
is wrong, I still think she has a right to be as grantful to them as she 
is. Indeed she has been through something, something which the majority 
of us may not experience  (her comment of coming to and asking how she 
had gotten to the where-ever it is she was, ie. the hosiptal. The 
realization of what must have happened must have been something powerful, 
huge, whatever you want to call it, just something that most people do 
not experience in their lifetimes, as far as I can guess). I, myself, do 
not expect my friends to call 911 in such things happen. Indeed I would 
like them to, but their doing so is not 'contracted' in being my friend. 
This may be a shallow ideal of friendship (that one is not committed to 
saving a friend's life in all situations) but it is one I have adopted 
from experience. One cannot always save someone's life, but when an 
effort is made, it is nice to have the person express that he or she is 
glad you did it...
	In terms of the ODing to the point of the heart actually stopping
(well, she said she had no pulse, I guess that means she could have only
been in vfib, anyway...) I may be a bit biased here cuz I know someone
else who had a smimilar experience and she explained the coming to bit to
me. It changes your outlook on a lot of things...  

> Are we supposed to be impreesed that she has an enviable job and yet is
> able to do heroin?  Is this some kind of post-modern fashion statement: 
> I am successful but I have an edge.  Try piercing your tongue and
>  working for Apple Computer, that would be much safer. 

	She wrote quite a bit about this. Her answer was no. She, like a 
lot of others who take drugs, is not a 'dead beat', nor a leech on 
society, nor an awful criminal who is going to rob to get her 'fix' (a 
line a cop once told me when they went over our car when the stereo was 
stolen)She did not fit into the categories that most of us put those who 
have let their drug use become an addiction (I should extend addiction to 
any habit that gets out of one's control, but for some reason this 
phenomona in the realm of drugs have been labeled adiction while outside 
that realm it is an obsession or the people is simply neurotic). If I 
remember correctly, China never said that her drug use made her harder 
than the rest of us, nor do I remember her being of the expressly 
'hardcore with attitude' type ( I used to be on some of te east coast 
mailing lists and heard much from her as she was on dcraves).
	I thought her post expressed a sentiment I wholeheartedly agree 
with,one taking responsiblity for one's drug use.  And she illustrated 
her point well: Here's what can happen to YOU, only you may not come 
back... 
Surfing the Aphex's sine waves
	Among others...
dave

Well, I for one am glad to see that Susie posted China's story. Maybe it
will make others think twice before playing with fire. I for one saw it
as a post of someone who wanted to share her story about her brush with
her mortality. I thought that it was well written and I felt nothing but
compassion for her. I was glad to hear that she had no brain damage...
pretty amazing for being dead for 8 minutes as alot of people who have
been revived after drowning after only 3 minutes have suffered major
damage. She was verrry lucky. She was lucky that she wasn't alone.
I didn't feel that she came off as superior. She impressed me as being
genuine and happy to be alive.

Rox

> I got a sense that the "Overdosegrrrl" felt somehow superior for having
> "died" and come back to life

I didn't get a sense that she felt at all "superior" but that she was 
feeling (as most junkies coming off a binge...two months or twelve 
years... do) the rush of "reality" and life itself coming back.

> Are we supposed to be impreesed that she has an enviable job and yet is
> able to do heroin?

I doubt it. Lots of us do it. Look at the people in the stock market. 
Lots & lots of junkies there. There's also a high rate amongst 
programmers. Think of it this way for a second: if your a junkie, 
what better way to support your habit than to keep your job that will 
pay for it? Lots of people work "better" on junk...floating, numb, 
quiet in the corporate world.

Try piercing your tongue and working for
> Apple Computer, that would be much safer.

It seems to me that you're completely missing the point. I know that 
a pierced tongue and keeping a good ("enviable" is appropriate too) 
job does not force one to explore the same, or even similar, aspects 
of life. A pierced tongue compared to junkiedom is kinda like 
comparing a fashionable haircut to having a terrible life-threatening 
accident on a Ducati.

Alissa

>OF COURSE opium is toxic to humans

wrong. Overdose is an incredibly different circumstance than 
poisoning!

One of the hugest problems with opiate addictions is that the human 
body and opiates are so incredibly compatible. Physiological 
dependancy. And when an opiate-addicted person stops using the body 
goes into shock because it (the body) senses that the world itself is 
toxic.

amazing, and fascinating this body vs. lifestyle equations stuff! But not 
really rave-related anymore is it? Anybody that wants to continue 
this thread with me, that's great but let's get off the list with it

Alissa

story from the Village Voice a couple of issues ago about heroin users.

article, written by a long-time user, showed that the popular stereotypes
of junkies are just that - stereotypes, of which you can certainly find
real-life examples.  If anything, heroin seems to be an amplifier of

I just want to point out the below this is a really good
attitude to have on this topic, IMO. I'm don't want this
to sound hipper-than-thou or snotty, but if you have never
been close with someone who is into heroin, than you probably
don't get it. There is so much misinformation and outright
myth surrounding the drug that most people out there don't
understand anything about what it really means. I'm not
endorsing it and I'm not 'condoning' it (does it matter,
really?), but people that criticize without having any
understanding of it should realize that they are (if I may
be a little harsh) talking out their ass.

Also, I have a pierced tongue and work at a computer company,
and resent the 'successful with an edge' comment. I'm proof
that is entirely possible to do both and be hopelessly unsuccessful.
(That's sarcasm, BTW.)

Trying to talk to the judgement cops,
-j

At 7:59 PM 9/14/94, 'Dave Bayer' wrote:

>> Are we supposed to be impreesed that she has an enviable job and yet is
>> able to do heroin?  Is this some kind of post-modern fashion statement:
>> I am successful but I have an edge.  Try piercing your tongue and
>>  working for Apple Computer, that would be much safer.
>
>        She wrote quite a bit about this. Her answer was no. She, like a
>lot of others who take drugs, is not a 'dead beat', nor a leech on
>society, nor an awful criminal who is going to rob to get her 'fix' (a
>line a cop once told me when they went over our car when the stereo was
>stolen)She did not fit into the categories that most of us put those who
>have let their drug use become an addiction (I should extend addiction to
>any habit that gets out of one's control, but for some reason this
>phenomona in the realm of drugs have been labeled adiction while outside
>that realm it is an obsession or the people is simply neurotic). If I
>remember correctly, China never said that her drug use made her harder
>than the rest of us, nor do I remember her being of the expressly
>'hardcore with attitude' type ( I used to be on some of te east coast
>mailing lists and heard much from her as she was on dcraves).
>        I thought her post expressed a sentiment I wholeheartedly agree
>with,one taking responsiblity for one's drug use.  And she illustrated
>her point well: Here's what can happen to YOU, only you may not come
>back...

>dave

Nope, they recently released the original 2-cd version in the states.

> 	I think that was the first ORB CD I bougth and one of my first
> 	ambient CD and it is still one of my favourites.

Same here!

> 	BTW, what do you think of POMME FRITZ ? It's different from the
> 	usual ORB and I still don't know how do I like it.
> 	I was reading the posting on alt.music.orb and this seems to be
> 	the general feeling.

Heh.  It's very er... weird.  I wrote a review of it for Wired.  I 
basically said that if you can imagine Negativland meets Monty Python, 
you might like this.

> 	Somebody on alt.music.orb also talked about a remix of Pink Floyd's
> 	"Wish you were here" with some Orb in it (Little fluffy clouds),
> 	but it seems the remix is not from the Orb. Anybody knows more about
> 	this record ?

There's a bootleg CD going around claiming to be Pink Floyd songs remixed 
by the Orb, but supposedly it's a hoax and very lousy musically.

	Brian

If any of you were at Wicked last weekend, I was the guy who walked
by at about 12:30, thinking the line was too long.  Anyway, I went
over to the 14th St party someone posted about, and thought it was 
great.  This weekend, Organic is back - they've been some of the best
big parties lately.  Also, check out the boat party or Sunset on Sunday
and the full moon party on Monday.  Tonight, try the opening of Lube
or a good lineup at Pure Space...

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

        and power house.  Guest DJs weekly (SF & East Bay)

        acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.

From: "Dana WATANABE" <DWATANAB@uci.edu>
Message-Id: <199409160007.AA01815@mothra.nts.uci.edu>
Subject: poopiness (was Re: IO Overdosegrrrl)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves@hyperreal.com)
Date: Thu, 15 Sep 94 17:07:38 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i've written this message quite a few times now cuz i keep deleting it

i dont want to sound preaching or judgemental or anything..
and i really dont think i have much to add that hasnt been said 
on the topic...

the one thing that sticks out to me though is this..

(i'll go through a bit of story time here :)

Last summer i was a counselor with this program for incoming students
to the University

The environment among the staff (also students) that is created is one 
of incredible safety and openess that permeates from the staff to the 
incoming students so that the environment is usually pretty unique
in allowing people to be and explore themselves.

One time, during this program, some 500 or so people were in a room
and we were watching a video about health/sex education.
In one of the scenes a man was talking about his date,
and when he used the word "he" in reference to his date,
there was a very loud groan and other disgusted mumblings.

The chill that i felt come over my body and the complete
nausea that took over my whole being was incredible.  

Point of the story?

I dunno... a VERY similar feeling crept across me as i read the messages
on here that seemed (to Me) to be in complete ignorance
of the fact that someone DIED.

but really.. think about that.
death.
no heart beat.
8 minutes.
thats what something like 500-600 heart beats that should have happened
but Didnt...

just try staring at a clock and watch a second hand tick 
and realize everytime it does.. your heart wouldnt

i dunno.. i dont know china at all... we've been online at teh same time
but i dont think i've ever said more than a quick 'Hi'

but that post really meant a lot to me, living in the drug culture
that i happen to live in...
maybe thats why it didnt seem preachy or high horsed to me
maybe its somethign i really needed to hear...

maybe its cuz my brothers fiancee OD'd on coke and had a seisure
and he got to hold her in his arms, covered in her blood,
as she died...

although i can see the relevance of any drug to the discussion
about the rave scene (and related messages that get put
on CD inserts), i think the most important relevance here
is compassion for a hurt raver

something, that _I_ think we would hopefully all have

 ,
dana

"the EPA loves saying how many thousands of people get cancer
from saccharin, but never mention how many thousands get it
from cauliflower"

>opium is not toxic to humans in any way. withdrawal, however, IS.
>so is HIV spread by needles.

Ummm. actually, opium is a very potent analgesic which has several adverse
side effects including  respiratory depression (which can kill you!!!),
nausea, dysphoria (a bad feeling), increased biliary pressure (predisposing
to gall bladder disease), physical dependence, allergic reactions such as
skin rashes, bronchoconstriction (not to cool if you haver asthma)!  Read
up before you shoot up!

William H. Birdsong
Medical Student, UCB-UCSF Joint Medical Program

510-658-8570
birdsong@uclink2.berkeley.edu

Heroin is a lot more complex than you give it credit for, birdsong.
I managed to chop my previous message, but I really do think that
Village Voice article from about a month ago gets into this in a
compelling way.  Like alcohol, heroin is an escape *and* an amplifier
of pre-existing problems, in addition to its direct psycho/pharmacological
effects.  I say this only on observation, I've never done it myself.

Heroin has a justifiably bad rap, but people keep doing it, and the reasons
are not identical for doing so, the social settings are not identical,
and so on.  

I suspect we all do things from time to time we probably shouldn't.
(Hey, what's that empty Nestle's Crunch package doing on my desk, huh?!)
It strikes me as uncharitable at best to criticize someone else who comes
to terms with this in such a public manner as China did.  What she wrote
taught *me* more about this situation, and about the deeper issues we're
wrestling with in this life . . .

c u in the future

phred

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep 16 17:27:24 1994

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Re[2]: IO Overdosegrrrl (fwd)
In-Reply-To: <9409150000.ZM23093@well.sf.ca.us>
References: <2A26382E011C0400@sybex.com>
	<9409150000.ZM23093@well.sf.ca.us>
	<AFEINBER@sybex.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

You can go at any time. A few days ago, a coworker of mine, Josh, had
a head-on crash so violent that his windshield ended up in the back
seat. If it hadn't been for the airbag deflecting it upward, it'd have
gone right through his head. He walked away from that one. I've known
several people that didn't.

Sometimes people need to be reminded that what they are doing
shouldn't be taken for granted. I think China's post should be heeded.

You know, heroin isn't especially dangerous in itself. It takes a long
time to get addicted, and most people who use it don't get addicted at
all. Compare to tobacco, where 9 out of 10 people who ever smoked a
cigarette are still smoking.  Even when addicted, it does not present
health problems; history has many cases where well known and well
respected professionals have been addicted their entire lives without
consequence. Again, compare to tobacco, the #2 killer in the USA next
to heart disease.

The only thing really dangerous about it is that there's no quality
control.  Are you getting a dose, or 200 doses, or 2000 doses? Care to
bet your life on it?

Our government need to recognize that the WOD is a failure, that
people are dying because of the lack of quality control, and that the
best way to prevent death and suffering is to legalize it, regulate
it, and provide support for those who want help.

Anything else is a witchhunt.

Sean

Subject: Xochopilli
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Mijos, a poem for Xochipilli, the Nahuatl god of the sun and plants, by the
wise people of Oaxaca....

                   (Flowers foster friendship-translation below)

Solo las flores son nuestra riqueza      
Por medio dellas nos hacemos amigos    
y con el canto nuestra pessadumbre se dissipa

Y en el las flores preciosas se ven sus flores en la tierra
Lo sabe el corazon nuestro.
Cantad como lo quiere el corazon de
 aquiel por quien vivimos en la tierra.
_____________________________________________________________

Only flowers are our wealth.
Through them  friendship between us grows
 and through song our sadness vanished.

And by the precious flowers we are permitted to see
 your flowers here on earth.
We know it in our hearts.
May you sing according to His heart's desire,
  by whom we live on earth.

If you made it this far, mijos, know then that the Nahuatl, people of
Oaxaca and its highlands, refer to mushshrooms as "flowers" in their poems,
and used them in both profound ceremonies and in revelry, with dancing,
music and the warmth that comes from being surrounded by smiling, loving
freinds. This was an essential part of meso-american religion and
especially popular culture, as were morning glory seed (conataining
D-Lysergic amides) and several other spiritually powerful herbs. 
 R.G. Wasson, now in his ninetees (I believe) travelled there and took part
in a curandeira's ritual in the 30's! He introduced Timothy Leary to the
'shroom....It was wasson who saved this poem in his book and can be
credited for their (toadstools) access to us (ancient europeans used the
more dangerous Amanita muscaria that grows in colder regions, not too
popular!). He and his wife dedicated their lives to shroom studies and have
several entralling books ("mushrooms, russia and history" and "the magic
mushroom" and "the entheogenic origin of religion" where he links the birth
of religions with ingestion of certain plants and the visions/doors opened
thereafter...)
Maybe we're propagating that ancient vibe? I hope so,but wow, what a
responsibility!
Rave on, 
 Milton and the E-Bee....

Subject: Heroin & tobacco...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 16 Sep 1994 17:42:19 -0700 (PDT)
In-Reply-To: <9409170027.AA03209@pilot.njin.net> from "Sean Casey" at Sep 16, 94 08:27:25 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1088      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> You know, heroin isn't especially dangerous in itself. It takes a long
> time to get addicted, and most people who use it don't get addicted at
> all. Compare to tobacco, where 9 out of 10 people who ever smoked a
> cigarette are still smoking.

Heroin and tobacco both must be taken daily (pack-a-day or more for cigs)
for 1-2 months before physical addiction sets in.  However, once this
happens, even if you quit, _one dose_ will jump-start your addiction
right back up.

The figure for crack is 5 in 10.  All are addictive -- I think the
difference can be explained by relative availability.  I support
legalization, but don't fool myself into thinking _less_ people
would shoot up if it were legal; less people would die, though, which
is the important thing.

> The only thing really dangerous about it is that there's no quality
> control.  Are you getting a dose, or 200 doses, or 2000 doses? Care to
> bet your life on it?

More importantly, what is it cut with?  Quinine is common and also
very nasty.

You can't have a war on drugs; you can only have a war on people.

// g

Hey, Lee An was sposed to get me on the guest list for Kevin Haskin's b-day
party rave down here in L.A. but he didn't tell me how to get there or where it
was gonna be.

Can someone drop me a VMB nbumber or an address even por favor?

thanks




   milk
   weed
                                                     paul.geronca@support.com

>LUBE was excellent- great location on the water with excellent sound.

I agree 100%.  The sound was *very* good at both the ambient and the dance
floor locations.  Being that both areas are outdoors it made for a very
clean sound and to my surprise almost without sound transfer between each
area.

Miguel played a wonderful set of ambient music for almost the entire
evening.  Great selection and variety!

At the dance floor I managed to dance myself into a sweaty mess although
the night had gotten a little cool. Shoban (I hope I'm spelling this right)
spun an eclectic set to get the dance floor in motion then split her set
with "Ken Machine" LIVE - what a quirky fun group they are, then Shoban
came back spinning for awhile until Alex took over at 12:30.  I may be a
little biased but I think he has incredible control over the emotion and
energy of the music.  Alex is incredible at teasing you for awhile and then
he goes for the kill.  Great set Alex!

>next week at LUBE:
>
>Weird Blinking Lights will generate electronic sounds and WBL DJ
>CALIBAN will spin
>
>we'll have a sound system all to ourself and its
>BIG SYNTHESIZER night- forget those tinysynths that are easy to carry-
>we are bringing out the BIG ones- the 60+pounders that need special
>WIDE LOAD trucks to carry them down the street. Extra power generators
>will be sunk to the bottom of the bay to convert saline->alternating
>current to fuel these monsters.

Sounds like we will need solid state ear plugs for this one:) :)

Don't miss it.  It was alot of fun.

Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com

From sfraves-owner  Sun Sep 18 01:09:39 1994

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id BAA04318; Sun, 18 Sep 1994 01:09:39 -0700

	id OAA25279; Sat, 17 Sep 1994 14:27:23 -0700
Received: by uclink.berkeley.edu (8.6.8/1.33(web)-oc4)
	id OAA21685; Sat, 17 Sep 1994 14:24:00 -0700
Date: Sat, 17 Sep 1994 14:24:00 -0700
From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199409172124.OAA21685@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: a late take on the new moon
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


well, the moon of course waxes anew..sorry this post is a little out of
date but i goofily missent it last week:


we had it at gregg's house on Albany Hill, overlooking the lovely and
talented I80 highway, vroom vroom.  

we started out, kind of, at sunset, with an absolutely fabulous ambient
plus a little beat set from Ronan, fresh from a month-long stay in LA.
lucky for us, he is back for good.  ronan spins cds & comes equipped with
cd mixer plus lots of incredible music.  (i say "kind of" started jus
'cause we were still setting up.) the altar was assembled with his music
providing the perfect musical backdrop.  thanks go out to the MESS crew
for providing the decks, and Sean Casey for the use of his mixer.

the house is huge & we were able to set up a second sound system (provided
by Harlan and Billie, wizards of sound and light) downstairs in the garage,
which was transformed into the chillest of deep chill spaces, complete 
with wall-to-wall carpets (rescued from several flea markets), black lights,
a wall of paper for painting w/ flurescent paints, a big-screen video
projector, candles and so on.  many people contributed to make this space
work, including maui, sean c, pal greg, the MESS crew, harlan & billie plus
a few early arrivals to the party, including some sfravers.  wow...you
guys are the greatest.  thankyou again and again!

after ronan spun, m noraml went on with ovid, who did a quantum visualization
reading.  right now i'm kicking myself for not asking to tape it, just
because i'd love to hear it again.  i bet there are a lot of people, myself
included, that would like the chance to re-enter the frame of mind their
performance created.  

scottie of MESS took over after m and began the dance phase of the evening.
by then (12:30 or so) people were FLOODING in, provoking a few worries about
whether the house could hold so many people comfortably.  in fact, we had
to shut down the voicemail around 3 jus' cause they kept on coming.  many
people were heading over to the new moon party after going to the sunset
party at the marina & many of these had been playing all weekend.  we met
peole from Oregon, Reno, LA & other distant locations who were in the area
for the long weekend.  

after scottie, tracy ameba went on.  people kept coming up to me saying
"tracy is the shit!!" & yes, i have to agree!  this was only the third
time i'd heard her play & it was fabulous.  i hope i get to hear her
again soon.

downstairs was totally ambient all night, with Billie, Scottie, Bonnie
(recently arrived from Denver, i believe) and Mark Ameba.  this was the
first time mark had spun at this party (& the first time i've heard him
play) & it was right on: trippy, smooth but with just enough of an edge
to keep me going.  the space had a way of sucking people into the chill..
i wish i could show you some of the paintings that people made, including
one side of a conversation someone had on paper 'cause he'd lost his voice!
the MESS crew brought the united states of free love flag which they wanted
to colorize with fluorescent paints.  (we'll bring this out to the sunset
party today for all to see..)

after tracy, whitt of MESS went on to play a very deep house set, which
unfortunately was somewhat interrupted by a visit from two of Albany's
finest.  fortunately, we were on hand immediately to escort these two
gentlemen back out onto to the porch, where we assured them again and
again that there was no alcohol being served inside and that yes, we would
be happy to turn down the music to accomodate a mystery neighbor who
had complained about the noise.  after informing us that they would bust
up the party if called again, they left, but not without writing down
our names and ages.  (huh?)

by then, dawn was nearly upon us.  the house was full, but the majority
of the people there were fast asleep.  then someone volunteered to make
coffee and pancakes for everyone.  since lots of people had a long drive
ahead, breakfast seemed like a good idea.  yum!

all in all, doing this party was psychically refreshing to all concerned..
as usual, it was a collaborative effort among lots of people.  many new
moon regulars plus lots of newcomers came & contributed their efforts &
good attitude.  i hope we will get the chance to have more spoken word
ambient performances like m & ovid have been doing.

thanks so much for making it happen the way it did!  where do you get
all that talent, all that energy?  and where did you learn to dance so
good?  :) :) thank you sean, billie, harlan, gregg & greg, ovid, m,
mark, tracy, whitt, scottie, catherine, paul, seth, jeff, maui, dave
(for the amp & speakers), jacob (on keyboard & for the decks), bonnie,
fox (for you-know-what), devon & everyone else 

lotsa love,

ann

From sfraves-owner  Sun Sep 18 18:30:20 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id SAA16047; Sun, 18 Sep 1994 18:30:20 -0700
Received: from quack.kfu.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id SAA16042; Sun, 18 Sep 1994 18:30:14 -0700
Received: by quack.kfu.com id AA02749
  (5.65c8/IDA-1.4.4 for sfraves list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>); Sun, 18 Sep 1994 18:30:09 -0700
Date: Sun, 18 Sep 1994 18:30:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: Willis Wong <walrus@quack.kfu.com>
Subject: The Yin and Yang of Organic
To: sfraves list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9409181707.B1840-0100000@quack.kfu.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Last night's Organic was good. The recording said it was in a "new
building" with plenty of free parking.  But when I got there I recognized
the place from 2 years ago where they held the "Cosmofunkagrooveathon",in
a roller rink, which was busted before I got in.  The parking lot was full
but there was street space (if that's what they meant).  Big ole line
outside and it was coldddddd. Inside was like a zoo.  People sitting here,
standing there, dancing wherever.  Nice cheasy roller disco ceiling lights.

Sound was not so good coming in and out, soft and loud, but this was 
genuine techno with plenty of breakbeat and lots of bounce.  People were 
wiggin' out at the fast bpms and I was thuroughly enjoying it.  I even 
heard a song with that techno-rave chord progression theme to it... what 
happened to those songs?  I guess people got tired of chords?  

Music stopped completely at 3:30am and somebody said something.  What did
he say?  I dunno.  Music came back on in five minutes and people tried to
get back in to it and sudddenly it's trance-time and whooowheee so much
FOG.  This fog was thick but it was more pleasent than somebody's
Marlboro. Trying to dance and not being able to see my hand in front of my
face was really something.  I felt insecure not knowing where I was or
which way I was facing or who was around me... but there was always the 
beat to keep me going.  This feeling was nice but very stressful at the 
same time and I could only handle it for a bit.

Glow sticks, whistles, slinky's, blow pops, a Dr. Seuss Hat, and of all 
things a Fruit Loops Box serving as a backpack.  This was classic rave.

Ok one thing: the speakers were set up RIGHT in front of the bathrooms
which maybe is not a good place because you have your speaker worshippers
and you have your restroom goers all converging to the same personal space
and it was really quite a traffic jam trying to do either act.  What is up
with that? 

-willis

I really like william orbit a lot...
i have strange cargo 2, and i like 3 better...
I'll buy sc1 as soon as i see it in a cut out bin or something :)

the weird thing for me about his music is that offhand i look at it
as this sort of new agey style music--which is a big turn off
for me...so i have this strange sense that i shouldn't like
his music...but i really really love it...

it's just really nice mellow music that somehow moves something
inside of me when i listen to it :)

go figure :)

-John

> I really like william orbit a lot...
> i have strange cargo 2, and i like 3 better...
> I'll buy sc1 as soon as i see it in a cut out bin or something :)
> 
> the weird thing for me about his music is that offhand i look at it

> his music...but i really really love it...
>

> 

 william orbit is one of my immediate favorite "composers" in that
 while people like R. James, Namlook Etc. play nice stuff their music
 is obviously more "live experimental". I'd say offhand that orbit is
 to techno what alan parsons is to rock. And I'd agree that it has a
 "new agey" feel but that's only because people like T. Dream, Schulze,
 Jarre, Etc. were lumped into a marketing hype category NOT because they
 had anything to do with the NA movement.

 Artists have little control over the "record bins" they find themselves
 sold from - it's just great to be sold ! Another fun pastime is
 to watch the people at Tower in San Mateo try to figure out where to
 file artists. They now have a fairly new "techno" section. Let's see
 AFX is in techno, Willim Orbit III is techno - others are rock. Polygon
 Windows is New Age (at least that's where I finally found it) but SAWII
 is techno. KLF is under rock and so on....

 It's a great sport to watch people struggle with labels  :-)


 Mike ( not sure if I have a label ) Clay

I just wanted to put in mine about Orbit, one of my favorite artists for 4 or 5
years:

In case you all didn't know, he also did stuff as a band called Bass-O-Matic,
whose first album rocks, but whose second album is now out of print, and was
never released domestically.  The Bass-o-matic singles were really cool too, as
was the "Water from a Vine Leaf" single from Orbit by himself with remixes by
Underworld among others.

Also, a while ago he was in a band called Torch Song, with a woman singing, and
I actually found the out of print tape (which is like 5 or 6 years old) at a
close out sale in Berkeley (can't remember the name of the store).  IT was kind
of cheesy (the lyrics), and the music was only pretty good, definitely not up
to his standards nowadays.

His remix of Madonna's song was really cool, and I have yet to hear his other
remixes including Prince and Siouxsie.  Any stuff that anyone else know about
him?

Oh!  I finally saw the video to Water From a Vine Leaf, and thought it was
totally cool.

PS - Sunset was great.  I can never get enough of Papua New Guinea

Subject: Organic and Sunsets

Well I had a great weekend even though Organic started by not treating
people quite right.They didn't open up until after midnight so there
was a long cold period of waiting in line with lots of people trying
to crash the front of the line.  But they let everyone in for the $10
price so... The place was really fun, although something more than the
cheesy 70's roller rink lights would've been nice... well there were
those big strobes, but ... The sound was bad at first.. the amp to their
tweeters kept overheating so the music kept losing intensity and then
come back the go away... eh... When they shut off the sound completely
after a few hours of this, they said that they needed to rewire the amp.
15 or so minutes later it came back on and was nice from there on out.
I really like the trancey stuff after that but then the music became very
basic house like and lost my interest as it slowed down a lot.  Too
slow, in my opinion and so many people then were just laying down and
cuddling :) or resting... sort'f low energy.   But, one really cool thing
was that they were playing videos from Futur on the back wall.  They showed
the laser dancers and had a few shots of the lasers streaming from the
stage and though by no means did this do Futur justice, my friends and
several others and I just sat and watched and grinned and talked about
how much Futur was the shit.  That was good.  They also had some of the
videos of the face that they played on the triangle screen at Futur.
So... everybody was really happy and overall good vibes from the whole
crowd.  Ended up being really fun by early dawn.  Sleep Sleep Sleep...
and head to Sunset.  Sunset is just happiness.  The energy at unset made
up for the mellower energy at Organic.  Danced pretty hard for most of the eveni
ng.
Simon (I think) did a great set.  Lots of Hardfloor, and acid trance goodness
that had my grin from ear to ear.
Had an older couple walking by stop and ask me if this sort of thing
happened a lot... I said yes.. here every Sunday this summer.  They said
that it was great.  *grin*
-john (the guy with a green gumball machine question mark hanging from my neck)


From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 19 13:16:30 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

	id NAA29624; Mon, 19 Sep 1994 13:14:30 -0700
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 1994 13:14:30 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199409192014.NAA29624@netcom12.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Weekend rave report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Weekend Rave report
-------------------

Greetings!!   I finally get to a "Massive" this weekend since all the
traveling around I've been doing.    So I decided to check out Organic,
and see for myself this new space that was hyped over the info line.

The info said it was a half hour from the Bay Bridge,   but unless you
were in a helocopter,  or driving a fast car,    I hardly think anyone
could make it in the indicated time.    Not one mention was given about
what city it was in,   unless the other info lines included that info.
The direction to take on 4 was vague,  but luckily I took the right
direction.    After driving for more than an hour,    I stopped for
directions,   met a few other lost ravers but eventually found it.

The venue was a roller rink,    low cielings,    little or no ventilation,
dispite the smoking ban which nobody paid attention to anyway.    No real
chill zone,  but people just flopped down anywhere there was room.

Chlling out was a real problem,  as I often stayed next to the entrance
blocking things,  until I ran into Jerry,   the promoter.    He finally
realized that allowing me to stand outside,   was better for all concerned.

The music was really pumpin,   mostly housey stuff,  no fast beats,  but
consistant.    About 3:30 just before Simon was to go on,  the music stopped
so they could change a mixer,    but soon started up again.

It was crowded all night,  with perhaps about 75% still there at about
7:30 pm.

Although the party got started late (probably to give more setup time
after the rink closed),   people were still getting in for $10.    For
the price,  it was worth it.    

Almost immediatly,  peopole were asking me where I've been for the last
month and a half,   but it was great to touch base with some old friends.

There were a few SFRavers there,   but due to the "Out of the way" location,
there wasn't as many as there could have been.

The music finally stopped at about 8 am,   where Mark Ferina played some
slow stuff to finally close things off.

After the rave,  I left and headed back to Mill Valley for a much needed
shower,   but on the way home,   decided to visit the jacuzzi at one of
the 24 hour Nautilus health clubs instead.    Hmmm!  Gonna have to do
this more often  :-)

After a much relaxing plunge into the warm water,   I headed home,  tried
to chill,   but couldn't sleep, so headed out to Sunset.

As I arrived,  they were just setting up,   so I chilled around,  did some
meditation,   until the music started.

As usual,  Sunset started off with the slow beats,   but picked up soon
after that until the generator finallly conked out.   Thanx to an individual
who happened to have a spare,   we were off and running again and the 
momentum and vibe finally picked up.

Soon,  several hundred people were milling around,  dancing,  or just
schmoozing around.    

Dispite the much cooler weather,   lots of people showed up,  but not as many
as last week,   and the music played on until shortly after 10 pm.   
Probably in part due to some street gig in San Jose.

So,  once again,  Sunset lived up to it's expectation as one of the best
daytime gigs,    and I highly recommend those to come down and check it
out next Sunday.

CC


From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 19 13:19:23 1994

Thanks to the sunset gang for yet another wonderful party!! I have been 
happy to make Sunset a weekly ritual.  Too bad the fog didn't allow us to 
climb  to the top of the hill and watch the sun disappear.  I LOVE that 
change of energy as people run down to dance just afte. Galen 
continues to blow me away everytime - set me deep in a trance. Cathy and 
I always meet more incredible people there each sunday, (Hi to the Mother 
Earth crew).  Is Sunset moving soon?  Milton thought he heard that it 
was, but I hoped somone from Sunset might confirm this.    

Bye for now, Peace and Love,
Andrew


From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 19 14:37:17 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id OAA08334; Mon, 19 Sep 1994 14:37:17 -0700
Received: from bethe.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id OAA08329; Mon, 19 Sep 1994 14:37:14 -0700
Received: by bethe.ucdavis.edu (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA22906; Mon, 19 Sep 94 14:37:11 PDT
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 94 14:37:11 PDT
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Message-Id: <9409192137.AA22906@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: LA report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Millenium was a big movie scene extravaganza in Los Angelos 
this weekend.  Calling it a Party would be too generous.

Driving up freeway 110 straight into Downtown was spectacular.
Giant concrete freeway cathedrals.  Off the freeway we immediately
started to see police blockades and rows of trucks on the side
blocks.  

We whizzed by Flower St in Awe.  All we glimpsed were giant
screens, blazing lights, throngs of people, and a whirlwind
of confetti filling the sky.

Following directions for the free parking shuttled us past
a fancy hotel that opened up right into the party.  This
little drive-by was around midnight.  It was a mob scene.

We parked out on the street and circled the 5x3 city block 
Hollywood encampment.  There was an extremely high stress
level outside.  Scalpers were aggressive and pissed-off
groups of people (didn't get in?) were milling about bitching 
and whining.  Entering at the far end we were greeted with
a 100+ porta potties, the free food and drink area, the free 
water area, and then the main street corner.

There were speakers everywhere, brilliant film lights, huge fans blowing
confetti into the air, two Football Stadium sized tv screens, a stage,
balloons, and searchlights all surrounded by skyscrapers with a nearly
full moon thrown in on top.  The main set decorations were Tanks and 
Army Guys standing around in the middle of the party.

25,000 people and maybe a 100 trying to dance.  These are difficult
odds.  DeeLite was either plagued with technical problems or the filming
demanded that they play a song and then stop for 5 minutes.  Their whole
set was disjoint and broken up like that.  There were constant pauses in
the music.  Interruptions by the movie people were way more annoying 
than I thought - "Ok people, let's do a countdown!"   Note that these
countdowns were really weak, it'll be interesting to see the post-production
results.

Before and after DeeLite were long silent breaks or timid dj'd interludes.
Random horribly distorted instructions to sound or lighting people were just
blasted out over the djs.  It was an Allstar Dj Lineup.  They each put
in a lackluster, broken up, 1/2 hour set.  No one was into anything except
standing around and gawking at themselves on the tv screen or people
watching.  It was a very mixed crowd.  Most similar in feel to the
State Fair or maybe an Amusement Park - without the happy kids!  Some
people were very beautiful.  A decent contingent of decorative model types
and club kids (USA twins were a personal favorite).  Others were 
desparately draining their "love phasors" into the fray.  The Alamo.

Aphex Twin came on after lengthy pleas for waving our hands in the air.
He at least managed to get the movie people to shut up during his set.
It wasn't that long but it was good.  I moved way back away from the
stage near a big screen and a tank.  This spot had a nice breeze, some
room and the best sound in the party (lots of places got muffled by
people or objects).  His set ended and then Doc Martin started to DJ.
I know this because someone kept saying it OVER and OVER and OVER in
an attempt to "Come on LA let's show some Respect."  I don't know if
these extended motivational shout-outs are normal for LA or exclusive
to this hopeless affair. 

Then the Clincher.  It just fucking ended at around 3:30.  The tickets
said "9:00 to Dawn".  Displaced party goers who were not ready to 
leave wound up sitting in big groups in the street throwing confetti
all over themselves.  These were the friendliest moments of the party.
Unfortunately, there was a HEAVY POLICE PRESENCE.  They were mostly
cool but there were So Many standing around watching.  They seemed
to become more noticeable after the music stopped and people were still
trying to lounge about.  Chalk that one up to my fear of cops.  I just
wasn't comfortable.  It was Over.  We left.

We raced back to SF (actually it was nice to get away, the trip was 
pleasant) and made it home for Sunset.  I was SO HAPPY to come home
and dance.  I had all this unused energy.  We didn't arrive til after 
dark.  When we first saw about 20 people grooving on the hill, my
friend commented "I already see more dancing than last night"
The last dj played a very good set.

I kept hoping for some small contingent of the Millenium people to 
get together. I know they were there - it was just hard for things
to gel under the circumstances.

Dave

I as at Millenium too and I thought I would add to David's comments since
he and I had different times, so it seems. :)

> 25,000 people and maybe a 100 trying to dance.  These are difficult
> odds.  DeeLite was either plagued with technical problems or the filming
> demanded that they play a song and then stop for 5 minutes.  Their whole
> set was disjoint and broken up like that.  There were constant pauses in
> the music.  Interruptions by the movie people were way more annoying 
> than I thought - "Ok people, let's do a countdown!"   Note that these
> countdowns were really weak, it'll be interesting to see the post-production
> results.

There were only 10,000 or so people there and I don't know where you were
for most of the evening, David, but the area in which we spent most of our
time (to the left of the stage and down some) was filled with loads of
happy dancing people - just ask Lee and Rox. :)

I don't think Deee-lite was being interrupted by the filming. Their set 
as disjoint but I think that was intentional. The sound was lousy for them
from where I was standing but wasn't that bad at other points in the evening.

> Before and after DeeLite were long silent breaks or timid dj'd interludes.
> Random horribly distorted instructions to sound or lighting people were just
> blasted out over the djs.  It was an Allstar Dj Lineup.  They each put
> in a lackluster, broken up, 1/2 hour set.  

Jason Bentley's set was lacklustre and broken up. Doc Martin's set was 
refreshingly different for Doc and quite nice. Aphex's set was incredibly
wonderful, sick acid house that really surprised me, coming from him. Sadly,
he only played for about 30 minutes.

> Then the Clincher.  It just fucking ended at around 3:30.  The tickets
> said "9:00 to Dawn".  Displaced party goers who were not ready to 
> leave wound up sitting in big groups in the street throwing confetti
> all over themselves.  These were the friendliest moments of the party.
> Unfortunately, there was a HEAVY POLICE PRESENCE.  They were mostly
> cool but there were So Many standing around watching.  They seemed
> to become more noticeable after the music stopped and people were still
> trying to lounge about.  Chalk that one up to my fear of cops.  I just
> wasn't comfortable.  It was Over.  We left.

The LA Times said it was shut down due to five Ecstacy overdoses though
what I heard on the night was that the fire marshall shut it down due to
excessive noise complaints. I don't believe the promoters had the intention
of shutting it down early. In fact, I spoke with Philip Blaine, the promoter,
last week and he had mentioned that the film commission was concerned that
they wouldn't be able to keep people there long enough to do all their
filming, like keeping people there well into dawn.

> I kept hoping for some small contingent of the Millenium people to 
> get together. I know they were there - it was just hard for things
> to gel under the circumstances.
> 

Dave, I'm sorry you couldn't meet up with the socal ravers because we were
there going strong!

Hug Your Waistline to the Bassline............................................

Tamara Palmer * trance@netcom.com * izzyzi5@mvs.oac.ucla.edu * 

.........................................................Women Respond to Bass

From: deaks@netcom.com (Ernie Deakyne)
Message-Id: <199409192125.OAA02703@netcom11.netcom.com>
Subject: Cloud Factory/Big Sur :)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 1994 14:25:32 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2191      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

  It's been a while since I've posted anything, been too busy with school 
and adjusting to city life, but here's a little weekend report :)

  Drove down to Monterey with my two friends and got there around 11pm.  
We drove around a bunch of artichoke fields looking for the site.  After 
an hour of this we called the voice mail and discovered I wrote down the 
wrong directions..  We finally get to the spot and Scott (drenalin) and 
crew were still setting up.  I was really impressed with the site my 
friends found, it's in a little valley and has an incredible view of the 
Moss Landing power plant. (who needs a generator??)  After some sound 
problems, we got the music going around 1am and about 80 people showed up 
from Santa Cruz and Monterey (and some friends from San Jo!) 
  Shilo spun some really nice groovy acid/trance for about an hour and 
then Scott came up to me and said it was my turn to spin.  Well, I wasn't 
exactly ready ;)  and then after the first few mixes I realized the 
monitors were WAY too far away, making beat matching a bitch!  Once the 
monitors were fixed I decided to just thrash as many people as I could, 
so I brought it up to 145 and kept it there for an hour ;)  Scott went on 
after me, it was his first time spinning at one of HIS parties!  

  We finally shut down around 7:30 and had a wonderful breakfast in 
Monterey, got some sleep, then drove to Big Sur!

  We had reserved two group camp sites at Big Sur  Pfiefer State Park.. 
The redwoods were amazing, you could easily have 500+ people here for a 
full moon or anything else you wanted to throw..  But we kept it small 
with only about 30 or 40 close friends showing up.  We also kept it 
ambient.. We had 3 T-tables, echo/reverb fx and a sampler and some realy 
bizzare feedback effects which sounded just like a 303.  Tim McKnew and 
myself played strange stuff for about 2 or 3 hours until most people had 
decided to get some sleep.  I haven't heard it yet, but we got most of 
the night on tape..  We have a growing archive of Cloud Factory sets and 
we may someday get them produced and available to the general public of 
ravers out there ;)

Peace out...

-Ernie 'Deaks'

after weeks of email saying that there was no way
that aphex was going to show up,
resonate said:

Okay- now for the real question- was it REALLY aphex twin playing?
was Richard James actually *THERE?* Did he play live or just spin music?

Well i have to admit it.  Resonate was right. Aphex was nowhere to be
seen in LA last saturday night.

They DID get this guy who looked a HELL of a lot like him,
(friends who were down in the lobby of the Bonaventure,
at around 4:30 saw him wandering around)
to go up on stage and play records and twiddle knobs 
with this incredible Acid House set that included songs like
Phuture (?) and Eon's The Spice, and made me damn well giddy.
(While This Is Acid was playing, i was forced to say
"Yes, This IS Acid." cuz it damn well was.)

At the end, there was there wonderful beautiful mindfucking
noise eminating from the speakers (causing a friend to say
"Do you remember that ripping sound in the middle of that?
Man... someone just shouldnt be able to do that to me"), 
and that sounded a hell of a lot like Aphex, but that was 
probably just a coincedence.

 ,
dana

"the EPA loves saying how many thousands of people get cancer
from saccharin, but never mention how many thousands get it
from cauliflower"

Tamara says,

>(to the left of the stage and down some) was filled with loads of
>happy dancing people - just ask Lee and Rox. :)

I know there were people into the party.  From my point of view,
they were really spread out among tons of people who were not so
enthusiastic. Bored, frowning, tired spectators were everywhere.

I expected a mix of people from a huge party promoted in lots of 
places.  However, I was planning to stay until "dawn" and hoped the 
party would pull together and go off when the crowd thinned out.	
In fact, this is exactly what I heard from folks arriving at the
same time I did.  People definitely believed it was going to
be "djs all night long - after the bands".

With the incredible amount of money and effort going into that
party and all the police and emergency crews who were there, I 
don't think noise complaints shut it down.  Seems like they
would have had the permits to do it right.

I believe the overdose shutdown story.  I'm also inclined to believe that
that they got what film they needed and didn't argue too much after that.
So they got 5 overdoses - they would expect more after 3:30 ... ??	
Or shutting down would somehow help this?
I don't get it.

I don't mean to completely slam the event  
It was fun for what it was

Dave

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2739      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Here's my take on Millineum.

Drove up on Friday night and stayed with my brother in Agoura Hills.
It was to be his first rave. We went to Venice Beach Saturday after
scoping out the location and seeing the Jumbotron screens alongside
5th Street.

We got to the parking area around 8:50 and started walking towards
the site. We ended up on the upper-level roads and took an elevator
down to the street level. This was right across from the big hotel
where they were dumping confetti. When we got to street level, the
security crew told us to go towards the entrance to get in. When
we got to the area of the porta-potties, we noticed that they were
patting down the incoming people. We asked someone if they were
tearing tickets or stamping hands. She said no, and we turned around
to go to the action.

At that time of the evening, the filming was doing rehearsal and
security was trying to keep all of the ravers in one spot. I thought
that the party was going to start at 9, but in actuality, it started
around 10:30. The countdown scenes were weak. The guy hanging off
of the top of the hotel was interesting. The confetti was neat. Too
bad the music sucked. Well, the presentation of the music sucked
anyway. I explained to my brother that this wasn't a rave, but it
was a "rave-like" event. The music was disjoint and had very annoying
silent spaces. Most of the people were milling around and not dancing.
 Dee-lite had a very muddled sound and it seemed like they couldn't
hold a groove. Dancing was at times difficult because of the crowd.
(I was in my colorful spiral tye-die and a bike cap). I continually wandered
throughout the crowd, stopping in the slightly open areas and dancing.
Sometimes the crowd around me would join in. The mad-hatters were dancing
pretty well and at times, the area in front of the Jumbotron was dancing.

There was no velcro wall or acro-bungie or human gyroscope and no
Ambient Garden. 

The props were interesting. My brother asked the guys in the tanks
if they were props or what. They said yes. I also found it interesting
that the cop cars were getting vandalized. These too were props.
The area next to coffee shop seemed to have the most consistent dance
area.

I was quite disappointed when the music stopped. I thought that it
was going to continue 'till dawn. When the filiming stopped, though,
so did the music. Bummer. The only piece about the party on the news
the next evening was that it was closed down because of Ecstasy
overdoses. They showed a little bit of dancing and then had some
doctor spreading his ideas of the evils of ecstasy. That was it.

It was definitely an interesting experience. My brother got hyped
about raves and may start looking into the LA scene.

-Mike
