From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 19 19:09:39 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id TAA14892; Mon, 19 Sep 1994 19:09:39 -0700
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (Smail3.1.28.1 #12)
	id m0qmueE-0003VvC; Mon, 19 Sep 94 19:09 PDT
Message-Id: <m0qmueE-0003VvC@taz.hyperreal.com>
From: laura@taz.hyperreal.com (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 1994 19:09:33 PST
In-Reply-To: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
       "LA report" (Sep 19,  2:37pm)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.1.1 5/02/90)
To: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves), sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: LA report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I had a great time at Millenium.  The first DJ I heard (about 10 PM
I guess) was spinning honest to god trance and acid trance.  My cups 
of tea.  Not many people were dancing except right up by the speakers, 
so I gladly jumped in with about 75 young LA guys waving and bouncing
to the 140 bpm+ beats.  That didn't last too long, the next DJ came
on and things got much slower and with more organs and horns, so I
wandered around to just soak things up.

There were all kinds of people there:  movie people, LAPD (and they
all seemed to be in friendly moods, I didn't get a bad feeling from
them at all), people who looked like they just sort of wandered in,
club kids in full regalia, and ravers of many ages and fashion senses.
People were friendly to me -- no pushing or shoving, people smiled and
said excuse me if they had to get by, complete strangers gave me 
blow pops and when Susie said to a random person "hey, where did you
get that hat?" he just gave it to her.  

Some of the music really annoyed me, but I liked the first few bits of
Doc Martin's set (it had 303's wailing away in it) and of course I
liked the stuff that the Aphex Twin was spinning.  

Whoever did the sound for Dee-Lite should be barred from doing sound
ever again.  The sound during their live performance was unbearble.  
Things were much better for the DJ's spinning vinyl.

Off to the left of the stage was a sort of valley studded with Palm
Trees.  It was MUCH darker there than anywhere else, and there were 
hundreds of people dancing like crazy and smiling and bopping around.
I ran into several people I knew, which was nice -- It was very
cool bumping into Rox and spending a good amount of time talking to
her.

The movie's set (New Year's Even 1999 amid tanks in Desert camoflage)
wasn't condusive to a good rave per se, but hey, I knew what I was
getting into when I heard it was a James Cameron film.  Like, what 
do you expect from the guy who brought us _Terminator_?  Basically
the bulk of the screaming production assistants was in the highly
lit area at the corner of 4th and Flower, at the opposite end of 
the square from the stage.  "Oh my god I'm not getting enough
confetti over here?  What should I do?"

So anyway, I thought it was fun and I'm glad I went.  Everyone's 
perceptions are different, and I just wanted you all to know that I
didn't think it was one bit as bad as Dave Alves described it.  But
then, I'm an East Coast Hardcore Girl (TM) :-) so maybe I'm used
to a more apocalyptic take on raving.  As I said on alt.rave, the
only bad thing in my opinion was that the Fire Marshal (I'm told)
stopped the party at 3:30 am because some idiots were doing back
flips off some equipment AFTER the promoter had gotten on the PA and
said that if people didn't stop doing dangerous stuff like that the
Fire Marshal would shut the party down.  Some people are just so
clueless and/or selfish.

Laura

I'm not a cheeseball (I'm a vegan and am what I eat). Maybe a wheat
gluten puff.
 
However I'm simply not a peace and love raver.
 
I remember 11 years ago when all the rage was to make movies about punk
rock and many "filmed" punk concerts happened and it was the SAME thing
that happened in LA at Millenium:
bad music, bad vibes, bad drugs, bad people, and bad press.
 
No solid scene needs *any* hype from the multi-death-corporate Hollywood
film industry. The media is a parasite on significant pop and underground
culture- it feeds itself and kills the host.
 
Fortunately- the one thing that dance music has going for it is that often
our favorite stuff has no vocals- and this will keep it out of the top 40
for a long time- or at least until MCA convinces everyone to buy it.

point and subtly contradicted yourself: revelling in someone getting 
screwed is a bit like Sony having a party if MCA were to bite the 
dust.  

	Sami

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: 	Mon, 19 Sep 1994 20:55:57 -0700
From: Todd_Spaulding@mockingbird.globalvillag.com
Subject: HARMONY! @ Santa Cruz

Date	9/19/94
Subject	HARMONY! @ Santa Cruz
>From	Todd Spaulding
To	Awesome Ravers

HARMONY! @ Santa Cruz


    ___ We'd love to see you all at  Harmony  this Friday the 23rd! ___    ;) 

It's going to go off at a beautiful, new outdoor location north of Santa Cruz that
has never been used!  This is the special Santa Cruz location that we wanted to use
for the Harmony this last August 26th, but ended up locating at a beautiful spot in
the city.  (It was a peninsula on the water overlooking the San Francisco bay, the
city lights practically in our reach just beyond the bay on the other side.)  

Our August Harmony turned out to be very successful, and quite a big turnout
considering our relatively careful and conservative flyering and promoting.  This
time we've printed only a couple hundred flyers, and we are relying more on our
friends in the underground to support the scene and to spread the good word!

                  This is Greg's Birthday Party!  (Yay!!)
       A great big Happy Birthday to Greg (of Harmony Productions) 
              and to everyone else in the world on this day! 

Friday, September 23rd - Harmony
        DJ Deaks    Taylor    Tim    Tim McKnew    Donut
        A godly outdoor location about 15 minutes North of Santa Cruz.
        408.486.9591  408.488.9954

We are doing everything we can to make this party free.  IF we end up charging, it
will be very cheap (less than $5), and only to break even.  

        We have _ZERO_ interest in making any money!

        -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
There is plenty of room for tents, and be sure to bring lots of warm clothes,
blankets, stuffed animals, candy, toys, water, love, and everything else that is
good to share with others.
        -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Keep the Joy...
Keep the Love...
Keep the Faith...
Keep the Family...
Keep an Open Conciousness, and Dance Your Ass Off!

Most of all, Respect Your Mother Earth!  (We actually mean it though!)

Love and Hugs,
Harmony
Support the Underground!

Cloud Factory definately was a good time.  DJ Deaks, Shiloh, and all the other DJ's
did a wonderful job, and I left the next morning feeling like I had a very good
night.

after  Harmony  this Friday the 23rd in Santa Cruz?

seemed to be a few hours... sitting up.

state prevented me, somehow.  Usually that's not supposed to be a problem!  ;)

On Mon, 19 Sep 1994, David Alves wrote:

> I believe the overdose shutdown story.  I'm also inclined to believe that
> that they got what film they needed and didn't argue too much after that.
> So they got 5 overdoses - they would expect more after 3:30 ... ??	

	I hate to harp on this subject, well, maybe I don't hate harping 
on it, but I do not like always coming back to it. I would like to hear 
what they called this E overdoses, were they actually people passing out 
and needing a shot of Narcaine <spelling is worng, but the name of the 
anti-narotic is pretty close> to keep them from dying? Was this actually 
e, or was it cut with something?
	You see, I am quite sick of hearing that every rave or rave like 
gathering is a horrible drug infested event, just look at all these 
overdoses! I further find it unresponsible for the media to spread half 
truths about a subject very few people have any direct experience with, 
any viewpoint from to make a judgement for themselves (although one can 
argue that such a thing does not exist, I still would like to give people 
a less ditorted view, but then is my view less distorted?). 
	The way things tend to be played up, the word overdose can be 
misleading. A medical overdose on e consists of jaw-crenching and 
eye-twitching at the one to two hour mark, so 5 overdoses can be 
expected. But this is not the image that is conjured in the minds of 
people who can write letters to their mayor when a bunch of these people 
bring their loud music in their neighborhood and try to tempt their 
children into possibly overdosing themselves. Furthermore, who would 
want to have to think about people overdosing, such a scary thing... I do 
think people have been led to read a lot more into these what can be 
'accurately' reported (one might question which should allowed to be 
labeled as accurate though, the actual reporting, or the imagery which 
the media wishes to conjure in its readers eyes).
	I have trouble deciding whether to mad at people for taking the 
media's reporting at face value. I think a sense of fear of the unknown, 
a kinda of hopeless, lost-ness can deter a lot of people from looking at 
some situations for themselves when someone else expresses disgust or 
outrage toward an activity. Granted I have read a lot of Kesey, but I 
like to credit myself with seeing this before I read Sometimes a Great 
Notion... But this is degenerating into babble to keep me from writing an 
essay I have to write, I how there is something of intelligence in here...

dave

An unsolicited plug for this event...I went to the last Harmony and found 
it to be exactly what a party should be: lots of love, peace and positive 
energy; excellent music; smallish but connected crowd; outdoors in a 
beautiful setting; low admission price; promoters who were putting it on 
for love not money; a real sense of community; etc. etc.  Jason, if you're 
reading this, thanks again for reaffirming my faith in the scene. 

Kathryn

Subject: Galen at bigger parties?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Date	9/20/94
Subject	Galen at bigger parties?
>From	Todd Spaulding
To	Awesome Ravers

Galen at bigger parties?
Phuture says:
> SUNSET SUNSET SUNSET SUNSET!!!! This party is *SO* GOOD!  Galen's set
> just made my weekend.  Why doesn't he play any of the 'bigger' parties?

I know very little of Galen's history, but I would imagine that if he doesn't spin
at bigger parties, there is a reason.  If I were Galen, my theory would be that if I
were really supporting the underground, I would not be supporting the "bigger
parties" because that would be contradictory to my purpose.  Bigger, more
commercialized parties are exactly what put a bad name to all the tried and true,
sincere underground parties.  The very parties that try NOT to make money.

Until recently, Sunset WAS pretty much an underground thing.  Now that everyone and
their cousin knows about Sunset (from pretty much all around the bay area), it's
just not the same anymore.  It's still WONDERFUL, yet just not the same as the days
when there were 20-30 people out there dancing; instead, 200-300+ people show up
now.  

Don't get me wrong, the energy is still and always will remain with me as TRULY
AMAZING at Sunset parties, but the fact of the matter is, just too many people have
begun to find out about it.  No wonder Sunset will probaly live on at the Berkeley
Marina for only a few more weeks.  

Sunset was undoubtedly a scene that will remain in my memory forever, it was fun
while it lasted, and there is always another time and place for everything.

I luv Sunset!!
Love and Harmony,
Todd

--------------------------------------
Date: 9/19/94 6:59 PM
To: Todd Spaulding
From: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Yin and Yang, Up and Down, Back and Forth  - but overall a fun party.  The
later early morning tracks were great, I just wish the DJ had switched to
that earlier.  I think the low energy level in the earlier morning was due to
too much unfunky hard house. Faster, acidic stuff would have been better or
slower, funky workouts.  Tony spun a really nice set earlier in the evening.
 I always forget how much I like him but I've been hearing him spin more
often in the past couple months and really enjoying it. SUNSET SUNSET SUNSET
SUNSET!!!! This party is *SO* GOOD!  Galen's set just made my weekend.  Why
doesn't he play any of the 'bigger' parties?

phuture

I never really understood why security guards bust anyone anyway.  Assumedly
they are hired by the promoter to prevent fights and such and the promoter
can tell them to do whatever he/she wants them to do.  Or do these
rent-a-cops actually think they are a distant part of the police department?
Anyway, open drug use is different than open drug dealing.  To quote Snoop on
MTV's Straight Dope, if you're gonna do it, do it in a business-like manner.
 Parties are a comfortable, friendly enviroment and its easy to forget that
you may be breaking laws that some folks take VERY seriously and that there
is massive pressure from a brainwashed public to enforce.  I do beleive that
communally breaking unjust laws is important though :-)  Martin Luther King
said that morally, you HAVE to break unjust laws.

phuture

Todd Spaulding says,

>Until recently, Sunset WAS pretty much an underground thing.  
>WONDERFUL, yet just not the same as the days
>when there were 20-30 people out there dancing;
>instead, 200-300+ people show up now.


This really seems like nit-picking to me.

I think the fact that the party has changed makes it
a better party.  The Freedom of the people to make the
party and the Thrill of watching it change is what it
is All about.

It wouldn't *be* Sunset without the first small 
parties And these later big parties.  Sunset is. 
Let it grow.  Enjoy it. 

It has not gotten to a size where the People have lost
their creative ability to Contribute.  It is a laboratory
and a studio and a kitchen.  It is a place where everyone 
can do their part to Make It Beautiful.

Even with 300 people you can still Feel what you put in
come right Back to Ya.  That is underground.  Not numbers.

And, of course, it doesn't hurt to have Galen transport
the whole damn meadow onto another planet like this Sunday ...

Love ya,
Dave

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep 20 20:32:46 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

Received: from mail.crl.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id UAA10439; Tue, 20 Sep 1994 20:32:41 -0700

Received: by crl3.crl.com id AA11630
  (5.65c/IDA-1.5 for sfraves@hyperreal.com); Tue, 20 Sep 1994 20:31:14 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ptiger@crl.com (Purple Tiger)
Subject: Purple Raving
Date: Tue, 20 Sep 1994 19:31:12 -0400
Organization: Purple Tiger Sophistems
Reply-To: ptiger@crl.com
Message-Id: <03tVkm4EmInS071yn@crl.com>
Lines: 64
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I had a very good weekend all in all.

Went to Crash Worship on Friday at the Berkeley Square and was sorely
disappointed.  Instead of feeling the overwhelming since of excitement and
tribal bonding overdubbed with industrial sound, I got pushed around in an
unemotional pit and got covered with water, oil and a 1/2 lbs of sugar.  It
went from fun to interesting to pure torture in a little under 15 minutes.
Now, to be honest, this was my first Crash Worship experience and my friends
all said it was probably the worst performance they ever did.  They blamed it
on the venue and the perponderence of inhibited UC students.  Sigh.

I guess I can't expect it to be Burning Man can I?

I did the Organic thing like a lot of sfravers did.  I too experienced that
sense of "wait, I must have missed the exit" when the 30 minutes from the
bridge elapsed.  I'm stubburn though, so I kept going.  Not so my friend who
gave up when he reached the 680 junction.  The 5:30 - 6am set was my fav, but
I was too tired to dance.  Chocolate covered expresso beans can only carry me
so far in the night.

While waiting in the Organic line for an hour, I got to witness a teenager on
4 hits of acid.  According to his friends, it was his first time.  Some
friends, I thought, who let him down 4 hits.  Anyway, this poor guy reached a
state in his trip where reality ceased to exist, and he fell flat on his face.
The Pain brought him back long enough so he could stand up again.  You could
see the smile on his face when he realized he was still in the parking lot,
still on planet earth.  Then you could see reality slipping away one more time
and he fell again, only this time straight back into the concrete.  His head
hit the ground with a very loud melon thud.  I'm sure he got a concussion from
it.  Finally, his friends who were probably just as high picked him up and
took him back to the car.  I shudder to think what the rest of his night was
like.

The moral:  If your going to take acid for the first time, stick to a hit or
maybed two.  For gods sake, don't take 4 hits at a rave in pittsberg.  It's
stupid and sad.  Quite honestly, I think more than one hit at a rave is a bit
overkill.  Save the heavier doses for a place with lots of comfy pillows,
toys, and good music.

At Organic, I met Milton sans the E-bee.  He had Rogaine the Frog with him
instead.  Milton has the right idea.  Too many people are afraid to play in
public anymore.  It nice to see other people who aren't afraid to look silly
in order to have some fun.

Sunday I went to the incredible sunset rave with my purple beanbag.  I got
there early enough to hear the blue haired dj (what's his name?) spin some
really sweet ambient (dub?) tracks.  The sun was still warm then folks, and
the kites were beautiful.  It was well worth the effort of waking up so early
in the morning (noon) to get there.

I got to meet, briefly, phuture.  Its nice to tie a name to a face.

Another happy note, I got a very nice CD, "One A.D."  Very yummy ambient.
I like it as much as the United States of Ambient cd.

Finally, one of my friends is doing a showing of her photos taken at Burning
Man.  She took a lot of "risky" shots with color and IR film, and many of them
turned out great.  The show opens on Thrusday, let me know if you want more
details.

Ciao,

Purple Tiger

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is now basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules.

 It's every Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I shifted the lunch meeting time a 
bit -  I hope to see more of you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

I think i could just be overreacting, cuz im really sick of
people in SF saying shit about LA when they are never even here.
("people in SF" obviously equals SOME people in SF, not all of them)

i dunno, its just that the amount of ego masturbation 
going on from someone not even at the party is just ridiculous

>I'm still waiting for someone who has *seen* him play before to tell me
>it was him. 

Look, it wasn't him. It was some Richard Barnes guy. The LA Times said so.

I have seen Aphex at an event he was supposed to play live at.
I was in the room while he rehearsed and i just saw a mess of
equipment with this figure moving around in the middle of it.

I also passed him on the way to dinner.

If you were there and heard the incredible "mind-crunching"(tm)
shit he was playing, there would be no question.

>I'm glad to hear that Millenium was exactly what I thought it would be-
>a hollywood scam.

And i'm sad you give more of a damn about making sure you can gloat
than having 10,000 people have a good time.

Although it's kinda funny, but from the standpoint of most everyone
i went with, i dont think the term "hollywood scam" would be
what pops into their mind

(and since most of the people i went with are the 
'elitist punk rock' types who are the first to dump
any band that looks at a major label, i think they
would just as quickly dump a rave that was too hollywood)

>However I'm simply not a peace and love raver.

i really dont care about the P, L, or U, but the R (Respect)
is something i place a lot of value on

create arguements and conflicts, dont love,
but have enough respect not to blatently lie

>I remember 11 years ago when all the rage was to make movies about punk
>rock and many "filmed" punk concerts happened and it was the SAME thing
>that happened in LA at Millenium:
>bad music, bad vibes, bad drugs, bad people, and bad press.
 
well there was some of all of this, there was also
GREAT music, GREAT vibes, GREAT drugs, GREAT people, and good press
i didnt have to look very hard for any of them,
but maybe i was just in the right spot

>No solid scene needs *any* hype from the multi-death-corporate Hollywood
>film industry. The media is a parasite on significant pop and underground
>culture- it feeds itself and kills the host.
 
Amen.

but i dont think anyone wanted hype from Millenium, 
people just wanted a fun time on a big scale budget

>Fortunately- the one thing that dance music has going for it is that often
>our favorite stuff has no vocals- and this will keep it out of the top 40
>for a long time- or at least until MCA convinces everyone to buy it.

definitely. although it was kinda funny cuz there was Farsi 
(or psuedo-farsi) on all the things, and no English...
so i guess they dont think Sony is going to take over the world,
some Middle Eastern oil barron will


i'll probably shut up about this soon, but its really hard, cuz well,
you know it not like people on the SoCal list go bitch about
the events in SF that they went to that sucked,

i could go off about how EVERY full moon i've been to has been busted
and for a year or two EVERY event i went to was busted
but, i listen to people in SF and know that things arent like that
so im not about to keep bitching about them,
nor spread rumours around here about the scene up there
from my limited experience

 ,
dana

"the EPA loves saying how many thousands of people get cancer
from saccharin, but never mention how many thousands get it
from cauliflower"

Subject: no really, enough of this LA crap :)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves@hyperreal.com)

I swear, this is my last post on the subject,
(if i have anything else to say, i'll have someone forward it :) :)

i probably would have even given up on this, but 
there was some mention of the "real facts" and well..
i dunno...
maybe i've just fucked with my brain/body too much
but considering its also my academic major's strongest viewpoint,
probably not, anyhow
no such thing as "real facts" just people's perceptions..
(especially since a fact was that "millenium rocked")

so here's a bunch of random responses to people's comments
with their comments removed so you lose context :)

I really have to say that confetti en masse dropped from a
35 story building is one of the most incredible things/effects
that i have seen in a long time, 

Although it would probably be good to make sure that it is made
out of something that will degrade quickly, cuz there was confetti
all over the roof and in the pool INSIDE the bonaventure

------
Just to make the story as clear as i know it on this:

Aphex was reported as spinning and twiddling knobs,
but even at the mental state i was in, all the songs
sounded pretty much like i thought they should,
so im assuming the only knob twiddling was on the last incredible
noise track that he played

----------
i pretty much think they were done filming
(probably didnt get what they wanted either)
so they were all cranky and wanted to go home

but it pretty much seems to have been the fire marshall, 
not the promoters or the film crew
and i highly doubt it was for noise complaints,

i was the one rambling about people doing back flips off of transformers
into a crowd of people (who were being supportive and planning on
catching the person, it didnt seem like swimming or stage diving
where the participants on the ground arent always willing)

there was also a rad dance show on top of a bus stop
with a guy in drag doing psuedo-ballet
next to a very fluid more agile dancer :)

both of those things caused the fire marshall to Threaten to
shut it down, (as was announced over the PA)

and im sure similar activities occurred after that announcement,
but like 10 or 20 minutes before it got shut down
i noticed a bunch of EMT's walking through the crowd
so  the overdose story seems to be accurate for once

(that the OD's got it shut down, not how many there were
or what they were on)

----

finally, i really think it needs  to be said that i think
the fact that 10,000 people were in that small of a space
and there was seemingly no violence, is quite impressive

if there was a large supply of alcohol, there would have been 
plenty of fights and related injuries, but people seem to be ignoring this

(although, the cops said they were pleased with the crowd
and many people commented on how friendly the cops were...
some told my friends they should sneak into the hotel
and use the bathrooms there when they were asked where a bathroom was.
but same friends said they actualyl had some cool convo's with a few 
of the different officers...

gee. Cops are friendly and people are friendly back,
what a fucking amazing concept :)

anyhow.. enough of this LA shit...
back to your regularly scheduled SF postings

screwed up the addres to it got bounced back to me. Better late than 
never i guess.

O.K. I don't know where all of you were but obviously you wern't in the 
right area. I and my two friends were off to the left of the stage right 
were the pillers of the building meet all night well actually i went and 
walked around about every hour just to meet other people but always 
returned to that spot and all i have to say is besides the sound cutting 
out and the movie trying to get a good count down that they could use which 
went hand in hand it was the shit!!!!! all the people around us were 
dancing hard and all night hell most of us didn't even notice that the 
music cut out everyone we met were so friendly and nice and we met alot 
of people no negative vibes at alllllll....I really wish we would have 
met some of you there because if you would have seen how much fun we and 
all the others around us were you would have been happy to. one thing 
though james or john (i don't know which) cameron should have thought 
alittle more about how to deal with a bunch of people who are very high
and dancing to the groove of the beat. think about it they are not actors 
they are not getting paid they do not say how high when you tell them to 
jump. and if you want them to jump and scream when they are dancing you 
sure as hell DO NOT TURN OFF THE MUSIC!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! get a clue if they 
wanted a great count down they should have keep the music loud and had 
lady miss kier come out and do the count down the croud would have went 
crazy.
well thats all.Talizman

For those of you party people who were at Millenium...

I'm just curious... I didn't get to go to Millenium, but I saw DJ Orlando's
name listed on the Millenium flier.  Was he the same DJ Orlando who plays
in Chicago with Freddy Bain and Lil' John?

Or was he another Orlando who plays regularly in L.A.?  I remember reading
of a DJ Orlando who plays L.A. in Xler8tor magazine.

The reason I'm curious is because Orlando from Chicago (along with Freddy
Bain and Lil'John) came out last January to SF (at a party called "Le
Plaisir de Vivre") and last April (at a party called "House").  I don't
know if any of you went to these parties, but I was at both.  I thought
these three guys played the BEST deep house I have EVER heard.  I don't
think I've heard anything better since then (well, with the exception of
certain nights at gay clubs).  And Orlando just blew me away.  I've
actually been thinking of flying out to Chicago just to hear them again.

If anybody can let me know which Orlando it was who played, I'd really
appreciate it... Thanks!!!

Much respects to the party people... Stop the negativity...


jack

we're having a very hard time finding housing (most people don't want
to rent to 3  young guys)...i've heard there's a youth hostel in chinatown
but don't know where it is...

if anyone has any ideas of good places to crash,  we (mike, doug, and i)
would really appreicate it...we're desperate...

-John

Subject: [comp.sys.ibm.pc.demos] [NEW RELEASE] Grind 1.1
From:    jleonard@falcon.depaul.edu (Jim R. Leonard)
Date:    19 Sep 94 13:58:52 +0200
             ----------------------------------------
Archive-Name: auto/comp.sys.ibm.pc.demos/-NEW-RELEASE-Grind-1-1

For all those who waited, were patient, or simply didn't know where to
get it, GRIND version 1.1 is now on ftp.eng.ufl.edu in the
/pub/msdos/demos/incoming/music directory for everyone's enjoyment.
(Keep in mind that those guys are pretty quick, and by Saturday it might
be moved to the /pub/msdos/demos/music/programs/players directory or
something.  :-)

For those who don't know, GRIND is a MOD/S3M/MTM/FAR/STM/669 player that
displays people dancing in time to the music.  Cool, but best suited for
techno/dance/rave/trance/hip hop music.  And yes, it supports both SB
*and* GUS (amongst others), so I don't want to hear any whining.  |^)

New in this version:  MODplayers shell support (many people complained
that they couldn't use GRIND from their favorite player shell, like DMPC
and the like, so the majority of changes in GRIND 1.1 is to facilitate
that).
-- 
Jim Leonard
jleonard@falcon.depaul.edu
"You're all insane and trying to steal my magic bag!"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

You want an instant natural high?  Listen to this new release by MORPH,
called Stormwatch.  Incredible......  You can even do it in your office,
Wow!!

I bought a CD copy at Tweakin Records yesterday.  I am so blown away by
most of the cuts on it, I had to post something on it.  I don't want to
review it as that tends to pigeon hole and then I would have to compare too
much.  Let me just throw a couple of names here: Richie Hawtin (as in Fuse)
meets Aphex Twin in a Zen Paradox acid journey into vapour space and more.
(Oh well, so much for not comparing...)

music, more idm. Oh yah, it is very trancey (my middle name).

This is a New Electronica Presents (not a compilation) and all tracks are
credited to 2 guys, Damon Wild and Dennis Ferrer.  Does anyone have more
info on this group or those guys?

Precedence: bulk

Date	9/22/94
Subject	RE[2]- Galen at bigger part
>From	Todd Spaulding
To	Awesome Ravers

Internet mail                 RE[2]: Galen at bigger parties?

Todd> Until recently, Sunset WAS pretty much an underground thing.  Now
Todd> that everyone and their cousin knows about Sunset (from pretty much
Todd> all around the bay area), it's just not the same anymore.  It's
Todd> still WONDERFUL, yet just not the same as the days when there were
Todd> 20-30 people out there dancing; instead, 200-300+ people show up
Todd> now.

Dave> This really seems like nit-picking to me.

  Sorry, but it is just my humble opinion...  While Sunset remains an incredible
scene that does wonderful things, and while it is not the numbers that count
(VIBE _IS_ EVERYTHING!), I still think that Sunset has changed.

Dave> Even with 300 people you can still Feel what you put in come right
Dave> Back to Ya.  That is underground.  Not numbers.

  I think having Sunset growing to such a large size has some blessings, and
some caveats.  With more people, there is more energy, more understanding, more
love, but also more unwanted vibe (in my opinion).  I certainly don't enjoy
having BIG gangsta boyz in long, black, puffy trenchcoats stand up against me
and stare me down with their stone-cold look as I dance.  This does make me
uncomfortable, so to deal, I try to absorb the good energy around me for
comfort.  Once I feel better, I project back as much good positive love as I
possibly can from then on -- to EVERYONE, gansta's included.  It's a real drain,
but its worth it every time.  They end up backing off, but sometimes it takes
30-40 minutes of dancing my ass off (without moving my spot much) before they
will back off and leave me alone.

  It may be worth it to our scene to make this 'statement', showing how ravers
won't be affected by (what appears to me to be) blatant intimidation attempts. 
We will keep smiling, but sometimes I wish these guys that stared wouldn't try
to make such a point of their presence and intimidational power.

Dave> I think the fact that the party has changed makes it a better party.
Dave> The Freedom of the people to make the party and the Thrill of
Dave> watching it change is what it is All about.
Dave> It wouldn't *be* Sunset without the first small parties And these
Dave> later big parties.  Sunset is.  Let it grow.  Enjoy it.

  I agree entirely!!  It's a beautiful way to watch a good scene grow with good
people.  But I think you may have misinterpreted my tone.  I'm just a bit bummed
that Sunset will probably end up moving in a few weeks.  I would think that one
of the reasons for this is that Sunset is becoming a little too well known for
some people's tastes.  

Todd> Don't get me wrong, the energy is still and always will remain with
Todd> me as TRULY AMAZING at Sunset parties, but the fact of the matter
Todd> is, just too many people have begun to find out about it.  No wonder
Todd> Sunset will probably live on at the Berkeley Marina for only a few
Todd> more weeks.

  My above "fact of the matter" should be corrected.  It is only my opinion, and
I share it with SOME other ravers.  I apologize for such a poor use of
terminology...

Dave> And, of course, it doesn't hurt to have Galen transport the whole
Dave> damn meadow onto another planet like this Sunday...

A M E N.

Love you -- right back,
Todd

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Subject: Re: anybody with a PC -- what's this?? [Grind music player]
To: mayer@netcom.com (Niels P. Mayer)
Date: Thu, 22 Sep 1994 12:02:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Root" <root@ultima.org>

My mailer says that Niels P. Mayer said:
> 
> 
> this looks interesting -- what is it? 
> 

Here's a brief glossary to explain some of the tastier parts of the post
below:


GRIND: a piece of software (as in [organ] grind[er]); displays people dancing
      as it plays the music.
ftp.eng.ufl.edu: the ftp site for the engineering college at the university
      of florida; notable hackers and techno-lovers
MOD:  a file extension, refers to a 4 track, highly efficient means of
      encoding music.  extremely popular in the PC world
S3M/MTM/FAR/STM/669: other file extensions referring to additional sound
     encoding schemes
player: piece of software that reads a file and "plays" it on a PC speaker
     (yes, it can be done) or a sound card
SB: Sound Blaster; refers to the de facto standard sound synthesizer card
     in the PC world.  like "PC", now refers to generic "Sound Blaster
     compatible" cards; uses FM synthesis to create sound
GUS: Gravis Ultra Sound; a rather nice (i have one :) ) sound synthesis card
     that uses wavetable synthesis to create sound. has an SB compatible
     operation mode; taken with all SB compatible cards, represents
     compatibility with 99.999...% of al PC sound cards. Capable of
     multi-voice, multi-timbral and 3d synthesis.
player shell: a program that acts like a unix or dos or whatever shell;
     typically text or window oriented; displays sound files; when one is
     selected, determines which "player" should be used, and calls the
     "player"
DPMC: one of the more popular player shells

> --------------------
> 
> Subject: [comp.sys.ibm.pc.demos] [NEW RELEASE] Grind 1.1
> From:    jleonard@falcon.depaul.edu (Jim R. Leonard)
> Date:    19 Sep 94 13:58:52 +0200
>              ----------------------------------------
> Archive-Name: auto/comp.sys.ibm.pc.demos/-NEW-RELEASE-Grind-1-1
> 
> For all those who waited, were patient, or simply didn't know where to
> get it, GRIND version 1.1 is now on ftp.eng.ufl.edu in the
> /pub/msdos/demos/incoming/music directory for everyone's enjoyment.
> (Keep in mind that those guys are pretty quick, and by Saturday it might
> be moved to the /pub/msdos/demos/music/programs/players directory or
> something.  :-)
> 
> For those who don't know, GRIND is a MOD/S3M/MTM/FAR/STM/669 player that
> displays people dancing in time to the music.  Cool, but best suited for
> techno/dance/rave/trance/hip hop music.  And yes, it supports both SB
> *and* GUS (amongst others), so I don't want to hear any whining.  |^)
> 
> New in this version:  MODplayers shell support (many people complained
> that they couldn't use GRIND from their favorite player shell, like DMPC
> and the like, so the majority of changes in GRIND 1.1 is to facilitate
> that).
-- 
------- Bryce Ryan ------- AMBIANCE ------ brycer@ultima.org -----------

Oops, almost forgot this again.  I haven't been out, so I might be
missing stuff.  Potion and Harmony sound pretty cool, dunno what's up
with the Moonrise Gathering - it could be really nice if it's well
organized, but I don't know who's doing it.  Sometimes the really big
things turn out really great, sometimes they're fiascos.  If you're
ready for either, it sounds worthwhile.  Don't forget Lube tonight,
with Weird Blinking Lights and more...

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep 23 03:02:44 1994

  (5.65c/IDA-1.5 for sfraves@hyperreal.com); Fri, 23 Sep 1994 03:01:13 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ptiger@crl.com (Purple Tiger)
Subject: Synths ate my brain
Date: Fri, 23 Sep 1994 01:17:57 -0400
Organization: Purple Tiger Sophistems
Reply-To: ptiger@crl.com
Message-Id: <5KcWkm4EmwpE071yn@crl.com>
Lines: 20
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Big synthesizers ate my fuzzy purple brain!

Wierd Blinking Lights dragged to Lube three big non-digital synths weighing
from 50 to 70 lbs each.  Wow, like they had wood cabinets and real plastic
knobs.    After Caliban spun a very relaxing set, he and Resonate fired up the
big beasts and started playing with a Maharishi dialogue going in the
background.  I wish you could have been there to hear the sounds these synths
made.  Wild, unfettered, liquid lava electrons screamed out of the speakers.
No on/off well behaved eletrons were these, no you could hear them fighting
as Wierd Blinking Lights pumped, prodded, and throttled the suckers in ambient
noise.  All I kept thinking about was all the capacitors, transitors, op amps
and resitors configured in strange ways for the purpose of herding the little
beasty 'trons around.  It helped me to back in touch with the quantum.

I think everyone should see and hear something like this at least once.   It
helps put the digital shit in perspective.

Ciao,

Purple Tiger

> Todd_Spaulding@mockingbird.globalvillag.com wrote:
>>  I'm just a bit bummed
>> that Sunset will probably end up moving in a few weeks.  I would think that one
>> of the reasons for this is that Sunset is becoming a little too well known for
>> some people's tastes.  

 Brian:
> Uh, actually I think the reason is a little more germane - summer's over.

A while back, Galen had talked about moving the party to Benecia if it got
too big, and in fact it was held at a Presidio location as a change of 
pace.  He was pretty nervous about it getting shut down because the permit
they have *doesn't* cover the size of Sunset.  But once a positive dialogue 
was established with the Berkeley police (who have kept an eye on this from 
the beginning) he realized that he might be able to keep a good thing going 
at the Marina.  Speaking to Jason, of the Pacific group that puts these on, 
they feel that the size last week (around 300) was manageable, while the 
500 of the previous two weeks was pushing it.  The cooler weather will 
probably keep things smaller and they are now planning to continue Sunset
through the end of October.   

We hope to dance with some of you at Sunrise 2night; call the 
Pacific (Sunset) number for details.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\Everything/\Is/\Possible/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

##    The following is a repost that a few of you requested I put up.
##    ...sorry about the messed up formatting the first time...  -Todd


  ___ We'd love to see you all at  Harmony  this Friday the 23rd! ___   

  It's going to go off at a beautiful, new outdoor location just north of
  Santa Cruz that has never been used!  This is the special Santa Cruz
  location that we wanted to use for the Harmony this last August 26th,
  but ended up locating at a beautiful spot in the city.  (It was a
  peninsula on the water overlooking the San Francisco bay, the city
  lights practically in our reach just beyond the bay on the other side.) 
     
  Our August Harmony turned out to be very successful, and quite a big
  turnout considering our relatively careful and conservative flyering and
  promoting.  This time we've printed only a couple hundred flyers, and we
  are relying more on our friends in the underground to support the scene
  and to spread the good word!

 ---->           This is Greg's Birthday Party!  (Yay!!)
       A great big Happy Birthday to Greg (of Harmony Productions) 
              and to everyone else in the world on this day! 

  Friday, September 23rd - Harmony                                 <-----
          DJ Deaks    Taylor    Tim    Tim McKnew    Donut
          A godly outdoor location about 15 minutes North of Santa Cruz.
          408.486.9591  408.488.9954

   We are doing everything we can to make this party free. IF we end up
  charging, it will be very cheap (less than $5), and only to break even.  

          We have _ZERO_ interest in making any money!

 =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
   There is plenty of room for tents, and also be sure to bring lots of    
    warm clothes, blankets, stuffed animals, candy, toys, water, lots    
      of love, and everything else that's good to share with others.    
        =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=--=-=-=-=-=

        Keep the Joy...
       Keep the Love...
      Keep the Faith...
     Keep the Family...
    Keep an Open Conciousness, and Dance Your Ass Off!

 Most of all, Respect Your Mother Earth!  (We actually mean it though!)

 Love and Hugs,
 Harmony
 Support the Underground!

enjoy these free performances!

I have to comment on this since it's become a kind of mission of mine:
"BIG gangsta boyz in long, black, puffy trenchcoats stand up against me and
stare me down with their stone-cold" 

Just the other night at Organic, Milton was saying that these guys(and gals)
HAVE vibe its just takes more effort and perception to "feel." Yeah, they can
seem frozen but the vibe is there its just swathed in enviromentally produced
protective defenses.  I suspect there's a little envy that you can open up
and have such a good time.  As I see it, these folks are our immediate
"neighbors"  in that the musical tastes are similar and often crossover, we
all love a good underground party often in similar locations because of
simple logistics, the use of  recreational drugs produces a lot cultural
commnalities, a suspicion of authority particularly it's enforcers, and just
plain old street style.  Since these are our closest neghbors in this world,
we're going to come in contact again and again unless we become isolated and
defensive ourseles.  Sure it's tempting to want 'them' to go away and
preserve an easy to handle more or less homogenous scene.  But if we want to
GO anywhere and actually put this PLUR thing to the test you gotta spend some
of your personal pleasure and try and make it work.  You might try and hang
out with 'them' - it's fun and the insight is worth it because then you won't
suffer the impression that they are so negative to your vibe and you'll
better know how to approach someone without fear of offending or pissing em
off.  Think of the potential - we're so close already, if we could make that
connection then we would have really done something towards changing the
divided social landscape that is preferred by the powers that be.  Its such a
simple thing really - let's party together.  

actually, its all the fault of that cement path :-)
phuture

Mijos,I  read Phuture's post"Re: RE[2]- Galen at bigger part" about the
gangsta presence at Sunset. Phuture's got it right, and positive, too!

  That cement path has made it easier for the "old-school"/teeny
bopper/gangster camps to seperate, but like he said, if you don't make a
distinction on who's where, you'll share their space with them, you will
become one of them, they will become one of us. Damn simple.
 Just do some buzzin', flit around all over the place, talk to somebody,
BEFORE MAKING THE F##@!# JUDGEMENT, and you will be surprised, pleasantly
even! Heavens to murgatroid!
 A lot of older ravers have lost their aversion of younger dancers, by
Sunset therapy, and must see that they have been missing out on their
excellent, innocent vibe (those kids are dancers, not tweakers!)
 Remember, if the scene is about acceptance, ACCEPT! Or at least give
everyone a chance to give you a chance.....


Have you hugged you gangster today?
 Milton and the E-Bee...............

 (and Rogaine, the Velvet Frog)

From sfraves-owner  Sat Sep 24 00:57:52 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id AAA11255; Sat, 24 Sep 1994 00:57:52 -0700
Received: from gonzo.cc.wwu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id AAA11248; Sat, 24 Sep 1994 00:57:48 -0700
Received: by gonzo.cc.wwu.edu
	(5.65/WWU-M1.0/UW-NDC Revision: 2.26 ) id AA12744; Sat, 24 Sep 1994 00:56:47 -0700
Date: Sat, 24 Sep 1994 00:56:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: lucid fluffy cloud <n9010387@gonzo.cc.wwu.edu>
Subject: SUNSET b l i s s ! ! ! 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9409240000.A12555-0100000@gonzo.cc.wwu.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	After reading the numerous posts regarding Sunset recently, I have
become so overwhelmed with fond memories of my trip to SF a month ago, that 
I thought I'd contribute a northwest perspective of the thriving scene that
you are all so fortunate to be a part of.  It had been several years since
I'd been to the bay area, and during that time I could only drool at what
I read and heard about the sfrave scene.  
	My first Saturday I was taken to the Chateau for MESS's 
"Disorientation", and had a great time.  I was charmed by the homemade 
decorations and the intimate vibe, as well as Scottie's wicked house
set and friendly energy-what a nice guy! : )  Before I knew it, however,
I was whisked off to a rave in Oakland in a somewhat scary part of town.
I don't recall its name, or the djs, but some blistering acid was being
spun which I enjoyed immensely, until I was again yanked to yet another
rave, this one in the city: "Hope."  I personally thought the size of 
this event was nearly perfect--not too large or small, decent visuals,
and GRRRReat djs!  This was the first time I had seen Carlos, and was 
astounded at his bombastic energy and uncharacteristic dj presence...
he was bouncing off the walls!  I have rarely EVER seen a dj break out of 
that stoic-moody-undemonstrative personna, what a refreshing sight!  Is 
he ALWAYS like that?  As Jeno brought in the morning light and the music 
stopped at 6, I was quite satisfied with the first day of my vacation!
(Btw, if anyone knows Wednesday, the promoter for Hope/Organic, please 
let her know that if she still wants copies of the Hope photos, she
can contact me via email or (206)671-3916...).

	The ABSOLUTE highlight to my entire vacation, however, was 
several hours after Hope at SUNSET.  The pure, positive vibe, the music,
the smiles, the view, the family atmosphere, all caused me to be  
filled with an overwhelming joy that I have not experienced to such a degree 
before (yeah, like e, but natural!).  I was utterly amazed that something
so incredible as Sunset went on EVERY week, for free!  It was enough to 
make me entertain the idea of uprooting myself from Washington, and 
simply pitch a tent at Berkeley Marina so that I'd never have to miss
a party.  Btw, for those of you that were there on August 28, I was the 
guy waving a big, lighted log of incense around and passing out sticks
to everyone.  Anyway, I think the Sunset experience is VERY special,
and it breaks my heart to hear that gangstas are dragging their 
unwanted, ego-filled, negative-energy selves to this event, AND, that
Sunset may soon be no longer.  Life is change, I guess, and I feel
very lucky to have been able to participate in something so utterly 
unique.  For those responsible for the Sunset parties, a warm and 
appreciative THANK YOU!
	The remainder of my week in SF was fun, having attended Deep Space,
then OogaBooga in Sac, and Groove Kitchen the night before I left, but
what could have possibly compared to dancing on a hill beneath the stars
that Sunday with a hundred or so smiling souls?  Blessed nothing.

(A big hello to dj's Scottie and Brad!)

Peace,

Andrew


t r i p p i n g o n s u n s h i n e . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

A nice party in a great location!

 I managed to chaffeur Ernie Deaks to HARMONY at about 2:40AM , after
going up the wrong end of the road ( the road is a big loop that is
connected to HW 1 at both ends - something the HARMONY phone message
failed to mention ). 

 After parking in a lot near the road , it was a quarter-mile walk under
a clear moonlit sky to the glen were the big bass sounds were coming 
from. About 40 people dancing , about 30 sitting on blankets or 
hanging out or exploring. 

 Music ranged over various genres , including progressive house , trance ,
and especially fast techno during Deak's set. ( A bit too harsh and fast
for my tastes - must be my age  :-)  ). But even when I didn't dance ,
the listening was fine.

 Outside of the early morning dew , fog , and drizzle , the weather was
great , especially considering the rain earlier Friday . Very good 
crowd attitude , very chatty and friendly. The left hand speaker stack could
have been aimed better , but that the only criticism of the setup that
I  can think of.

 ( And now to bed ...)     Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

On Fri, 23 Sep 1994 Phuture@aol.com wrote:

good posting.  gangstas are people too, and they kind of make the scene a 
whole.  lots of people haven't evolved to the stage where they can open 
up and have fun, because so many kids nowadays don't know how to be any 
other way than negative and pushing people away.  slowly, though, i have 
noticed that people that stick around in the scene evolve naturally by 
just seeing their (now) peers hugging one another and just being 
positive.  they see it is ok to be like that and no one will put pressure 
on them to be negative or anything.  

--->deepfog



> I have to comment on this since it's become a kind of mission of mine:
> "BIG gangsta boyz in long, black, puffy trenchcoats stand up against me and
> stare me down with their stone-cold" 
> 
> Just the other night at Organic, Milton was saying that these guys(and gals)
> HAVE vibe its just takes more effort and perception to "feel." Yeah, they can
> seem frozen but the vibe is there its just swathed in enviromentally produced
> protective defenses.  I suspect there's a little envy that you can open up
> and have such a good time.  As I see it, these folks are our immediate
> "neighbors"  in that the musical tastes are similar and often crossover, we
> all love a good underground party often in similar locations because of
> simple logistics, the use of  recreational drugs produces a lot cultural
> commnalities, a suspicion of authority particularly it's enforcers, and just
> plain old street style.  Since these are our closest neghbors in this world,
> we're going to come in contact again and again unless we become isolated and
> defensive ourseles.  Sure it's tempting to want 'them' to go away and
> preserve an easy to handle more or less homogenous scene.  But if we want to
> GO anywhere and actually put this PLUR thing to the test you gotta spend some
> of your personal pleasure and try and make it work.  You might try and hang
> out with 'them' - it's fun and the insight is worth it because then you won't
> suffer the impression that they are so negative to your vibe and you'll
> better know how to approach someone without fear of offending or pissing em
> off.  Think of the potential - we're so close already, if we could make that
> connection then we would have really done something towards changing the
> divided social landscape that is preferred by the powers that be.  Its such a
> simple thing really - let's party together.  
> 
> actually, its all the fault of that cement path :-)
> phuture
> 
>

>On Fri, 23 Sep 1994 Phuture@aol.com wrote:

>good posting.  gangstas are people too, and they kind of make the scene a
>whole.  lots of people haven't evolved to the stage where they can open

First of all, I think that we tend to forget that people - be it ganstas or
ravers or whatever - are first human beings.  They also want to belong.
Being that we are as a whole (not everyone) but mostly very insecure with
ourselves we should be somewhat a little more understandable.  The guy
standing right beside you may just be just that *very insecure* person
*posing* as a ganster.  I WOULD SUGEST JUST SMILING BACK AT THEM AGAIN AND
AGAIN AND AGAIN. They will get the message that they do not need to put up
a "severe front" just to belong. All ravers are friendly accepting
individuals.  Maybe you should advance and just ask them to dance with
everyone and it would not surprise me how many would just do that.

Maybe the next time you see them they would be wearing a totally different
outfit - bright colors and a love peace sign.

What do you think?

Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com

hey all,


  well just wanted to give this little post and say that Sunset was
a JAM.  I got there around 4 and for the first two hours or so chilled
and danced up on the hill and checking out the American Flag that had
written on it  "The United States of Free Love" :)
  i then went down to check out the dj (who i later found out was garth. 
ignorrant i ;) and he was spinning some groves and i couldnt help but
find my body out dancing. And i continued dancing. Galen (sp?) was next
and his set was amazing.  I never once was let down by it the whole time
he spun. There were a few slight mistakes in his spinning at the beginng
but it didnt detract from the music he spun. Kudos to the that Meat Beat
Manifesto song near the end of his set. 
  Lastly was Jeno, who i havent heard since Jan. 1993 in Boston. He
just totally tranced me out and then made me groove at the end esp. 
when he threw on that "I have a dream" song. 
  So a very cool time. Sunset parties are the shit! when it got dark 
unfortunately the fog rolled in but the strobe and the laser and blue
police light were really cool effects. I didn't expect to stay to the
end but the music and the vibe made me :)

sfravers i met up with: Stevie and Phillip

peace and hope to see ya next week

doug ) ( dougie@netcom.com

Captain's log, stardate 9/26/94 at 12:57 am:

We have just taken the shuttlecraft "Frieda" back to Ten-Forward, which 
is currently docked in Santa Cruz.  I have personally had a wonderful 
experience at the Sunset party.  Tricorder readings were off the scale 
for positive vibes from other humanoids.  Mr. Spock danced his little 
vulcan ass off all night and didn't stop until the Klingons arrived and 
claimed back the Berkeley Marina as their rightful nesting ground.  So we 
all had to leave very quickly to show the Klingons that the people of the 
Federation (of love) are the most diplomatic people in the quadrant.  
After refeuling at Starbase "eat-a-pita" (falafel's only $2.50), we 
headed home under full impulse power and music by Dee-Lite.  After much 
analyzation in the ship's computer banks, I can only come to one 
conclusion:  SUNSET'S COOL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

byebye--->deepfog

I'm new to this scene: I started to grok the rave thing at the burning man 
out at the SPAZ camp.  I've been listening to the music for quite a while 
(I was a DJ many years ago, so somehow you never leave, and the desire to 
hang with the mix, however private is still there.)

Anyway, I made it to Harmony near Santa Cruz. (A group of us burning man 
alumnus camped out: it was really trippy to wake up to find all the ravers 
packed up gone.)  I also went to Sunset last night, where I had the top of 
my skull completely blown off by the music and the vibe.  I have come home 
after so many years of wandering.  To just be there, dance, groove, vibe 
and hang see the beautiful ocean going sleep under thick blankets of fog 
was best.  I'll be there next week, most likely wearing blue polka dotted 
shorts.

they call him...vordo!

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)

Subject: wheekend rpt & stuff
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


A year ago, various poeple were predicting the imminent death of
raving and I knew then what is so obvious now - they couldn't have been
more wrong.   There are just too many people who believe in the
magic of house music & dance...  It's not about money or egos or fads or
look-at-me performers or why-doesn`t-anyone-spin-my-favorite-kind-of-music; 
it's about people coming together to share and immerse themselves in 
positive energy and feelings of joy that come from being reminded how 
good this thing called "life" can be when we let down our hangups and 
experience some PLUR with friends, strangers and the surrounding cosmos.
Just like Woodstock 94 was a success because the *people* wanted it to
be, good vibey house & techno parties will continue because people want 
them to.  

There were 5 free outdoor parties (that I knew of) to choose from this 
weekend in addition to a couple of commercial ventures for the unclued.  
Deelite bailed out of the Moonrise Gathering, apparently something to
do with money guaruntees... hopefully they will soon bail out of the rave
scene altogether:  There is little need for a has-been pop band trying to 
glom onto raves in an attempt to keep themselves commercially viable.  
There were rumors at Sunset that Deelite was going to show up and do 
something for us - I suppose having Lady Kier model some of her outfits 
at the top of the hill would have been entertaining for about 5 minutes.

Anyway, the little bit of life Janie & I try to have outside of raving
and work prevented us from going to most things this weekend.  Not being 
very enamored with the 24th & Illinois site, we sadly passed on Sunrise.  
I made it to the Organic GG Park Bandshell party where a bleary-eyed 
Pacific crew had set up Galen's sound system on zero sleep from the nite
before.  Galen was spinning to a tiny crowd which grew with Graeme and
Jeno.   Organic decided not to use the Bandshell stage, and the lack of 
publicity kept this party relatively low key.  But like most free outdoor 
daytime parties in the sun, the vibe was relaxed and happy.  

When we arrived at Sunset, C3 was finishing up an ambient set that I
felt was a bit too loud.  Space music shouldn't be an assault - but I 
guess we always had the choice of chilling out further away.  Solar 
followed and was a bit housier than usual.  Then Garth came on and blew 
everyone away with a fresh sounding acid house set that I felt was better 
than what I had heard from him at the last Wicked.  Galen followed with
a blistering set that was rather Jenoesque - and in fact I felt it
outshone a good Jeno set that followed.  

Jeno, Garth, lazers... Sunset was a big-time party this weekend, with
most of the core SF House folks in attendance.  It was very smart of
Galen, who really does want the chance to play at big parties, to 
sandwhich himself between Garth & Jeno.  Hopefully, Martin and the other 
luminaries who were there took note.

We bumped into a bunch of SFRavers, uh let's see; Ronan, Derek,
Willis, Ethan, Bryce, Robert, Tony of Synergy, deepfog, Purple
Tiger, Grey, Kathryn, Niels, Gil, the Normals, Crunch, the Amebas, 
Jon D. &  Ann, Gregg, Anthrax, and others I'm sure, and we also met a 
very enthusiastic new convert: Vorgo - we didn't even know he was on the 
net until seeing his post this morning.  Welcome!  d:-)

Although Sunset remains the best party around town, it's innocence and 
PLURity was a little tarnished this week.  Near the end we encountered 2 
girls who were searching in vain for their probably stolen backpacks and  
A blank cassete was stolen from the Pacific crew who were then forced 
to tape over Solar's set in order to get Jeno's.  As far as "gangsta" 
presence goes, we *still* don't know what anyone is talking about with 
this.  If a couple of non-ravey observers happen to be watching us, what's 
the big deal?  And as usual, we interacted with someone who had just 
wandered by, never having heard the term "rave" or even "techno" before, 
asking "What is this?  This is GREAT!"  We could see the virus entering 
his soul...
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\Everything/\Is/\Possible/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

Mijo,RavnBird, some confusion:
 Your quote was by deep fog (tony), adding to Phuture's quote (at the
bottom of tony's post) which you may not have read.

Phuture wrote that as he talked to me about the strong G factor at organic,
I responded about givenem a chance and just approach with his normally low
level of judgement. He did. Situation resolved.
Some people have felt bad at sunset for the same reason, working out of
those olllddd stereotypes,the same things we want to avoid, when authorties
and fearful figures spy down on us...

Tony only   added that if we give them love, they can lower their barriers. 
But why is a gangster not dancing mean he's not having fun/threatening
while a sitting raver is just chilling?
 "They" don't have to dress in overalls or clown costumes, don't have to
hug (although I wish evreyone did both!) to fit in our scene.So amy
"ravers" don't. So many people dress to impress, ie at wicked, why is
G-fashion any less accepted?

Try to draw them in, they'll fit in. Many of them already are....

Lotsa love to all considered, 
 Milton and the E-Bee............

ps: Rogaine the Velvet Frog-E says: ever seen a low rider with hydraulics
while frying? Wubba-wubba-whoooo!

Sunrise was at 24th and Illinois.
I gave semi-lurking sfraver Steve Boyer a ride out
there and met a few other friends as we were parking.

It was a very nice warm evening.  Pacific and asphalt.
The crowd was smallish and into it.  Maybe 75 folks 
with the majority staying til sun-up.  Alex and Ethan
dj'd - and I don't know who else.  Unusual number of
capitalists about.  I met Carita (the slo mo disco queen)
and Stacy and Jake.  Got some free bagels straight out
of a dumpster from a group of Rainbow travelers.  Who
throws the Go Figure parties?  We chatted for a bit.
She was a particularly inspirational type. Jason
said Sunrise was his party with a big smile.
Morning flowers, a burning couch, 
and nice people.

I brought a few friends to Sunset.  They loved it.
One friend had never listened to any house or
techno until he came to visit this weekend.  He
was impressed with the "earth vibe" and even said
that "somehow technopop seems perfect".  
Go Sunset.

Dave

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Yet another wackey raving weekend
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yet another wackey raving weekend
=================================

  This Friday evening,   SunRise...  Brought to us by those beloved
SunSet folks.    So,   after checking the info line by about 8:30 PM,
I discover that the info wasn't put up yet.    So,  I head down to 
San Francsisco to hang out on the Haight,  and visit some friends
until the info comes out.   We all meet at the Horseshoe Cafe
(Where the SF Net terminals are) on a rather warm and unusually muggy
night.    It had rained earlier (First rain of the season),  so 
we suspected that site selection hasn't yet taken place.

   About 11:30,   the info came in....   "It's at 24th and Illinois",
the old standby spot,  so we all pile up in the car,   and head out
there.    None of us has any money this weekend,  so Potion (At 177
Townsend) was completly out of the question.    

   When we arrived,  the sound system wasn't up yet,    so we hung around
and schmoosed with all our friends,   and scouted out the area.    They
had paved the area,   so the site had an ideal dancing surface.    

   It wasn't long before the music started,   and the place started to
fill up.    Don't know exactly how many people showed up,   but I would
say about 100-150 folks showed up at it's peak.

   Alex spun a totally insane set of hard acid techno (140+ BPM) and at
that pace,  it wasn't long before my body really warmed up,   and got
into the music BIG TIME.    After that,   our own Ethan (SFRaver) dished
out some pretty funkey housey tunes,   most of which I haven't heard before.

   Solar then took over,   and upped the energy level yet another notch,
and I pulled put all the stops on his set.    Galen (From Sunset) then
took the controls and twisted my brain (and body) big time....   WOW!!
All these new DJ's.... Fresh new music.... and FREE!!!

   The weather cooled quickly,   a fire was started,   most welcome,  as
lots of us chilled out by the fire,   to warm our outsides up.

   Next thing,  the sun started coming up,   but no cheering (like Sunset),
but still a lot of folks remaining.     Eventually,   as the morning
progressed,   people were leaving around 9 - 10 am,   and people were
cleaning up the site.....  We left around 10 am,   and headed back to
the Haight for some free food at one of the Churches,   and prepared to
head out to Golden Gate Park for Organic,   yet another free party,
Organic in the park.

   I split off from the rest of my freinds,  and head out to the park,
where I home in on that familiar "thump thump" sound.   Only about
40 - 50 people were there at about 1:30, with Galen was at the controls.

   Eventually,  DJ Dan got on,   and dished out some incredably awsome
sounds,   scratching in some really creative sounds that got everyone
cheering.

   This site (Golden Gate Park),  often frequented by Japanese tourists,
and people from all over the world,   had people come over and watch,
and even some joined in and danced.    It was amazing.....

   By about 4:30,   the energy level reached critical mass,  when the
generator ran out of gas.    It took more than 20 minutes to nurse it
back to health,   but eventually the music started again.    Within
minutes,   everyone was dancing again.   

   All too soon,   6 pm finally arrived,   and we were given the chance
to hear the last song,   but just after a few beats started up,   the
generator conked out again.    So,  ended yet another afternoon in the
park.    I head out to the Haight with a friend who treated me to dinner
(thanx Matt),   and head up north to chill for a while.

   This big WICKED Dee-Lite party that was supposed to come off at a
Northern outside site,   never materialized,  and was later moved
to either the DV8 or the Sound Factory (Never did find out which one),
but if free tickets were to become available,   my friend was to call me.

   Before the party in GG park ended,   I was informed of yet another party
at same location as Friday,   but a dear old friend needed me to help him
out,    so I stayed home.

   Sunday......  Folsom Street Fair....  Where all the leather dudz,  and
freaky gays go out and strut their stuff.    Last year,  I happened to
be in the area (At Boogy Buffet),  so I checked it again this year,
but with no money,  I couldn't even scarf up a drink of water,   but
I did get in a little dancing.    WOW!!   That sound system sure was
powerful..   I got tired of looking at naked men,   so decided to head
over to E. Bay for Sunset.    As I arrived,   about 200 raving maniacs
were at it with full viger.   Now THIS! is my kind of party....

   This was the largest Sunset party yet.    I don't think it got to
1000 people,   but I would guess about 700 wonderful people were there.

   Hah!!  one gangsta type came up to and said "Have you hugged a Crunch
today",  and hugged me.   There was nothing out there but pure joy and
tons of high energy.

   As the sun was setting,  the fog came in,   cooled things down,   but
didn't damp any of the energy in the least.    In fact,  things picked up,
and went totally insane.    At 10 pm,   the last song was announced,  and
everyone put in their heart and soul on the last song.   An announcement
"The park is closing,   please pick up your trash,  and leave as quickly
as possible".

   I finally headed home with a "shit eatin grin on my face".....  winding
up a very nice "SMOKE FREE!!" bit of ravin....  ALL OUTSIDE!!  Simply
WONDERFUL!!   

Have a nice day everyone...

CC

Milton & E-Bee
> Mijo, you (lee fogel) refer to people who paid to party as being clueless,

I was only referring to the 2 choices for this weekend: The hyped
Moonrise Gathering fiasco, and Potion, the noname-promoter Sat. nite Club 
party at Townsend that I heard was a predictably vibeless affair.  People 
who shell out $10 or greater for big-flyered parties with no idea of what 
to expect while there are an abundance of free outdoor parties with the 
same big name DJs are (IMO) somewhat clue-deprived as far as raving in the 
Bay Area goes.  I really didn't mean to be insulting; I started out as
clueless as anyone, and even now will sometimes attend questionable events 
out of curiousty.

> yet you say "maybe Martin will take notice of Galen"!Uh oh, contradiction
> city....

True if I was slamming all commercial parties, but I wasn't.

> There are good money parties. 

Totally agree.  The good ones are usually thrown by promoters with
established reputations.
 
> If Galen feels that he needs a big party outlet:
>  1. sunset is a huge mutha

I'm sure that Galen wouldn't mind being paid for his talents, as well as 
be able to just spin without having to be the supplier of the sound system 
and backbone.  He has made clear to me that he wants very much to be 
noticed by established promoters.

>  2. He'll put one together and charge for it, why should Martin be the one
> profitting off of galen's vibe?

Because Martin (and a few others) have the savy that it takes to put 
together a big high quality event while attracting a relatively good 
vibe - without going bankrupt.  Everyone profits from this, not just the 
promoter.  When Galen feels he can recoup an outlay of the thousands of 
dollars it takes to throw a good big commercial party, maybe he'll 
throw one.  Right now, I think he'd be happy just to spin at a few.

truth/love/energy
Lee

THRIVE:
your favorite underground sound systems getting together for an 
end-of-summer romp:


SATURDAY, OCTOBER 8


FREE & OUTDOORS (the way it should be!)


with: 

MOTHER EARTH sound system
KOKAPELLI sound system
THC sound system
DIVINE sound system
VIVID sound system

and MANY others, info to follow!

This gathering is meant to prove the existence of, strength, and unity of 
the free outdoor underground community, and to be a celebration of our 
Mother Nature that gives us life and provides us such beautiful spaces to come 
together and THRIVE!!! 

INFO LINES:
415.487.7681
510.549.6260

If you or a group you identify with want to help in ANY way, PLEASE get 
in touch with any member of the Mother Earth Sound System ASAP, at the 
previous numbers -- EVERYONE can help this party thrive :)  Regardless of 
whether you belong to a "sound system," dee-jay, or own sound or lighting 
equipment, you can help make this a truly de-centralized, COLLECTIVE 
effort - no contribution is too small!


REMEMBER TO RESPECT OUR MOTHER!

medeiros@nature.Berkeley.EDU:
>Tony only   added that if we give them love, they can lower their barriers. 
>But why is a gangster not dancing mean he's not having fun/threatening
>while a sitting raver is just chilling?
> "They" don't have to dress in overalls or clown costumes, don't have to
>hug (although I wish evreyone did both!) to fit in our scene.So amy
>"ravers" don't. So many people dress to impress, ie at wicked, why is
>G-fashion any less accepted?

Gangstas probably have to sit around radiating attitude -- if they
start dancing, all those stoopid oversized pants will just fall right
off. Or they'll trip themselves up.

Kinda reminds me of this thing that happened to my brother in law
(sister's husband) who lives in NYC -- he bought a pair of colorful
"cross colors" pants and was wearing them, you know, like pants are
supposed to be worn. So this kid, dressed inna gangsta stylee (full on
baggy, butt-crack-and/or-boxers showing) just had to come up and tell
him "you're wearing your pants wrong!"...

PS: for the record, I noticed no gangsta presense whatsoever at the
recent sunset raves. On the other hand, at the one 2 weekends ago, I
did notice this girl dancing in oversized pants trip and fall over her
own pant leg. I personally find dancing and loco-motion is much easier
if your shoes are the main interface to the ground, not your pants.
Guess I must be getting old and conservative. Those craaaazy kids!

Hello Sfraves--(and Lee Fogel, for hint, hint, hinting to POST!!!)

Well, It's kinda of nice to be missed.  It seems like at each of the parties
I've been to recently; Groove Kitchen, Phutur, Organic,  Wicked, and Sunset,
people have come up and asked me where I've been.  Maybe my new beard  has
been a bit of a disguise, but I've hardly been able to disguise my 6'5"
frame. I've recently purchased some new vests at "Cognito," (my favorite
store in Santa Cruz, for those who've asked)-but I don't think that it
either--I think it's because I was away for a lot of the summer and didn't
POST.

I guess if you don't post you begin to look like you're  being beamed up on
the Starship "Enterprize."--A disintegrating SFraves molecular memory--and
shimmering shred of Past-Life participation.  S0, "Post or Die" is the
subliminal manifesto here. 

 Let me stretch out the gauntlet again (especially to Lane, my fave-rave
buddy)  and to all those Sfraver's "Lurking on the Skirts"--but desperately
wanting to blurt their blurbs.....................Break on through to the
other side!!!!!.Break on through.................... 

(Repeat.this Mantra 10 times, if you ever have doubts or fears about
posting...........)

Having been with SFRaves for over a year, has anyone else noticed the
delightful absence of any real acidbath flamewars
this summer? Very little electronic blood seems to have been shed during the
summer months. Do you think the Sunset parties, with their positive,
feelgood, loveGroove vibes, have contributed to a certain Sunset Vibe on the
Net? I do. 

And there are so many more people I can attach a name with a face, rather
than just an e-mail address. And I am sure that is true for others.

Even while I was "dancing in the dark," last night, people were coming up and
saying hello. People were waving around incense, glow-sticks, and the dreaded
marriage-E-wanda.

 While there are still a lot of people left to meet on SFRaves, I think a lot
of people have met,  and spent more time together at the Sunset parties.
There just seems to be more space for  smoozing it up when you're shakin' and
bakin' that groove thang,  and the music isn't so loud you have to pull out
your ear-plugs  to talk to someone, Eh?

Although I did have a little trouble conversing with Milton's Frog, but he
did have  that hand stuck all the way  up his ________, so I'll have to
forgive him. Ouch!!!!

All in all, it was nice to look out and over a sea of bobbing heads, dancing
to the music, that blue K-mart Shopper light spinning, red squiggle lazer &
strobe,  and feeling a vibe as thick as my dear old mother's cheesecake. I
even had fun staying to pick up trash!!!

 BTW, I've been asked to give a presentation on telecommunications in
education at the national conference for the "Coalition of Essential Schools"
in Chicago on Nov. 2-6th. If anyone has information on clubs, record stores,
or info lines for Chicago, let me know. Or, maybe a hot line to Mark Farina?

                                                 robertj........monterey


*************************************************
              After silence, music comes closest to expressing
               the inexpressible"--Aldous Huxley

*************************************************

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 26 17:03:54 1994

From: jocelyn@hal.com (Jocelyn Cordell)
