To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: it goes up....
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

it goes & gets down!

It's Sunset! I had a really great time. Thanks to 
all who threw it & participated. It just blows my mind 
to see so many people having fun. I was only there for 
about 3 hours 6-9ish. I spent most of my time in the 
DJ cheerleading section sweet spot- right in front of the 
tables. I saw Niels (I think) and Cpn. Crunch, grooving 
a bit to the left of me towards the speaker. I guess I was
into my groove a bit too much- they disappeared before I 
thought to say hello- well, hello! I was wearing a green 
dress with a cream&black striped shirt tied around the top,
an orange suede jacket, and some sneakers. It was really 
neat-o, becuase I took a friend of mine who hasn't been 
out on the scene for nearly two years. Of course, she ran into 
some people from way back when & it was just wonderful to see her 
enjoy herself at such an "event." Around nine, as we skipped away 
to the car, she commented, "we should do that again sometime."
Coming from a heavily jaded post-raver, that's the best compliment 
that I have for the sunset crew. Keep it coming... please?

Ob: have you hugged your gangsta today?

I didn't really see any gangster type people- at least 
not to my mind's eye, anyway. Then again I wasn't 
really looking for gangsters. There was only one 
negative incident which I witnessed-

This guy was sort of dancing, sort of slamming into other 
people who were dancing- basically, trying to be bothersome. 
He kept yelling things at the DJ (Galen?) like, "play the shit-
you think this is the shit! that ain't the shit- this ain't goin'
off, man!" while sort of throwing himself into other people's dance 
space & into other people. Everyone around the tables got 
very quiet & dropped the groove. 
It kind of got my blood up- I kept thinking that if I 
had been at the turntables, it would have really thrown me- 
but maybe I'm thin-skinned. Anyway I tried to get a cheer going, 
but I didn't time it very well with the music so it didn't have the 
effect I would have liked it to have. But I think it gave other 
people the same idea- during the next mix/transition, people 
started to whoop it up again. Problem solved. I'm not sure whether
the human "the shit"-ometer kept grooving or headed for the hills.

I had a terrific time, regardless....

Take care-

Jocelyn

Subject: RE> Have you hugged your ga
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Date	9/26/94
Subject	RE> Have you hugged your ga
>From	Todd Spaulding
To	Awesome Ravers

Internet mail                 RE> Have you hugged your gangsta lately?

   Milton said on 9/26/94 at 12:04 PM:
Milton> Tony only added that if we give them love, they can lower their
Milton> barriers. But why is a gangster not dancing mean he's not
Milton> having fun/threatening while a sitting raver is just chilling?


If you will re-read this quote from my previous message, it may tell you why I
feel so particularly uncomfortable about this whole "gangster vibe" that I
experienced at Sunset two weeks ago.

  I said on 9/22/94: 
Todd> I think having Sunset growing to such a large size has some
Todd> blessings, and some caveats. With more people, there IS MORE
Todd> ENERGY, MORE UNDERSTANDING, MORE LOVE, but also more unwanted,
Todd> negative vibe (in my opinion). 

Todd> I certainly don't enjoy having big gangsta boyz in long, black,
Todd> puffy trenchcoats  STAND UP AGAINST ME  and stare me down with 
Todd> their stone-cold look as I dance.

Todd> This does make me uncomfortable, so to deal, I first absorb the
Todd> good energy around me for comfort. Once I feel better, I project
Todd> back as much good positive love as I possibly can from then on -- to
Todd> EVERYONE, GANGSTER'S INCLUDED. It's a real drain, but its WORTH IT
Todd> EVERY TIME. They end up backing off, but sometimes it takes 30-40
Todd> minutes of dancing my ass off (without moving my spot much)
Todd> before they will back off and leave me alone.

Please note that what I experienced I DO NOT BY ANY MEANS perceive as positive
energy.  I feel that I was being physically threatened, and NOT AT A DISTANCE as
Milton implies is all that happens.  I don't feel like this unsmiling, very
unhappy looking guy follows me around, only inches away, so that I can't dance. 
I'm not the type that tries to show off or anything, I just like digging into
the music and the vibe REEALLY DEEP when I dance.

Milton> "They" don't have to dress in overalls or clown costumes, don't
Milton> have to hug (although I wish evreyone did both!) to fit in our
Milton> scene. So many "ravers" don't. So many people dress to impress,
Milton> ie at wicked, why is G-fashion any less accepted?

It has absolutely nothing to do with fashion for me!
OK, Here's what happened:
  Basically, this fairly threatening looking man with a very unhappy overtone
about his presence decided to fuck around with me.  (I realize that this
"overtone" is MY PERCEPTION, but it's STILL MY PERCEPTION.)  He stood still
flush up to me, behind me and two my left slightly, only inches away.  If I
danced any more than strictly in place, he would rub up against me like he was
trying to start something.  I kept as much of a positive attitude and demeanor
about myself as possible, trying not to look affected by him.  In reality, I was
shitting in my pants, wondering if he was about to pull out a knife and take a
stab at me at any moment -- because he thought I was ugly, or perhaps because he
didn't like the way I was smiling and looking so happy or something. 

_I FELT THREATENED_ and I didn't know what to do other than to move over a bit
(among the already crowded dance area DIRECTLY in front of the DJ table).  After
I moved over, he continued his power/intimidation trip on me, so I just ignored
him and dug into the existing good part of the vibe that was ever-present.  I
tried to share with him as much of this good vibe as I possibly could, and
perhaps some of it got through.  He eventually backed off, but you have no idea
how hard this experience was on me.  I was so shaken (albeit not so much visibly
so), that I had to go sit by myself on the other side of the Big Hill for about
a half-hour or so to sort things out.

What is this fear that I have fallen to?  Should it be this way?  Am I wrong for
feeling threatened?  Am I not being understanding enough, or loving enough? 
What great lengths more do I need to go to in order to be as readily accepting
as you make it sound so easy for me to do, Milton?  Do gangsters ever fuck
around with you like they do me?  I'm 6'3", I smile a lot, and I like to dance
for my own personal pleasure and to share energy with others around me.  Maybe
I'm doing something wrong -- I don't know...  I wasn't going to give him a hug
-- he looked like he wanted to eat me for lunch!  (Would you if you were in my
shoes?)

Let me state that I am still dealing with my feelings about all of this, and
that I'm TOTALLY open to discussion that could potentially change my whole
viewpoint on this, and I'm interested in knowning how others might feel if they
were to deal with a similar situation.

How would YOU feel???  

I love you all.
Todd

--------------------------------------
Date: 9/26/94 12:04 PM
To: Todd Spaulding
From: Milton & The E-Bee

Mijo,RavnBird, some confusion:
 Your quote was by deep fog (tony), adding to Phuture's quote (at the
bottom of tony's post) which you may not have read.

Phuture wrote that as he talked to me about the strong G factor at organic,
I responded about givenem a chance and just approach with his normally low
level of judgement. He did. Situation resolved.
Some people have felt bad at sunset for the same reason, working out of
those olllddd stereotypes,the same things we want to avoid, when authorties
and fearful figures spy down on us...

Tony only   added that if we give them love, they can lower their barriers. 
But why is a gangster not dancing mean he's not having fun/threatening
while a sitting raver is just chilling?
 "They" don't have to dress in overalls or clown costumes, don't have to
hug (although I wish evreyone did both!) to fit in our scene.So amy
"ravers" don't. So many people dress to impress, ie at wicked, why is
G-fashion any less accepted?

Try to draw them in, they'll fit in. Many of them already are....

Lotsa love to all considered, 
 Milton and the E-Bee............

ps: Rogaine the Velvet Frog-E says: ever seen a low rider with hydraulics
while frying? Wubba-wubba-whoooo!





From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 26 18:18:32 1994

From: David Whitsitt Goodson <whitsitt@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: baggy man g-rocker
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9409261730.C7833-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>

Precedence: bulk


I never thought I'd see the day that a "raver" calls baggy pants stupid :)
Back in the day (read in your best grandpa-chilling-on-the-porch-with-a 
bourbon-and-a-blunt voice), before ravers were "ravers" and raves were 
just acid parties (like in Manchester circa 1987) house music people were 
refered to as "baggies" on account of their pants.  (Happy Mondays: "Dad, 
you look shabby/ you run around and groove like a baggy")
So are you going to alienate me on account of my jeans are a foot too 
big?  I don't think so.  Really they don't stop me from dancing my skinny 
little ass off, so don't you worry your pretty little head.  I kinda like 
the way they flap around my shins.:)
(please don't consider this a flame, or even an attempt to start a 
discussion on the politics of fashion, I'm just havin' fun with it.)

BTW, I have seen NO (imho) gangsters at sunset.  I keep wondering what 
all the fuss is about?  Some of those kids are a little raw maybe, but 
gangsters? come on.  Not to invalidate anyone's experience or anything; I 
mean, being intimidated is REAL and SERIOUS, but having met up with 
actual, truer than life thugs on a few occasions, those sunset fools 
ain't shit. (But that's only my observation)
 Positive/Negative.... it's all just energy. If you try to vibrate only 
on one side, you'll find you can't.  Please don't try to force any values 
on anyone.  They become self evident at the apropriate time, anyway.  
   Having spent a fair amount of time amongst "hippies" (whatever that 
means), I'm worried that our scene, as it wakes up and becomes more 
conscious, will fall into the same sort of moralizing and patronizing 
tone that assures us that WE ARE RIGHT, but really pisses off the rest of 
the world.  I guess I'm moralizing a bit here, too, sorry.  I just 
believe in our potential for total acceptance, and don't want any of the 
vibe to get cut off, especially the funky parts.

really, it all stops mattering so much when that fat beat hits...

love,
whitsitt

p.s. the free love flag got kinda dirty, so we might have to re-paint it 
after washing....

Yep, someday I'll be able to tell my grandkids "I was at Chemistry's 
make-up party."  But seriously, I had a good time.  I had to go-I had 
never been to a Chemistry before, but it was at my favorite Mexican 
restaurant- El Flanker in East Oakland.  It's a cool place- an old 70's 
steak house with a disco floor.  There were lots of people there, but it 
wasn't "massive"-in the hundreds somewhere.  They did charge $2, but I 
didn't mind.  Carlos is a blast - so much energy.  Nice guy, too, went 
out meeting people in the crowd after his set.  I think Christpher and 
Dutch ("CDC=Carlos-Dutch-Christopher") spun also. The crowd was quite 
young.  Younger than me, anyways.  Mostly teenagers.  But there was a 
large variety of young folk there, huggy ravers, fashion plates, suburban 
gangstas.  The young ravers there were enthusiastic indeed,  some of them 
just *had* to come talk with me ;).  The only negatives were the usual 
annoyances, breakdancers and nitrous zombies.  Not enough people dancing 
sometimes.  The sound was pretty good.  There were two systems, one was 
the familiar SF sound, the other was mainly old school dance music.  All 
in all, quite worthwhile.

On Mon, 26 Sep 1994 medeiros@nature.Berkeley.EDU wrote:

I don't think anyone likes being treated like that.  It may well be that 
he was just unconsciously jealous that you were so happy and he was not.  
But I think that the best way to handle people like this is to try to 
treat them just like you would any other person you've just met---could 
say hello, wassup, or whatever you think might be some lingo they can 
relate to.  Then if they don't respond, maybe LEAVE the area as quickly 
as possible.  I highly doubt that he was really going to start anything 
with you, since it sounds like he was by himself.  No?

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I feel a bit bad posting this after someone posted about the fact 
that there have not been any flame wars here, BUT: 

I am a bit irked about the

Big baggy clothing = menacing gangsta

argument.  First, let's look at the social problems this creates.  The
media has lead some to believe that an entire style of clothing has 
been created for young, irate, murderous thugs.  And thus, anyone 
who wears this stuff is someone that should be feared, someone who
must be dealt with the powers that be.  Actually, big, baggy clothes
are not a gangsta threads, they are simply an urban style.  After 
living in South Central Los Angeles for three years I can say that nearly 
every kid in the city wears these clothes, it is just the urban style.  
Is it such a surprise that kids in the city will be wearing different 
things than kids in the suburbs?  Life in the city is 100% different
than life in the suburbs.  Not always better, not always worse, but 
just completely different.

Now that we have stigmatized this urban wear as Gangsta Threads,
we have almost mandated that the law can take "special precautions"
in dealing with young people wearing these clothes.  We know that
many of the kids in the city are minorities.  Can you see where this
argument is going?  By labeling all city kids as gangstas, we will only
further the racism and (if you want to go so far as...) genocide in the
inner cities.  Go to central Los Angeles, and you will see everyone
in the urban style.  Are all these kids criminal gangsta types?  The
media will tell you absolutely, so I guess we just have to eliminate
this little problem.

Styles change.  Compton used to be clothed in 70's sweats and 
sportswear.  Does this mean that all the Adidas Kids are gangstas
too?  Miss Lady Keir, are you a gun-toting criminal?

We need to stop judging people by the clothes they wear.  It is really
just as bad as judging someone by the color of their skin.

Personally, I absolutely love the urban style.  Big clothes are just so
darn comfortable!  I can't imagine dancing in anything but big
pants, big long untucked shirts, boxers, ect.

Because the weather is starting to get cold, I figured this weekend I 
should invest in a good jacket for club-going in SF.  I ended up
getting a big, long, puffy black jacket.  It's the shit!  It kept me
very warm while waiting outside of DV8 (*choke*, yeah, it was a 
nightmare, don't ask me why I went), and it also served me well
while I caught the "top of the hill vibe" at Sunset.  It is simply the
best type of jacket for the stuff I do.  But, after reading Niels' post,
I realized that a lot of people out there are going to think that I am
trying to put up some kind of attitude or something, just because
of my jacket!  Jeez, I hope that is not the case, because I'm really
not that type, but... well...  who knows.

Let's just judge people from the inside out, okay?

-troy

PS.  I have yet to meet many, many SFRavers at Sunset.  Look for me.
I'll be the tall guy wearing... well, you know, and hanging out with 
the Adidas Kids...

From: Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Final Star Trek/Paradox
To: Conscious Ravers <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
cc: centauri@cats.ucsc.edu, Stuart Barber <s.j.barber@engineering.hull.ac.uk>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9409262039.A26453-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I was watching the final episode of Star Trek the Next Generation the 
other night, and an interesting subject came up that I didn't pay much 
attention to before.  For those of you who don't know the episode, I will 
BRIEFLY outline it.  

Captain Picard is being transported through 3 different time periods in 
his life:  the past (when he first took command of the ENTERPRISE), the 
present, and the future (everyone is old and grey).  In each of the time 
periods he is drawn toward a particular sector in space to find a rupture 
of "anti-time".  When time and anti-time mix, they annihalate each 
other.  

In the future, he no longer commands the Enterprise and somehow convinces 
Beverly Crusher (who is now his ex-wife) to cross the neutral zone and 
find this hole.  In the other 2 corresponding periods, he takes the 
Enterprise out there. 

In the future, he gets to the point in space, but finds no hole.  
However, the hole is there in the other 2 time periods, and it is much 
larger in the past.  He says we must find it, and they scan with a 
"tachion beam" to look for this invisible rupture.  He also in the other 
2 time periods did the same thing.  So what happened was all 3 beams met 
at a common point in space and CREATED the very rupture he was looking 
for.  

I've been thinking about this a lot, because it brings one question in my 
mind:  Is it possible to create your own destiny just by believing 
something is true?


From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 26 23:02:01 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>,
        Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Re: Final Star Trek/Paradox
Date: Tue, 27 Sep 94 00:17:55 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> I've been thinking about this a lot, because it brings one question in my 
> mind:  Is it possible to create your own destiny just by believing 
> something is true?

Yes.

"Belief in truth" worked quite well for Adolph Hitler and Charles
Manson didn't it? "Belief" caused many a heretic to burn at the stake,
and inspired many a parishioner to light the fire. "Belief" in our
ability to classify human versus sub-human got us slavery, genocide,
the crusades, etc. Belief in the "manifest destiny" of the colonizer
stole the land from many a native in many a country. Belief in the
power of the atom caused the scientist to ignore the dangers of
radiation.

Not that beliefs are inherently good or bad. "Democracy" ultimately
rose out of englightenment beliefs, for example. On the other hand, the
US Govt is happy to invoke "democracy" and/or "capitalism" as
justification to interfere with other countries and  cultures -- can
you say Vietnam, or Panama, or Iraq? Just mentioning the word
"democracy" invokes a certain "leap of faith" among some US citizens
even though the zeitgeist of democracy gave up the ghost long ago.

Perhaps if fewer people tried to create their own destiny (and others')
via belief,  life might be more pleasant for everybody else. Imagine
how pleasant human history would be without belief in the truth of
nationalism,  capitalism, socialism, communism, religion, etc.

Belief, like drugs, are powerful and should be used carefully, in
moderation, and with great skepticism. Belief is drugs to some extent.
People can and will twist reality to fit around their beliefs, rather
than vice versa. Mass consensual hallucinations are not always a good
thing.

Perhaps the true path, grasshoper, is the one reached without belief. :-)

	- Niels "I rave, therefore I am!" Mayer.

I don't think anyone here means to make lite of Todd's gangster encounter. I
certainly didn't.  I would still like to see everyone dress up as their
favorite animal and go to a rave, gangsters or no gangsters.  :-)

Have you ever met a person that doesn't understand a word you're saying?
No matter how your explain something to them, they just can't understand.
It's almost as if their mind is on a different planet than yours.  There are
folks that are that way about positive energy.  I mean, you can smile all you
want and they still won't get it.  Todd's gangster might have been one of
those.

What do you do with folks like that?  I don't know.  Me, I keep my distance
and wait for the channel to change or for Todd to drive 'em off. :-)

Ciao,

Purple Tiger

Deepfog ponders:

> I've been thinking about this a lot, because it brings one question in my 
> mind:  Is it possible to create your own destiny just by believing 
> something is true?

There are certainly those that believe so, that if you devote enough thought
or effort to your dreams they will come true.  I also think that if you desire
a particular destiny too much, you'll never be happy with the one you got even
if it is what you were wishing for.

Seek instead to be happy with whatever life gives you.  Once you let that
happen, you'll see all the wonders you've dreamed of.

Subject: Re: have you hugged your gangsta today? 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Mon, 26 Sep 94 20:19:23 PDT."
             <199409270319.UAA14303@phakt.usc.edu> 
Date: Tue, 27 Sep 94 02:18:11 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> I am a bit irked about the
> Big baggy clothing = menacing gangsta
> argument.  

I never said that. In case you feel like checking the facts, I've
included my original post below.

Basically, I was gently poking fun at a rather stupid fashion (IMHO).
Next week, maybe I'll pontificate about stupid shoes (like women in
high heels), or the incredible Karmic benefits derived from wearing
brown Rockports.

Fashion should be poked fun at, because it is fundamentally stupid,
unnatural, and poseurish. Even worse is when fashion becomes a uniform,
As it has become with the mega-baggy wear (i'm not talking raver baggy
here either, I'm talking gangsta baggy, which is extreme to the point
of disfunction).

(I like silly, unique, personal styling. I give more props to someone
that clothes themselves from a thrift shop than some poseur that is
trying to buy their way into a culture by picking up the latest baggy
and/or grungewear at Emporium for big $$$$. I like it when I wear my
patented atrociously psychedelic 1960's polyester golf pants  to a rave
just so I can hear all the big-hairspray club-girrrlz go
"eeeeeeeeuuuuu!". Now that's fashion!)

I don't like the idea that fuels fashion amongst its victims -- the
idea that you're not cool/hip/popular/sexy unless you're wearing
something that some 'droid in the head office of a department store
decided was hip for this fall's back-to-school lineup. Isn't it just
"strange" that next year, something else will be in? Consume kiddies!
Consume!

> media has lead some to believe that an entire style of clothing has 
> been created for young, irate, murderous thugs.  And thus, anyone 
> who wears this stuff is someone that should be feared, someone who
> must be dealt with the powers that be.  Actually, big, baggy clothes

Unfortunately this is somewhat true, except that the "entire style of
clothing" has been created for poseurs that think they can purchase
rebellion. Actually, gangsta fashion is pretty stupid now that it has
shown up in shopping malls across America. Just how much gritty urban
authenticity are you getting when you lay out $50-100 for a pair of
pants? 

Equally stupid are the record execs pushing "gangsta rap" gansta this
and gangsta that towards what is ultimately a white suburban market.

> are not a gangsta threads, they are simply an urban style.  After 
> ...
> Go to central Los Angeles, and you will see everyone
> in the urban style.  Are all these kids criminal gangsta types?
> ...
> living in South Central Los Angeles for three years I can say that nearly 
> every kid in the city wears these clothes, it is just the urban style.  

I dunno. I can understand a big baggy jacket in NYC or DC in the 
winter. It doesn't make any sense at all in central LA. No, we're
talking mass conformity here. It's not a race thing, it's not a class
thing, it's a lemming thing. It's a stupidity thing. I reject it,
straight up, no chaser. Can you dig that?

This urban style (i've been told) evolved out of gangsta style of the
ghetto on the east coast. The oversized pants were supposed to show how
much you've slimmed out while in prison. How that style made it into
every suburban shopping mall in amerikkka is a great "mystery". Almost
as ironic as "grunge" becoming mainstream suburban fashion.

Equally mysterious is the marketing push towards "gangsta" rap. If you
don't see the hand of corporate marketing executives at work here, then
you're blind. (If you want racial conspiracy, try to remember that the
chains of slavery have been cut, to be craftily replaced with the
invisible shackles of the wage slavery, credit card payments, keeping
up with the joneses, and "fashion".)

I just don't understand "gangsta" -- it is not something that deserves
respect, and it is not going to get it from me in any shape or form,
whether it's action, pose, or fashion (although I probably will respect
a loaded gun pointing in my direction). I can respect wanting to
overthrow the government, I can respect disenchantment in the system. I
can't respect a fashion solution to the problem. You can't solve what
ills the nation by putting more money in the hands of the powerful. 

> we have almost mandated that the law can take "special precautions"
> in dealing with young people wearing these clothes.  We know that

I think you're putting words in my mouth. 

> Can you see where this argument is going?

Yes. But it's your argument, not mine. I guess I was originally just
trying to be funny, but what with all this P.L.U.R bullshit, I guess
you can't really say much other than "the song was 120 BPM" without
someone snuffing your expression.

> We need to stop judging people by the clothes they wear.  It is really
> just as bad as judging someone by the color of their skin.

Wrong. You can change your clothes. You can't change your skin (unless
your Michael Jackson).  People are wearing the clothes because they
want to be judged. Otherwise they could have saved their parents a lot
of money and shopped at K-Mart.

> Personally, I absolutely love the urban style.  Big clothes are just so
> darn comfortable!  I can't imagine dancing in anything but big
> pants, big long untucked shirts, boxers, ect.

I'm wearing loose-fitting comfortable clothes myself. I guess you just
missed the humor in the "baggy one upsmanship" that seems to have
migrated from the east cost to the west in the past 5 years.  It is
ridiculous to see these kids unable to cross the street cuz they're too
busy trying to keep their pants on. I think it's both funny, stupid,
and pathetic, all at the same time.

Gangstas probably have to sit around radiating attitude -- if they
start dancing, all those stoopid oversized pants will just fall right
off. Or they'll trip themselves up.

Kinda reminds me of this thing that happened to my brother in law
(sister's husband) who lives in NYC -- he bought a pair of colorful
"cross colors" pants and was wearing them, you know, like pants are
supposed to be worn. So this kid, dressed inna gangsta stylee (full on
baggy, butt-crack-and/or-boxers showing) just had to come up and tell
him "you're wearing your pants wrong!"...

PS: for the record, I noticed no gangsta presense whatsoever at the
recent sunset raves. On the other hand, at the one 2 weekends ago, I
did notice this girl dancing in oversized pants trip and fall over her
own pant leg. I personally find dancing and loco-motion is much easier
if your shoes are the main interface to the ground, not your pants.
Guess I must be getting old and conservative. Those craaaazy kids!

This was my fourth time in a row at Sunset and I'm determined that this
time I'm going to write something about it. Anyway, it continues to be
way cool (can you still say that about a rave or is it now obligatory
to say that it was the shit? :-) Definitely becoming a habit. Got there
late this time (after six) I think the DJ playing was Simon at least
he looked like the guy who played after Galen last week and I was told
that was Simon (Assuming I really know which one was Galen) Sorry, I'm
still trying to sort out these various people and I don't know many of
them by sight yes. Anyway, after Simon was someone I didn't recognize
at all. The light show after it's dark is getting better too. tonight
someone brought a strobe and a small laser.

reading the messages today I am convinced that I am totally confused
about DJ identification. Could someone help me out? The guy I though
was Simon has long medium brown hair done up in dreadlocks and
gathered into a pony tail. Last week he came on about 7:00 and played
until 8:30ish. Yesterday he was spinning when I got there a little
after 6:00 and turned it over sometime after 7:00. I'd like to know
his name 'cause I really liked the stuff he was playing.]


Wish I could talk more about the music but I don't really understand
the terms I hear being used. I'm beginning to be able to distinguish a
sort of continuum with one end being the stuff that's slow[er], more
melodic, with more vocals and the stuff that's faster, has almost no
melody but is more like pure rhythm and has few if any vocals. Is this
the difference between "house" and "techno" maybe? But I'm still
confused about the meaning of terms like "deep", "acid", "trance",
etc.  Could anyone point me to someplace where I might learn about the
different kinds of music I've been hearing?


About gangsters.  I was kinda surprised to read Todd's remarks
about gangsters at last week's Sunset 'cause I didn't remember seeing
any. Maybe I missed them. Anyway this week I was looking around to
notice the types of people there. I did see a couple of people dressed
in what might be called "gangsta" style but they didn't really look
like a gang somehow. There were lots of different kinds of people
there doing all different sorts of things, dancing, standing,
juggling, sitting, walking
around, whatever... The all seemed to be enjoying themselves and
nobody seemed to be looking for trouble. I though that's what the
scene was supposed to be about. Anyway, that's what I like about it, all
different kinds of people coming together just to have a good time. If
"gangstas" want to come and have a good time too, I say that's fine.

Again, I wrote the previous paragraph last night. I don't think I want
to change it much. I would like to add that I'm wary of attaching
labels to people especially based on superficial attributes like
clothing style. Because once you slap a label on someone you start
reacting to the label instead of the person. And so do other people
who hear the label and maybe never even saw the person. 

I think maybe I've said enough for my first real post to sfraves. I
just want to thank the organizers of Sunset and all the people there
for some really good times.

Later,
-Bill

Bill asks:
> Could someone help me out? The guy I though
> was Simon has long medium brown hair done up in dreadlocks and

That was Garth last Sunday.  And you are right about it being Simon
the week before.  2 different people.  Galen came on after Garth - 
young guy with a baseball cap.  Then Jeno, older guy with a baseball
cap.

> confused about the meaning of terms like "deep", "acid", "trance",
> etc.  Could anyone point me to someplace where I might learn about the
> different kinds of music I've been hearing?

like lynx or mosaic.  Otherwise FTP or gopher might still be supported.  
And while you're there, check out "The Spirit of Raving" directory to get 
an explaination of what Niels refers to as "all this P.L.U.R. bullshit" :)

On Mon, 26 Sep 1994, Purple Tiger wrote:

> Deepfog ponders:
> 
> > I've been thinking about this a lot, because it brings one question in my 
> > mind:  Is it possible to create your own destiny just by believing 
> > something is true?
> 
> There are certainly those that believe so, that if you devote enough thought
> or effort to your dreams they will come true.  I also think that if you desire
> a particular destiny too much, you'll never be happy with the one you got even
> if it is what you were wishing for.
> 
> Seek instead to be happy with whatever life gives you.  Once you let that
> happen, you'll see all the wonders you've dreamed of.
> 
> More swami mumbo jumbo,
> 
> Purple Tiger

The REAL trick is to find the balance between being happy where you are 
and at the same time pursuing your dreams. Determining what the Universe 
has in store for us (as opposed to what we THINK we want from life) 
requires the greatest test of who we are: that of unbending self-honesty.

hoooooooommmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm...
Jaxun

On Tue, 27 Sep 1994, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

Interesting post.  It just want you to know that there are people like 
me  and other sfr people who believe in creating their own phuture 
WITHOUT the need to harm others in the process.  And this is where we 
need everyone's help enlisted.  If enough people BELIEVE the world will 
be a different, more peaceful, more spiritual place where ravers and 
people are accepted, it will all come true.  At least that's what I 
believe.  


> 
> > I've been thinking about this a lot, because it brings one question in my 
> > mind:  Is it possible to create your own destiny just by believing 
> > something is true?
> 
> Yes.
> 
> "Belief in truth" worked quite well for Adolph Hitler and Charles
> Manson didn't it? "Belief" caused many a heretic to burn at the stake,
> and inspired many a parishioner to light the fire. "Belief" in our
> ability to classify human versus sub-human got us slavery, genocide,
> the crusades, etc. Belief in the "manifest destiny" of the colonizer
> stole the land from many a native in many a country. Belief in the
> power of the atom caused the scientist to ignore the dangers of
> radiation.
> 
> Not that beliefs are inherently good or bad. "Democracy" ultimately
> rose out of englightenment beliefs, for example. On the other hand, the
> US Govt is happy to invoke "democracy" and/or "capitalism" as
> justification to interfere with other countries and  cultures -- can
> you say Vietnam, or Panama, or Iraq? Just mentioning the word
> "democracy" invokes a certain "leap of faith" among some US citizens
> even though the zeitgeist of democracy gave up the ghost long ago.
> 
> Perhaps if fewer people tried to create their own destiny (and others')
> via belief,  life might be more pleasant for everybody else. Imagine
> how pleasant human history would be without belief in the truth of
> nationalism,  capitalism, socialism, communism, religion, etc.
> 
> Belief, like drugs, are powerful and should be used carefully, in
> moderation, and with great skepticism. Belief is drugs to some extent.
> People can and will twist reality to fit around their beliefs, rather
> than vice versa. Mass consensual hallucinations are not always a good
> thing.
> 
> Perhaps the true path, grasshoper, is the one reached without belief. :-)
> 
> 	- Niels "I rave, therefore I am!" Mayer.
>

At 11:17 PM 9/26/94 -0700, Andrew McCoy wrote:
>anyone want to sell one?  anyone know where I can get the best 
>price and how much such a unit would cost?
>
>thanks.  
>
>Left all my vinyl in seattle =(
>
>
>Andy


You should be able to get a Denon for about $1000 or a Stanton for $700
(new).  DO NOT buy the Gemini one...  Most important flaw: it's cueing
sucks--with a single press of the search button you jump about 2 seconds in
the song.  It's also front loading instead of top loading.  The Technics
one is beautiful, but its about $1300+ for a single disc player.

The Stanton CD-11 allows you to cue frame by frame.  I have one and it's
nice; missing a few bells and whistles, but I didn't have money for the
Denon.


Feel free to email me if you want to hear more about it:)


mike

P.S.  Please don't flame--I also have a pair of 1200's, but use my CD mixer
mainly for ambient music which I have found much harder to obtain on
vinyl...


Anybody who can recommend a source of ambient vinyl around here?  It would
be much appreciated....

> Fashion should be poked fun at, because it is fundamentally stupid,
> unnatural, and poseurish. Even worse is when fashion becomes a uniform,

	I must really agree with these sentiments... Clothes are after all
clothes... If someone takes a little bit of gibing about their 
appearance, especially when it is not meant as a cut, then what does that
say about their personality? Actually quite a bit... and I think the point
of that fashion tends to destroy unity was well made. How am I supposed
to include people who do not want to include me because I am not decked
out in the proper gear. So before anyone goes and flames me for being lax
remember that unity works between individuals in a group and even if one
person is opening up to all, if that person is being excluded for any reason,
there is no unity, just someone being open in a group of people... Right,
well, that does not mean that I run around saying that I will not be open
to people who put themselves above me because their clothes cost more, it
just means I have another reason to go PPPTTTTHHHHBBBBB and smirk for a bit
while they try to figure at what the hell I was going PPPPTTTTHHHHHBBBBBB
at... (You those of you who do not know me, I like to PPPTTTHHHBBB just
abouyt everything, but I think my favorite thing to PPPTTTHHHBB is myself,
which after a few seconds thought, might mean that people who only interact
with me for a short peroid of time take my PPPTTTHHHBBBs the wrong way)...


>   People are wearing the clothes because they
> want to be judged. Otherwise they could have saved their parents a lot
> of money and shopped at K-Mart.

	As I see this, this is only partly true. You could go and shop at
K-mart but then you must take the abuse of those around you for not being
in the times. This is a problem with fashion, in that it is one of those
vicious cycles that people like to associate with 'bad' habits, ie. 
you get made fun of for not dressing to current fashion code, so to stop
the unwanted abuse, you go and shell out far too much money to dress to
ths code, but then you want something for your money (I guess) so you
decide to make fun of people that do not dress to the standard (ok, not
everyone does this, but the fashion cycle seems to work this way from
an outsiders perspective). Does this make fashion a bad habit?

> "baggy one upsmanship" 

	I think this is the real point of this arugment, or at least the
point which is being argued past. One person is looking at the attitude that
is often comes with a style, and the others defend the style or those that
the generalization does not apply to. When the I-am-superior attitude appears
people tend to notice, but not necessarily the fashion or the look associated
with the superior being. Surely, it is just the attitude that is being
recongized. And I tend to think that part of the gangsta image is an I-am-
superior-to-thou attitude or image (which is the real attitude, the image
one wants to portray or the way they actually feel?) which if sufficient
effort is made, can be gotten past. Whether or not this image will be broken
for more than the evening, I guess, is inconsequentual... 
	I guess I question the need to always be breaking down other peoples
attitudes, I have enough trouble finding time to sort out what I believe. 
And for some reason I have trouble 'forcing' someone to open up if they make
no move to do so on their own (I do not consider coming out to a gathering
to get blitz out of one's skull and go around exerting their trip, which 
seems to be unwanted a movement toward opening up). But I do see that an
effort should be made to explain what is going on, to give the person an
understanding of that in which they are trying to involve themselves. Yet I
do see a point when a person has rejected what they see in front of them, 
and decide to exert an unwelcome trip upon a mass of people who do not wish
to have that trip exerted upon them. In some ways, I believe that the 'scence'
as a whole can be too anti-confrontational, I have seen parties die from this
(take examples: look at parties which have happened at 16th and Harrison,
after my third one there, I vowed never to return, for the very reason that
no one including myself was going to do anything about about 10 people who
radiated a few stars worth of attitude, or imagine a nice little intimate
house party which was crashed by the local drunken frat group, yes, this is
personal experience, which killed a good vibe for the entire night, even
after we asked the group to leave...) One might quickily observe that even 
when something was done, the vibe was killed and this is something I do not
know how to work around. I believe that there is a point when enough is
enough, and something has to be done about attitude (hold over from my
teenage years of shows at CBGBs in nyc, nyhc :) )... But then, eventually
I might find myself rejected in my whistle blowing frenzy (I like noisy
parties where things are intense, and I think my dance style may be a bit
aggressive, it was termed by a friend as the way Max dances in Where the 
Wild Things Are(Live?), I take that as a compliment). Again, the problem
I see is that any line drawn is abritary and will most likely alienate
someone who does not want to be alienated... What to do????

dave

There's an article in today's San Jose Mercury News about why women's
clothes are priced so much higher than men's: women attach more status
to clothing and will pay more. Men (for the most part) don't follow
fashion and won't pay those prices.

I think the fun about fashion is to see how much you can look like you just 
came out of a Magazine without spending money.  I can go buy designer name 
clothes, silks, linens, wools, and many others for less than I can buy cheap 
clothing at Kmart.  I am more into finding basic clothing out of good fabrics 
at less than $10 an item.  If I can buy some DKNY jean shorts for $8 at a 
clearance store, I for sure am going to buy them over any $15 jean shorts at 
Kmart because designers often use higher quality fabrics that will last longs, 
and will wash better than Kmart's clothing.  Don't go spend tons of money on 
the latest DKNY or J.O.E. or Todd Oldham, when you can get the same stuff at 
discount stores, or on the clearance rack for 80% off the retail price.  Don't 
waste money just for the tag, all those tags end up at discount stores in the 
end anyway.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Fashion: who cares?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Fashion is a statement that is meant to impress others.  By devoting a lot
of time and energy to putting down 'fashion plates', you are only strengthening
the cult of fashion, because people are fashionable so they will be noticed.

The difference between fashion and cool clothes is the wearer's attitude.
Do you wear that outrageous hat because you like it, or because (say) sanp-
(oops) snap-brims are in this year and you see people wearing them on
bus kiosks?

Second: a note about attitude.  If people keep getting in your face while
you're dancing, go into the thick of the dancing so you won't feel isolated
and the person trailing you will have to work to follow.  If they're still
there, just ignore them; don't try to bump them, but if they get in your
way don't worry about it.  Fix them with a long stare; keep smiling and
dancing.  Don't stop looking at them until they leave.  I haven't met the
attitude-monger yet who will stand up to this, since the only two options
are to start a fight (dumb, you're in a big crowd) or go away.

Both these points tie together in that if a person is not physically
coercing you, they only have as much power over you as you give them.
Don't give up your personhood to someone else's projected image.  Project
your own, and let your two images fight it out while you keep dancing.

// g

>I've been thinking about this a lot, because it brings one question in my
>mind:  Is it possible to create your own destiny just by believing
>something is true?

Virtual world where are you?

In reality...yes, I believe that if you focus enough energy towards one
goal, that may become your destiny.  I also believe that you mostly (other
than catastrophic events) have control over that destiny.  If you look in
one direction to a point on the horizon you will get there eventually,
maybe through some steep valleys and some exhilerating climbs along the
way. Obviously and fortunately along your journey you will discover many
diverging paths, diverse beings, exciting adventures but if you do not lose
sight of that goal you will reach it undoubtably. Remember there are no
rules, just creativity.

Your destiny could simply be fulfilment as a whole, the balance between
body and soul, peace with oneself and the world around you.

I live by this simple line: "Life is not a rehearsal - live it to your best
now 'cause you do not get a second chance".

Peace...

Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i believe (har har) that you can't find yer true destiny
  if you know what it is; because that'll blind you to the
    signs that otherwize would've lead you to that destiny.
furthermore, since it's really unlikely that anyone would
  REALLY KNOW their destiny, even SEARCHING for it could still
    topple you off the path you would have persued elsewize...

so, to really find what you seek, look for something else entirely,
  and clear your mind of all things pertaining to what you originally
   sought.  all of a sudden, when you are TRULY looking for something
    else utterly unrelated, the original thing you MEANT to find will
     pop up and boink ya on the nose...

at least that's been my experience...

Dave Scruton

> women ... will pay 
more. Men (for the most part) don't follow
> fashion and won't pay those prices.

Our culture has traditionally insisted on women's involvement with 
fashion, and has not (until recently...historically speaking) placed 
a lot of emphasis on men being involved with fashion. Of course there 
has always been the well-dressed male, but being well-dressed is 
quite a different issue than  being involved with fashion. And "the 
well-dressed male" in American culture (to me anyway) has always 
brought to mind the suave and urbane European male...but the European 
male has traditionally been involved with fashion (look at LouisXIV!)


From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep 27 14:16:59 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

From: Alissa Feinberg <AFEINBER@sybex.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  Re: Fashion fun
X-Mailer: UGate [Ver. 1.94]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> > Fashion should be poked fun at, because it is fundamentally stupid,
> > unnatural, and poseurish. Even worse is when fashion becomes a uniform,

I'd agree that it's stupid when it becomes a uniform and the 
person(s) doing it don't understand why they're doing it (the lemming 
thing), but I don't see that fashion is "fundamentally stupid"... do 
you care to explain?

What's wrong with somebody wanting to look good? to do something 
flashy and fun to get noticed? I think it's natural for people to do 
stuff like this. It's a problem when people do it without being aware 
of what they're doing... because their friend, mother, boss, priest, 
teacher, billboard, magazine, television tells them that if they 
don't do it they're not worth anything. So how much of this is a 
problem with individual people or with the culture we've created?

Received: by NeXT Mailer (1.100.2)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: fashion / consumerism
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



 > Fashion should be poked fun at, because it is fundamentally stupid,
 > unnatural, and poseurish. Even worse is when fashion becomes a uniform,

But I like fashion. I think it's one of the greatest human inventions. I used  
to be fairly clueless about fashion -- thinking it has nothing to do with me,  
but a trip to paris few years back completely changed my opinion of it. I  
appreciate people who pay attention to what they wear and how they put their  
clothes together and how they mix their colours -- with a hint of vanity,  
flair, and fun. I like that touch of vanity in people (otherwise I think they  
are boring).

Granted, it is stupid when the person who is trying to be fashionable fails at  
it miserably, but I dont see why fashion itself should be the blame. That  
person who cant carry it off is stupid, IMHO, not fashion, as an institution.  
When somebody does it "just right", it gives many of us a sense of 'perfection'  
like a piece of art is perfect. I think fashion, when done right, definitely  
feels very natural, brilliant, and adds a certain joy to life. 


---
"I should have been a pair of ragged claws . . ."
bong@next.com

Good morning...

Well, Todd, I think you did everything possible to avoid a potentially 
harmful situation. When I was doing rape education seminars at San Jose 
State, the first thing I'd say was "Trust your gut instinct." If you feel 
threatened by somebody, move away from the person. That's what you did, and
the situation abated (eventually).

Being threatened *sucks*, especially when you're at a place where you don't
expect it to happen. Furthermore, it WASN'T your fault. Don't blame yourself.
You were at an event and this jerk decided to fuck with you. It was HIS fault,
not yours.

Hope you can put this out of your mind -- he isn't worth getting upset over.
Of course, a couple of weeks ago was my four-year anniversary of being raped 
after a party, so I know that it can be difficult to forget about it and move 
on. Take comfort in your friends, try to not think about it, and keep 
dancing!

--Lynn

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: RE> Have you hugged your ga
Author:  Todd_Spaulding@mockingbird.globalvillag.com at cc_smtp
Date:    9/26/94 5:50 PM


Date	9/26/94
Subject	RE> Have you hugged your ga
>From	Todd Spaulding
To	Awesome Ravers
     
Internet mail                 RE> Have you hugged your gangsta lately?
     
   Milton said on 9/26/94 at 12:04 PM:
Milton> Tony only added that if we give them love, they can lower their 
Milton> barriers. But why is a gangster not dancing mean he's not 
Milton> having fun/threatening while a sitting raver is just chilling?
     
     
If you will re-read this quote from my previous message, it may tell you why I 
feel so particularly uncomfortable about this whole "gangster vibe" that I 
experienced at Sunset two weeks ago.
     
  I said on 9/22/94: 
Todd> I think having Sunset growing to such a large size has some 
Todd> blessings, and some caveats. With more people, there IS MORE 
Todd> ENERGY, MORE UNDERSTANDING, MORE LOVE, but also more unwanted, 
Todd> negative vibe (in my opinion). 
     
Todd> I certainly don't enjoy having big gangsta boyz in long, black, 
Todd> puffy trenchcoats  STAND UP AGAINST ME  and stare me down with 
Todd> their stone-cold look as I dance.
     
Todd> This does make me uncomfortable, so to deal, I first absorb the 
Todd> good energy around me for comfort. Once I feel better, I project 
Todd> back as much good positive love as I possibly can from then on -- to 
Todd> EVERYONE, GANGSTER'S INCLUDED. It's a real drain, but its WORTH IT 
Todd> EVERY TIME. They end up backing off, but sometimes it takes 30-40 
Todd> minutes of dancing my ass off (without moving my spot much)
Todd> before they will back off and leave me alone.
     
Please note that what I experienced I DO NOT BY ANY MEANS perceive as positive 
energy.  I feel that I was being physically threatened, and NOT AT A DISTANCE as
Milton implies is all that happens.  I don't feel like this unsmiling, very 
unhappy looking guy follows me around, only inches away, so that I can't dance. 
I'm not the type that tries to show off or anything, I just like digging into 
the music and the vibe REEALLY DEEP when I dance.
     
Milton> "They" don't have to dress in overalls or clown costumes, don't 
Milton> have to hug (although I wish evreyone did both!) to fit in our 
Milton> scene. So many "ravers" don't. So many people dress to impress, 
Milton> ie at wicked, why is G-fashion any less accepted?
     
It has absolutely nothing to do with fashion for me! 
OK, Here's what happened:
  Basically, this fairly threatening looking man with a very unhappy overtone
about his presence decided to fuck around with me.  (I realize that this 
"overtone" is MY PERCEPTION, but it's STILL MY PERCEPTION.)  He stood still 
flush up to me, behind me and two my left slightly, only inches away.  If I 
danced any more than strictly in place, he would rub up against me like he was 
trying to start something.  I kept as much of a positive attitude and demeanor 
about myself as possible, trying not to look affected by him.  In reality, I was
shitting in my pants, wondering if he was about to pull out a knife and take a 
stab at me at any moment -- because he thought I was ugly, or perhaps because he
didn't like the way I was smiling and looking so happy or something. 
     
_I FELT THREATENED_ and I didn't know what to do other than to move over a bit 
(among the already crowded dance area DIRECTLY in front of the DJ table).  After
I moved over, he continued his power/intimidation trip on me, so I just ignored 
him and dug into the existing good part of the vibe that was ever-present.  I 
tried to share with him as much of this good vibe as I possibly could, and 
perhaps some of it got through.  He eventually backed off, but you have no idea 
how hard this experience was on me.  I was so shaken (albeit not so much visibly
so), that I had to go sit by myself on the other side of the Big Hill for about 
a half-hour or so to sort things out.
     
What is this fear that I have fallen to?  Should it be this way?  Am I wrong for
feeling threatened?  Am I not being understanding enough, or loving enough? 
What great lengths more do I need to go to in order to be as readily accepting 
as you make it sound so easy for me to do, Milton?  Do gangsters ever fuck 
around with you like they do me?  I'm 6'3", I smile a lot, and I like to dance 
for my own personal pleasure and to share energy with others around me.  Maybe 
I'm doing something wrong -- I don't know...  I wasn't going to give him a hug 
-- he looked like he wanted to eat me for lunch!  (Would you if you were in my 
shoes?)
     
Let me state that I am still dealing with my feelings about all of this, and 
that I'm TOTALLY open to discussion that could potentially change my whole 
viewpoint on this, and I'm interested in knowning how others might feel if they 
were to deal with a similar situation.
     
How would YOU feel???  
     
I love you all.
Todd
     
--------------------------------------

  Yes, there was Jungle played at Wicked's party at DV8 last Sat.  Super 
DJ Dmitri was the one who through it on.  I started freaking out and 
dancing my ass off but a lot of people just stood there :( .. I even 
heard a 'club girl' say "Don't ever go to a party if you see this guys 
name on the flyer, his name is Dmitri!"  

  As if hearing Jungle wasn't enough, Garth (I think it was Garth) played 
some acid during his FUNK MANIA set.  I guess the world is beginning to 
appreciate the energy a solid 303 groove can create.

  Speaking of 303 grooves, I finally finished a tape loaded with hard 
acid and trance.. Much thanks to Ethan and Lee for inspiring me at the 
last F&F.  I can't afford to mail it out (except to the people I allready 
owe, Hi Jacob!) but if you're interested in a copy, perhaps we can meet 
somewhere in the city.. Haight would be easiest for me..

  Thanks to everyone who came out to Harmony!  Special thanks to Larry 
for coming WAY out of his way to pick me up.  I had an awesome time 
spinning for all my friends :)

  Peace out...

-Ernie

From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@sfraves.org>
Subject: Thoughts on the vibe you bring ["David L. Bayer" <dlb@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>]
To: sfraves@sfraves.org

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: "David L. Bayer" <dlb@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Thoughts on the vibe you bring
Date: Mon, 26 Sep 1994 23:59:36 -0700 (PDT)


	Right, so we seem to have a large discussion of attitudes
connected with a certain fashion going. Or is it the other way around,
I cannot really tell anymore. A lot of thoughts that I am not sure are
really connecting, so I am going to add my own from the perspective I
have, maybe the will bring two or three or four people on to the same
wavelength...

	So, there is the baggy fashion, worn by a whole lot of people,
some of who come with big some smiles, some of who come with a stoic
expression, some of who come with snarls, some of who come with a dire
need to make someone feel small at an event that is the "shit". What
I see, is that the fashion is not the point, it is what someone is 
trying to express with their puffy jacket and baggy pants. I doubt
anyone with a smile on their face, someone that is giving some energy
bck to the group which they draw energy from, will come over as a
hardcore bad ass (Take the guy drumming two sunsets ago, he was decked
out, but no one around was looking one bit scared, or unhappy that he
was banging away on the toms). To that party I walked in behind a group
of people who dressed in 'urban' style, yet they made me feel a tad
uncomfortable, cuz I had on a pair of faded blue shorts, my bike shoes
a dark blue top, and my woolen hat. Right, so I walking behind them 
under the trees, and I keep getting these "You just do not know how to
dress" looks... Now I could take these one of a few ways: I could smile
and chuckle (but what am I smiling and chuckling at? That I am better 
than they are cuz I am above all this, I have to look like this?), I
could have gotten pissed off, expressed my rage, and taught them a
lesson (hmm, I doubt that would have done anything but made me feel like
shit two minutes later), I could have done nothing (which in my weak
hearted state, I did), or I could have employed the art of saracsm to 
make fun of these very clothes which, in part of my head, I both did not
like and found quite funny because they are after all, just clothes...
(oops, I am babbling) What I am trying to express, is that there is
a difference in people's attitudes and it can take a hell of a lot of
energy, and will to laugh each time someone attempts exert their trip
on you. (I know it can be done, I lived for six months in a town full
of these people, and I know quite a few around me these days as well).

	I have had experiences much like the one Todd (hope I am 
remembering the correct posts) described and turning to my aggressor
and introducing myself never entered my mind, but after the inital
reaction of fear I had to such a suggest subsided, I realized that is
either the best solution to the problem, or the best way to get yourself
decked for not showing the proper respect to your superior (I am sure
a lot of people who disagree that it would cuz someone to deck me, but
I cannot get it out of my head). Yet, I do have to say I wish people would
take this approach to getting rid of an unwanted overbearing presence 
(not necessarily make the person exerting the overbearing presence go 
away, just make the overbearing presence go away). But this is in part
due to my own insecurities due to a whistle that seems to be a bit loud
when matched against a sound system the size of Sunset's... (ah ha, you
know know who I am....)
	So I am ending this post in a sec. I am hoping I have not been
missing the point of this thread, and misconstruing it as a discussion
about different attitudes and the way those attitudes are expressed. I
will have to say that if it is really about gangsta style fashion popping
up at parties, and this 'fashion' may be evil or even a welcome change,
I have but to smirk and stick my tongue out and go PPPPPTTTTTTHHHHHHBBBBBB...
at I discussion I find entirely silly... Ach, but it is such a livid
discussion, aye?

dave

> 
> I've been thinking about this a lot, because it brings one question in my 
> mind:  Is it possible to create your own destiny just by believing 
> something is true?

Maybe not EXACTLY, but sure, as long as you believe in something, you CAN
make it your destiny.  As long as you believe in your dreams...as long as
you keep dreaming...and visualizing in your head...you are sure to actualize
these dreams.  So, in a sense...to a certain extent dealing with control
over YOURSELF (not the outer environment)...yes, you can control your own
destiny.

An interesting place to visualize and practice your goals for the future
is in lucid dreams... 

What I found paradoxical about that Star Trek episode is that if he went to
the anti-time hole when he was young, why doesn't he expect it to happen
at the 2 times when he's older?  Like, at which time period did this
shifting start to occur with him?  

Well, maybe this should be left to the proper newsgroups...

-djkc

> 
> You should be able to get a Denon for about $1000 or a Stanton for $700
> (new).  DO NOT buy the Gemini one...  Most important flaw: it's cueing
> sucks--with a single press of the search button you jump about 2 seconds in
> the song.  It's also front loading instead of top loading.  The Technics
> one is beautiful, but its about $1300+ for a single disc player.
> 
> The Stanton CD-11 allows you to cue frame by frame.  I have one and it's
> nice; missing a few bells and whistles, but I didn't have money for the
> Denon.
> 
	Denon has different models. I have the DN-2000F. It's good
	and easy to use, but I don't like the way it has to move in a track
	(a couple of buttons to do fast search, but if your track is 10 
	minutes long and you want to go almost to the end...)
	Anyway, the new one (I don't remember the model) is much more powerful
	(and expensive !) It has a joggle to move in a track and you can
	also jump directly to a point, typing directly the time on a
	numeric keyboard).

	Prices: I paid ~ $900 for the Denon DN-2000F last year. It should cost
	less now and I suppose the one Michael is referring to ( $1000 ) is
	the new one (I tought it was more expensive).
	Denon also have a single version called DN-1000F.
	I got a catalogue from Music Emporium and the carry the DN-2000F, the
	DN-1000F and the Gemini CDs. They also have some Stanton stuff but
	I didn't see the CD player. You may want to call them and check the
	prices: 1-800-648-8460.

ciao,
	Raffaele

On Tue, 27 Sep 1994, allen jebian wrote:
> Art Forum several issues ago called it the paradigm rave music... Most of 
> it is a lot like old hardcore breakbeat techno just a bit "classier".

not sure if i'd call it 'classier'..i certainly prefer the old-school UK 
hardcore - pianos, vocal samples, the whole nine yards -  but this new 
breakbeat mostly leaves me cold on the dancefloor. i sometimes enjoy 
listening to it, as armchair-techno-type-stuff, but ususally it makes me 
leave the floor....the reason i was so happy is that i've been 
*saturated* with alot of house (which i find boring, not that house is 
boring, but what i've heard lately is) here, and being from the east 
coast rave scene, am used to lots more diversity. therefore the jungle 
element was quite welcome. :) when he spun 'incredible' i was yelling 
'BOOYAKA BOOYAKA' at the top of my lungs. :)

mikebee

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is now basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules.

 It's every Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I shifted the lunch meeting time a 
bit -  I hope to see more of you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

Alissa Feinberg <AFEINBER@sybex.com>:
> Do you mind if I ask you a personal question here...?about you're 
> statement below, don't you get zits all over you're legs after a 
> night of dancing in polyester britches? Granted they LOOK cool, 
> but...

Who's gonna let a few zits come between them and their fashion!

From:    Alissa Feinberg <AFEINBER@sybex.com>
> > > Fashion should be poked fun at, because it is fundamentally stupid,
> > > unnatural, and poseurish. Even worse is when fashion becomes a uniform,
> 
> I'd agree that it's stupid when it becomes a uniform and the 
> person(s) doing it don't understand why they're doing it (the lemming 
> thing), but I don't see that fashion is "fundamentally stupid"... do 
> you care to explain?

I guess I really meant "it is fundamentally stupid in the context of
gangsta wear". THere's not much range allowed in gangsta wear so it gets
old real fast. Same with grunge. And it is a "uniform". That's what I like
least.

Also, I like colors a lot, and gangsta wear is not very colorful for the
most part (exceptions are always present, e.g. "Cross Colors")...

I don't have any problem with utilitarian "workman" clothing from which
some gangsta wear and some "rave wear" evolved, other than the fact
that I'd like to be paying "workman" prices for that fashion, not "idle
rich" prices... A while back, the SF Examiner magazine had a special on
young SF fashion designers and one group was "designing" this kind  of
"workman" clothing along with "Adidas" inspired fashion. I think it's
pretty ridiculous to call yourself a  designer when all you're doing is
a retread of a has-been. And beyond that, I think calling this retread
a "fashion" is laughable. Wow! cotton, a square-cut shirt, and big
metal buttons. Big f-ing deal. But hey, what would I know, i'm just a
geek and haven't been properly indoctrinated in the fine arts of
marketing.

> What's wrong with somebody wanting to look good? to do something 
> flashy and fun to get noticed? I think it's natural for people to do 
> stuff like this. It's a problem when people do it without being aware 
> of what they're doing... because their friend, mother, boss, priest, 
> teacher, billboard, magazine, television tells them that if they 
> don't do it they're not worth anything. So how much of this is a 
> problem with individual people or with the culture we've created?

I agree completely... a culture is made up of individual people so it's a
problem with both. It's also due to mass marketing and easy dissemination
of advertisements in a variety of media. Fashion now "invades" people's
homes and forces a level of conformity and normalization of thought that
we've never had to deal with before.  Even when you're not experiencing
something that is explicitly a commercial, you're dealing with a lot of
subliminal marketing push through endorsements.

From:    ravnbird@crl.com (RavnBird, Denis)
> Was it my mom I just heard nagging...

"Momma threw me out till I get some pants that fit..."
				D.Thomas @ Pere Ubu...

> Do you wear fashion as a facade or as an expression?

The latter. I guess some people wear it as an expression of conformity.

From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
> It is a shame to get turned off to what can
> be so beautiful. There are some talented 
> people in SF decorating themselves for
> everyone's enjoyment. 

And I enjoy them greatly. But they're not wearing boring cookie-cutter
monochromatic gangsta wear.  Their wearing cool metallic pants, or crazy
psychedelic hats, weird froot-loop backpacks, etc. I luv dat stuff.

The thing to notice is that these folks are not following fashion.
They're leading it. You notice and enjoy them because they don't look
like anything you've seen before.

From: jamiel@sybase.com (Jamie Lawrence) 
> > Fashion should be poked fun at, because it is fundamentally stupid, 
> > unnatural, and poseurish. Even worse is when fashion becomes a uniform, 
>

> threat to the nature of society. Through  unnatural acts, he spreads 
> immorality and disease..."

Yeah, I guess your incredible power of syllogism also allows you to prove
I'm Adolph Hitler because I once said the word "German".

> >   People are wearing the clothes because they
> > want to be judged. Otherwise they could have saved their parents a lot
> > of money and shopped at K-Mart.
> 
> "...Saved their parents..."??? Some of us spend their own money to be
> stupid, unnatural and poseurish, thankyaverymuch.

Guess you haven't been around any suburban high schools lately have you?
Palo Alto High is back in effect, and I've seen what the kids are wearing.
Are you telling me they can buy all that bullshit overpriced baggy-wear and
"grunge fashion" delivering newspapers?

>From bong@next.com (Bruce Ong):
> but I dont see why fashion itself should be the blame. That  
> person who cant carry it off is stupid, IMHO, not fashion, as an institution.  
> When somebody does it "just right", it gives many of us a sense of
> 'perfection'

Depends on what fashion you're talking about, don't it? I saw a fashion
magazine recently that had a picture of a button that said "grunge is
ghastly" -- I guess I'd have to agree, thought I don't think much of the
high-society b...matron that was wearing it....

I just can't get with every cycle of attempted anti-fashion becoming
fashionable itself. After punk was passe, it used to be "new wave"...
last year and this year "grunge"... this year and next year
"gangsta"... and the year after that, people will be dressing like me,
yes like me!

> But I like fashion. I think it's one of the greatest human inventions.
> I used   to be fairly clueless about fashion -- thinking it has nothing
> to do with me,   but a trip to paris few years back completely changed
> my opinion of it.

I recently bought two shirts in Paris. I must be really cool!

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Just what is a "303 groove",  and what does it mean.

Hope I'm not condescending, but: 303 refers to a Roland TB-303, a 
little synth for making basslines that you have undoubtedly heard if you 
have listened to acid/trance/whatever for any length of time.  The sound 
is squelchy and, well, acidic.

A 303-groove is an acid/trance/whatever groove, I guess.

	Sami

Larry Ching asks...
> I was wondering if there were any opinions about the upcoming 
> Megatripolis ? I was going to invite a non-raver friend to go
> with me to it.

This may or may not be relevant...

I was in London a few weeks ago and went to a Megatripolis event there, and
it was easily one of the best raves I have ever been to.  The music was great
the entire night (and I'm usually a pretty harsh critic).  They had a
house/funk room, a hard techno room, an ambient room and a live band room
(where Test Department played).  It was held in a film studio, which meant
that all of the rooms were acoustically isolated from each other.  (You
couldn't heard dance music in the ambient room.)  There was a large outdoor
chill space, they had free water, and they had a room where artists were
selling trippy artowrk.  The promoters obviously cared enough to put on a
very fine production.  (BTW: it cost 10 pounds ($15) to get in.)

The crowd was also especially good.  Although some people were drinking,
there was no negative alcohol vibe.  (This is probably more due to
differences in British and American culture in general, though -- people in
Britain drink to get light-headed and happy, not to get rude and annoying.)
The people were really into it.  It seemed like everyone was having a great
time.  Hardly anyone was standing around.  There was also quite a bit of
interaction on the dancefloor, too.  And the vibe was so warm and natural,
it never even *occurred* to me to question whether or not people were on drugs.




From sfraves-owner  Wed Sep 28 14:12:07 1994

Received: from netcom6.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA23825; Wed, 28 Sep 1994 14:12:00 -0700

	id OAA11432; Wed, 28 Sep 1994 14:11:42 -0700
Message-Id: <199409282111.OAA11432@netcom6.netcom.com>
To: Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Final Star Trek/Paradox 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Tue, 27 Sep 94 08:48:46 PDT."
             <Pine.3.89.9409270858.A10640-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU> 
Date: Wed, 28 Sep 94 14:11:41 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>From Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>:
> Interesting post.  It just want you to know that there are people like 
> me  and other sfr people who believe in creating their own phuture 
> WITHOUT the need to harm others in the process.  And this is where we 
> need everyone's help enlisted.  If enough people BELIEVE the world will 
> be a different, more peaceful, more spiritual place where ravers and 
> people are accepted, it will all come true.  At least that's what I 
> believe.  

That sounds good and reasonable. If this is done with good intentions,
with no structure or hierarchy, I might even buy in.

But the idyllic situation you describe could easily be subverted by
"happy police" enforcing groupthink, combined with people too lazy to
think for themselves but more than happy to regurgitate some spoon-fed
dogma or "spirituality". Throw some "control freaks" in to lead the
flock and you've got trouble. This has been going on for a long time,
all the way from the early Christians to this summer's Zippy Fiasco...

This kind of crap always happens when you try to get a "movement"
together. That's what makes me wary.

I'd rather have a PLURality of thought and opinions get together and
party in unity, than a bunch of blissed-out sheep bleating "P.L.U.R."
over and over again. The differences between people is what is
interesting; the spiritual/moral outgrowths of the rave or hippy
movements sometimes tend to squelch the differences and enforce a
boring sameness of thought. And I certainly don't want some
prescribed "spirituality" to be a part of the package.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

>From: jamiel@sybase.com (Jamie Lawrence)

>>     -JS, "Things God Hates", 1991
>
>Yeah, I guess your incredible power of syllogism also allows you to prove
>I'm Adolph Hitler because I once said the word "German".

I don't think I'm quite that good, but I would try to prove
something slightly more interesting, were I to bother.

Well, I guess you missed out on the sentence you deleted there.
I already archived it and don't feel like digging it out for
a silly little correction like this, but the deleted material
pointed out that making statements like

"
Fashion should be poked fun at, because it is fundamentally stupid,
unnatural, and poseurish. Even worse is when fashion becomes a uniform,
"

quickly displays the speaker to as dogmatic, closeminded
and frankly rather stupid in the eyes of people who might to
disagree with said speaker.

Hint: saying X is _fundamentally_ Y, unless supportable by the
same logic that allows one to say "Dogs are animals", is the problem
here. If you still don't get it, try plugging in other words, like
"Ravers are fundmentally braindead, fat, and ugly." Doesn't work well,
does it?

> >   People are wearing the clothes because they
> > want to be judged. Otherwise they could have saved their parents a lot
> > of money and shopped at K-Mart.
>
>> "...Saved their parents..."??? Some of us spend their own money to be
>> stupid, unnatural and poseurish, thankyaverymuch.
>
>Guess you haven't been around any suburban high schools lately have you?
>Palo Alto High is back in effect, and I've seen what the kids are wearing.
>Are you telling me they can buy all that bullshit overpriced baggy-wear and
>"grunge fashion" delivering newspapers?

You're right, I haven't been in an HS since I stopped attending
several years back. This is completely irrelevent, however, becuase
again, I think you missed the point, the point being that

1) I said "some of us...", which last I checked left plenty of
room in 'the rest' for differences (those being your HS students),

2) what was said was "people.... Otherwise they..." which seems to at
least try to implicate any humans who 'are wearing the clothes', and

3) 2 above is not true, as some people into fashion happen to support
themselves and thier fashion habits.

Is that easier to get down?


-j
