Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA15574; Wed, 28 Sep 94 15:37:21 PDT
Date: Wed, 28 Sep 94 15:37:21 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9409282237.AA15574@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: More Bleating (was Re: Final Star Trek/Paradox
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Niels asserts:
> I'd rather have a PLURality of thought and opinions get together and
> party in unity, than a bunch of blissed-out sheep bleating "P.L.U.R."
> over and over again.

The one thing that has bothered me (just a little) about the "PLUR" 
acronym is that it has caught on a little too much like some kind of
prescribed raver code-of-conduct.  Nevertheless, you have to admit that  
it is hard to have people with "a PLURality of thought and opinions get 
together and party in unity" without a certain amount of Peace, Unity & 
Respect.  Love, depending on your definition, doesn't hurt things either.  
Other ideals, like Openmindedness, also come in handy.  I think what you 
are saying is that just believing and preaching these words pales against 
actively experiencing what they are supposed to represent.  This may be 
true, but it doesn't necessarily make the words and acronyms conceptually 
invalid.

> The differences between people is what is
> interesting; the spiritual/moral outgrowths of the rave or hippy
> movements sometimes tend to squelch the differences and enforce a
> boring sameness of thought. 

I can't speak for hippies, but so far, the only thing ravers around
here seem to be able to agree on is that Sunset is a fun party.  :)

The key thing about the spiritual outgrowth of raving is that it is
an *outgrowth*.  The spirituality that some ravers experience
comes from the EXPERIENCE.  I.e. our actions aren't governed by some 
externally defined ideals, rather, the ideals are realized by our act
of coming together and transcending ourselves on the dancefloor.  

Yes, there is always the danger of overdefining these discovered ideals 
and then trying to *follow* them.  But as long as we can just let go 
of everything, stop worrying about what *should* be while connecting with 
each other and  sharing our energy through music and dance, I think the
special vibe that happens at good raves will remain unforced and sincere.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\Everything/\Is/\Possible/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

Precedence: bulk

Michael Wertheim spilled his beans:
>The crowd was also especially good.  Although some people were drinking,
>there was no negative alcohol vibe.  (This is probably more due to
>differences in British and American culture in general, though -- people in
>Britain drink to get light-headed and happy, not to get rude and annoying.)
>The people were really into it.  It seemed like everyone was having a great
>time.  Hardly anyone was standing around.  There was also quite a bit of
>interaction on the dancefloor, too.  And the vibe was so warm and natural,
>it never even *occurred* to me to question whether or not people were on drugs.

 Mijo, you got it on! There are good alcahol vibes, good sober vibes, good
E-vibes, everywhere...In Brazil, as in your experience of Britain, there
are people who get euphoric and lower their barriers on a beer or a rum and
coke. Must be the age limit here, creates a sense of awe and anticipation
in teenagers, so when they can drink, it MUST be to excess, and that
conditions them to binges for several years (Frat parties, anyone?).

Carnival is drunken revelry in many latin cultures, sometimes synergized
with ether (Whoosh! Kill da brain!). But the vibe is very much like one of
those raves you walk away smiling ear to ear like felix himself.....

I love that type of clean vibe, too, where drugs are irrelevant. I feel
that way at sunset, and it's great to know that people are enjoying
themselveswith just the vibe in their veins and galen under their
tongue.....
Right on Wertheim!

Lotsa love, 
 Milton and the E-Bee.....

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 26 Sep 1994 22:30:51 -0700
From: Randy Primeaux <tranze@teleport.com>
To: SoCal Ravers <socal-raves@ucsd.edu>
Subject: Jack's House

Fingers, Inc "Can You Feel It"  accapella on Trax records 12"

		*** Jack's House ***

In the beginning, there was Jack, and Jack had a groove.
  And from this groove came the grooves of all grooves.
   And while one day viciously throwing down on his box,
Jack boldy declared, "Let there be HOUSE!" and house music was born.
"I am, you see, I AM THE CREATOR!, and this is my house."
 "And, in my house there is ONLY house music."
"But, I am not so selfish because once you enter my house it then
   becomes OUR house, and OUR house music."
And, you see, no one man owns house, because house music
	is a universal language, spoken and understood by all.
You see, house is a feeling that no one can understand really
  unless you're deep into the vibe of house.
House is an uncontrolable desire to jack your body.
	And, as I told you before, this is our house and our house music.
And in every house, you understand, there is a keeper.
			And in this house, the keeper is Jack.
Now some of you who might wonder, who is Jack and what is it that Jack does?
Jack is the one who gives you the power to jack your body.
Jack is the one who gives you the power to do the snake.
Jack is the one who gives you the key to the wiggly worm.
Jack is the one who learns you how to walk your body.
Jack is the one that can bring nations and nations of all
	Jackers together under one house.
You may be black, you may be white, you may be Jew or Gentile.
It don't make a difference in OUR House.
					  And this is fresh.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

URL = http://www.teleport.com/~tranze                  -=Funkengruven /\

Date: Wed, 28 Sep 94 22:01:11 EDT
Subject: Re: Final Star Trek/Paradox 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

NPM says "I'd rather have a PLURality of thought and opinions get together
and party in unity, than a bunch of blissed-out sheep bleating "P.L.U.R."
over and over again. The differences between people is what is interesting"

This is one of the things I was trying to get across in my original g-reply
to g-fear.  Are you really tripping hard enough?  And even if you're new to
this particular mindfuck, will you be satisfied in the future?  Its kind of
like the darkside breakbeat(very unhappy jungle) stuff that I almost never
hear spun in this city -- its a different trip, a new flavor.  Hip-hop, goth,
punk, whatever, when its true its vibrant and creative and a communal vibe
exists no matter if it doesn't seem 'happy' to you.   I'm not really jaded, I
LOVE house culture(movement, as Niels points out, implies leaders, direction)
its the most amazing scene I've ever been involved in.  But it hasn't changed
that much since the late 80's and nothing will kill it faster than
stagnation, repetition.  And the best way to get others interested in what
we're doing is to go visit them!  Fashion can be a great way to crossover by
the way.  Take this gangsta stuff, ravers have adopted some of that style so
g's think, hey those guys look kinda like us and that beat is phat,maybe we
could party together.  Same goes for grunnge and several other sub-cultures
ravers sample and recycle.

Just some more thoughts,
phuture

There's a neat thing on the Wired WWW site all about that party that
DeeLite was at down in LA.  When people wrote how bad DeeLite sounded, it kinda
reminded me of working on a concert scene for the Doors movie way back
when.  they just played a tape and Val Kilmer just moved around..the rest
of the band just pretended to play the instruments.  That was because
all the sound was going to be dubbed over in the studio anyway.
Same thing with "Millenium 1999"--it's part of a movie called Strange
Days starring Angela Basset and acting god Ralph Fiennes written and
produced by Jim "Terminator" Cameron.  Juliette Lewis was supposed to be there
as well.  They probably had some really cool scenes during the party and
had to reset stuff and refilm some sequences which would account for the
pauses in the music...

ANYWAY...the URL to the Wired Rest Stop is 
http://www.wired.com/

check it out if you can...it's pretty interesting...like the article says,
it's proably teh first time actors had to PAY to be seen on film!

(the extras at least!)

Yeah, I've been talking to Kairo who is apparently the main "promoter"
behind sf's megatripolis. The vibe I get from him so far is pretty good.
One thing he mentioned to me is that he wants megatripolis to do "sound
system" nights wherein local soundsystems -- the pacific posse, or the
liquid posse, or the wicked posse -- for example would be featured. The
Friends & Family sound system (as it were :) has been invited to do a night
there. 

In any event, I'm very curious to see how megatripolis unfolds, though, in
truth, I wonder whether there's any real association or basis for
comparison between the sf and the London version...

Kairo certainly seems intent on involving the local community though,
something I cant help but see as positive.

take it easy
ethan

> >SO YOU WANNABE A DJ... :)
> >
> >Get your picture in 3D World.  Pose in a photo booth.  Don't smile or
> >look interesting.  Shave your head if you play hardcore.  Just shave
> >your head.  Look aggressive.  Look like the promoter at the last
> >rave ripped you off big time. Look like your parents molested you as a
> >child. Look like you have a problem with the world. It gets rave babes.
> >
> >Get 3D World to do a DJ Review on you.  Make it witty, and don't seem to
> >take yourself seriously (even if you do).  Name your all time Top 5
> >Tracks after obscure $9.95 titles you found down in the return bin at
> >Reach'n.  Make it look like you have got it together in the real world,
> >and that you just "Deejay" to relax.  You often listen to classical music,
> >soul, jazz and african.  Your current Top 5 cannot match anything that
> >anyone could possibly like or recognise.
> >
> >When you get to a rave situation, or guest DJ spot at a club, don't play
> >for the crowd.  Play all your b-sides.  You lay down the score - you got
> >hired by the promoter to play because you got a reputation.  Now
> >just because at the last rave you played you got hit over the head with
> >a crate of records by the DJ coming up after you doesn't mean it's the
> >end : it's just the beginning.  You'll be the butt of every 15 year old
> >girl's school gossip "...did you see the big DJ fight last Saturday
> >night between DoorJammin' and MC Hoppin'Bill-E?"  You'll suddenly get
> >yourself a secure paid career in the hardcore scene - you're doing well
> >now.  If anyone messes with you, just say "I'm from the U.K. so f--- off!"
> >
> >Now after you've played at your first big rave "And Introducing
> >Hoppin'Bill-E", even tho' you were speeding off your dial and not one track
> >stayed in a mix for more than 5 seconds ... you are now ready to organise your
> >first illegal rave.  Get your friends together and drive around town in a
> >beaten up ford escort pasting flyers on telegraph poles up and down Oxford St.
> >If you get questioned, just shout "bugger off, poofta!".
> >
> >Paint the rave details all over the front door at Central Station Records -
> >don't be a pansy and ask for permission - JUST DO IT.  They owe it to
> >you.  You play their records and people buy them, so they owe you some
> >free publicity.  Get them to sell pre-sale tickets, and needle them
> >every day, "How are they selling, babe???".
> >
> >Get an international guest - no, not a real one.  Just rip some palid UK
> >tourist off a plane at Sydney Airport, load him up on E, and if anyone from 3D
> >approaches him just get him to repeatedly say "sod off" or "get sorted".
> >International Guest Direct From The U.K. --> DJ Slingshott --> LIVE
> >He won't be able mix or programme but everyone will be so --cked on
> >drugs they won't notice.
> >
> >Now if the police try to close you down - even though you've got five
> >warrants for your arrest from bashing up a DJ last month while you were
> >losing the plot - stage a protest.  Save The Rave.  Scream and shout,
> >"Bloody oppressors", "fascist", appeal to the feelings of your crowd.
> >This is a free world, you can do whatever you want now you have a
> >following.  A mission from god.  Even though the warehouse roof is
> >showing visible cracking from sonic booms, five people collapsed from
> >asphixiation, and the owner of the warehouse has just arrived (still
> >dressed in pyjamas and angry) - you got to take the good with the bad
> >and forge on ahead for the rave scene.
> >
> >Take lots of coke & LSD and convince yourself that God sent you down to earth
> >to organise the most penultimate, wicked party.  And remember while
> >you are planning it in your solitary gaol cell, the mafia have
> >established strong communication lines from the 'inside' to ensure your
> >next rave is suitably supplied with drugs!
> >
> >Good Luck ;)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: 27 Sep 1994 21:50:15 GMT
From: isao@morph.com (isao)
Organization: Morph's Outpost on the Digital Frontier
Reply-To: isao@morph.com
Subject: Re: Final Star Trek/Paradox

>> I've been thinking about this a lot, because it brings one question
>> in my mind: Is it possible to create your own destiny just by
>> believing something is true?
>
>You are what you believe :).

Weird, but I was talking about this kind of thing to a friend last night
before I read this thread.  We were talking (a little tongue in cheek) about
the philisophical basis of Schwartznegger movies et al.

As it relates to this thread, in "Total Recall" Arnold asks the mutant leader
Kuwato (?) who is he, and how can he get his identity back.  The mutant
replies, why, what does it mater... "you are defined by your actions..." not
your memories or past.

I think this is fundementally different from Easter thought which doesn't
support redemption in the Judeo-Christian vein.  Eastern thought (or at least
the Japanese Zen thing ) is more that life is a continuum coxisting with a
universal continuum.  The Christain thing is even on one's death bed, one can
"find God" and attain redemption and go to heaven.  It seemed like a raw deal
to me in Sunday school, for those who were always "good."

But the philisophcal point was the only we can define ourselves.  I could go
on (as I did yesterday) but I think the point is clear enough.

Ob Pop Culture Movie Meditation Topic: Bill Murray in Groundhog Day...

Isao (aka Jake)
jake@cyberden.com
isao@morph.com

- sent via an evaluation copy of BulkRate (unregistered).

From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: This Week's SF Rave Guide!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFRaves)

Precedence: bulk


Megatripolis should be the most interesting party this weekend - or at
least the most ambitious, and you can still count on Sunset to finish off
the weekend.  Dig! and a Groovy Summer's Day should both have some great
acid jazz-type stuff, and the other parties on Saturday have great DJs,
but may be a little pricey.  Don't forget Come/Unity next Wednesday!

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Thursday, September 29th - The Velvet Shop
        DJs Mei-Lwun, Rick Preston, Garth
        @ Club Selections in San Jose
        FREE! For directions and more info. call 408-236-3732.  21+

Friday, September 30th - Nocturnal Pursuit
        Clear Lake cabin party 415.267.6193

Friday, September 30th - Dig! - dead on the heavy funk!
        DJs Thomas, Charlotte & Manny
        Brave New World, 1751 Fulton. 21+, 10pm-2am.

Saturday, October 1st - Megatripolis West
        "a tribal techknowlogical trip-out trancefloor"
        Cathedral--dj's  DRC,Goa Gil,Christoph,Dutch
        Psychonaut's Playshop---all night S.P.A.Z. with dj's 
        Susan(ysh),Topher,Happy,live tecno by Planet 6 + morning Ambi-Sketch
                with the Rev. Alex Strange.Tarot and Massage by Radion.
        Parallel Univ-"The Trouble With You Kids Today" John Perry Barlow
        Multimedia---Stefan and Scramble
        9pm-sunrise  18+  Trocadero 520 4th st. downtown SF
        to involve yourself----call 415-281-KNOW
         for online info --  email tess@ocf.berkeley.edu

        Josh  Jeno  Garth  Tony  Spun  Markie

        advance tix $8 at Bulletproof, 629 Haight        
        415.255.7168

Here are some weeklies, in the house/techno/acid jazz/etc vein.  Some
of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

---------------------------- T h u r s d a y --------------------------------

Universal Groove - $5. 415.281.5913  510.869.2727
Lift - Digit, David Harness & guests - $5, 21+, 55 Natoma, SF - 415.267.5984

        journees@netcom.com  408.236.2102  415.267.6974

        [9/29 - john howard, markie, spun]

        (every other Thursday)

        415.905.8811    415.882.1178

---------------------------- Radio/TV Shows ---------------------------------
Sunday evening 9-11pm - Universal radio at 89.1 FM.  Trance dance
        and power house.  Guest DJs weekly (SF & East Bay)
Sunday night 10pm-2am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X  KWOD 106.5 (Sac)
Sunday night 10pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 - Progressive house, 
        acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.
Mondays midnight-2am - "The Mix Show" KWOD 106.5(Sac) - lineup 916.551.0494
Tuesdays noon-3pm - "London Jamaica" w/Unknown KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
Thursday evening 9pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3 (SF)
weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)

Date	9/29/94
Subject	Cow Palace "Rave"
>From	Todd Spaulding
To	Awesome Ravers

Internet mail                 Cow Palace "Rave"

I recommend you avoid events like this if you don't want to waste your money and
feel like a cow all night, trying to weed through the crowds and crowds of
people with lousy attitudes (Not EVERYONE, of course).  Just IMHO.

If you've never been to a "Rave" at the Cow Palace, and you have nothing better
to do and a friend to go with who is just as bored, then it might be worth the
undoubtedly "interesting" experience to go.

Interesting, but only in the way that you know you'll never go twice.  I
wouldn't go as far as calling it a nightmare (that depends on you), but "rave"
events held there are certainly not my idea of a good party.

By the way, I base my opinions based on my semi-recent attendence to "World
Groove '94" by Cool World Productions several months ago at the Cow Palace.

It was, <ahem>, interesting.  ...yet somehow not as interesting as the flyer
overtly suggested (demanded?) I believe.

Todd

--------------------------------------

It's nice to hear that some folx aren't down on alcohol for poor reasons.

obtain...

but I am really tired of this puritanical tendency that is exhibited in 
"the scene", and on this list. Alcohol doesn't have to be nasty, mean, 
violent, and coppin' a 'tude.

Thanks for reading this :) :) :)



Maui

Additional info on Nocturnal Persuit!!
======================================

First off!!   The info number has changed...  The new number: 415-487-5426
should give out the directions.

DJ's - Rhion,  Barnes, Tracey,  Nate,  DJ Unknown - trance in the evening,  
and house in the morning.   Plus a live Acid Jazz band. 

Ambient cabin... Mark,  and Allan from Ameba plus special guests plus
a live acid jazz performance. 

Time:   Starts at 8 pm Friday evening...  FREE!!    Goes well into the
next day (Saturday afternoon).    Bring your own food,   water provided,
smart drinks available.  

I haven't really heard these DJ's,  so don't know how good they are,   but
I am always open for new changes in the rave scene,  and the price to
attend (Free!!) makes it all worth the effort to get up there and
check it out.     

If this number doesn't check out,   please let me know,  and I'll personally
Email the directions.    I'm planning on attending if I can get a couple
of riders to share the gas.

NOTICE:   Riders needed to go with me to the Clear Lake rave...    Call me
at 415-381-5847 if you want to go.     I live in Mill Valley,    but planning
on getting into the SF (Haight area) and can meet you at the Horshoe Cafe
or some other place if anyone wants a ride.    Don't know if I'm going
with a friend or taking the trek myself.     NOTE:  my car is small,  so
can take only 3 people (Perhaps 4 if you don't mind getting squished).

Cheers
CC

	<Pine.3.89.9409292353.A16135-0100000@netcom4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

"Maui-Your Sister's House" writes:
 > 
 > > >The crowd was also especially good.  Although some people were drinking,
 > > >there was no negative alcohol vibe.

 > I am also fully cognizant of the fact that alcohol can really mess you up --
 > but I am really tired of this puritanical tendency that is exhibited in 
 > "the scene", and on this list. Alcohol doesn't have to be nasty, mean, 
 > violent, and coppin' a 'tude.

I happen to agree. I've been to several events where alcohol was sold
and some have had very good vibes (fond examples: F&FII & III). And boy
when you've busted your butt for hours throwing or attending a party,
an ice cold beer at 4am is nearly orgasmic.

I think it's more a function of the crowd than a function of the
intoxicant. Throw in a bunch of (kids/oldpeople/gangstas/businesspeople/
lovechildren/urbs/suburbs/hillbillies/anyone) with "I don't like you."
attitudes, and the party is going to suck. And in this case, alcohol
will probably make it worse (compare to E).

Now start with a crowd of people mostly wanting to share and have fun,
and the party flies, alcohol or no.

People that want to put a lot of energy into discouraging certain
substances should instead spend that energy reaching out to people at
parties and fostering a positive attitude.  I've never ceased to be
amazed at how much energy one person can catalyze at a party by
something simple like handing out blo-pops and talking with people.
Reaching out to people works. It's one of the things that made me feel
at home at my first rave, and it's something I believe in doing at the
parties I help promote.

Just a heads up that following up discussion here with a little energy
out there will make a huge difference in people's experiences.

:)

Sean

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: MEGABOOOM@aol.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 29 Sep 94 22:05:12 EDT
Subject: Re:that big party in LA(Millenium)

Yes, in once sense we had to pay $10 to be an extra.  But otherwise this is a
breif stort of what I GOT for only $10.

I arrived at the site at about 9:15, parked at the free parking lot that was
printed on my ticket.  Then I went the the enterence which was at 3rd and
flower not 4th and flower and waited for 5 to 10 minutes in line. 

Now I am inside and this guy point to a sign that says "free food and drinks
with ticket stub".  My friends and I skipped dinner so we were stoked.  I had
a turkey sandwich, a hot dog and washed it down with an O'Douls non-alch beer
all for free.  We grabbed a few bottle of evian and walked into the tech area
where we play some cd-rom and cool vr games.  even our very own AOL had a
booth there.  

Anyway we walked toward a huge video screen where a small system was playing
some wicked trance.  But we explored more and went to the main system which
was at 5th and flower.  there they had another Huge video screen.  At one
point they had a mind melting video playing but the rest of the time is
simply displayed "2000" real big.  The confetti falling was AMAZING, it
filled up the sky so much you couldn't figure out where it started or ended.

We found a bunch of happy people at the sound stacks farthest away from the
stage.  we hung out here for a while and loved the beats.  The sound wasn't
very loud unless you stood inside  the area that the six different stacks
pointed towards.  then it was great.  The main dance area looked like it only
had enough space for 6 or 8 thousand to enjoy the sound but there was so many
other places to check out, a good flow maintained.  we went to the top of the
bonavenute hotel, and from the resturant we could look down at the five block
rave.  I heard there was 14,000 people, from up there it looked like even
more.  

Then we hung out to the left of the stage in this cool area with palm trees.
 the sound wasn't very loud here, but that turned out good because alot of
people chilled out here.  they had free water also in this area which was
great.

oops dinners ready, gotta go but it was a good trip. see ya.

To all you SFRavers planning to attend Megatripolus this weekend...   We
are trying to have a few tables set up for those folks interested in exchanging
PGP keys,  signing keys,  etc.    What we need are people who would be willing
to bring a Mac Classic,  or portable so that Mac versions of PGP can be copied
out and given to those that need it.

the table all night and watch their equipment.

Subject: The dude responsible for having Sunset cancelled
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Some additional info that came my way...

It turns out that this dude (Who shall be nameless) who freaked out at the
last Sunset,  also owned the VMail for Nocturnal Persuit.    What this means,
is that the thousand or more flyers that Dan handed out on Nocturnal Persuit
that gave the info number is not going to be updated in time for Nocturnal 
persuit (NP).  Thus was the reason why I gave out the new number earlier.

This is a very bad bummer for those folks putting on the party,  because of
all those folks that got the flyer.    A large search is underway to locate 
this dude so that he can update the Info for NP.

If anyone knows this person,   please let me know,  so we cen get him to
update the number.    

Apparently,  he was taken to the hospital,  and eventually released.   Some
people have reported to have seen him on the Haight,   but no word yet on
if he's been found.    I suspect that he is laying low (Much to the regret
to those folks putting on NP).

More later...

CC

Hi y'all (sic)

I know it's a drag when somebody gets greedy or whatever and imbibes
too much, causing problems for themselves and others, *but*, I'd be
*surprised* to find that among those who do *anything* there are people
who have *never* made the mistake of taking too much of something [the
*what* doesn't really matter, too much of anything can be a drag].

While this may have shut down a party, I think it's good to remember
that many of us have been there and some of us will likely be there
again, at some point in our lives...let's not let society's attitude
about intoxication make us forget that the person afflicted and their
health/safety/comfort is *more* important than partying whether the
cops got called or not.  I doubt that the person involved is not clear
on the concept that they made a mistake, so let's not get down on 'em
too hard whoever they might be.  Unless this person does this repeatedly
[as in regularly, has been spoken to and still doesn't do anything],
they deserve a little sympathy and support and could probably use it now
more than ever.

Family or not, I personally hope he/she recovers quicky and fully
as I trust that the rest of us will find another place to rave...

as for the cops, it's high time we got 'em off our case for these
types of offenses, and I sure hope y'all (sic) VOTE!!!!

sermon over

i'm out...

*

> Galen seemed to understand why the cops revoked the permit
> I think He is just dissappointed that it was one of the family who 
> screwed up. We screwed it up for ourselves basically.
> 
> salutations, allen@ameba

From: David Whitsitt Goodson <whitsitt@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: Def. of Deep House?
To: Sun Kim <sunkim@mercury.sfsu.edu>
cc: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9409301140.A29679-0100000@mercury>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9409301610.A24158-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



On Fri, 30 Sep 1994, Sun Kim wrote:

> 
> 
> On Fri, 30 Sep 1994, Jack Wang wrote:
> 
> > Freddie Bain is one of the best deep house DJs I have ever heard.  I'll be
> > there if it happens.
> 
> I've heard this term before but I could never figure what elements make 
> up deep house.  Can someone help?
> 
> 
deep house originally meant "well-produced" as opposed to rawer garage 
house.  Chicago, New York, Detroit and even parts of Europe (bust mostly 
American) are good cities for it.  Roots in disco, funk, jazz, gospel, soul, 
R&B.  Huge basslines, four-on-the-floor beats, crisp high hats, pianos, 
horns, guitar, echos, 
sampled and chopped vocals, as well as diva type singing.  Often tales of 
love lost and found, surviving through hard times, devotional or 
spiritual themes, and just plain getting down.
  For me, deep is a feeling or tone certain house tracks have.  Space in 
the mix seems as important as the actual music.  Sometimes the most 
minimalist tracks trance me out the most; that's deep house.  Mark Farrina 
plays the deepest house I've ever heard and Terrence Parker is my favorite 
producer.

love,
whitsitt

parties :)

there was nowhere to be found (whew!)
